SUMMARY OF THE PROSPECTUS

Summaries are made up of disclosure requirements known as elements (“Elements”). These Elements are numbered in
Sections A – E (A.1 – E.7). This summary contains all the Elements required to be included in a summary for this type of security and
issuer. Because some Elements are not required to be addressed, there may be gaps in the numbering sequence of the Elements. Even
though an Element may be required to be inserted in the summary because of the type of security and issuer, it is possible that no
relevant information can be given regarding the Element. In such cases, the summary includes a short description of the Element with
the words “not applicable”.

A–    Introduction and Warnings

A.1   Warnings.
This summary should be read as an introduction to this prospectus (the “Prospectus”).

The investor should base any decision to invest in the subject securities on the review of this
Prospectus as a whole.

If any claims are asserted before a court of law based on the information contained in this
Prospectus, the investor appearing as plaintiff may have to bear the costs of translating this
Prospectus prior to the commencement of the court proceedings pursuant to the national
legislation of the member states of the European Economic Area (“EEA”).

DFV Deutsche Familienversicherung AG, Frankfurt am Main, Federal Republic of Germany
(“Germany”) (the “Company”, and, together with its consolidated subsidiaries, the Group”,
“DFV”, “we”, “us”, “our” or “ourselves”), together with Hauck & Aufhäuser Privatbankiers
Aktiengesellschaft, Frankfurt am Main (“Hauck & Aufhäuser” or “Sole Global Coordinator”),
and MainFirst Bank Aktiengesellschaft, Frankfurt am Main (“MainFirst” and, together with
Hauck & Aufhäuser, the “Joint Bookrunners”), assume responsibility for the contents of this
summary, including any translations thereof, pursuant to Section 5 para. 2b no. 4 of the
German Securities Prospectus Act (Wertpapierprospektgesetz). Those persons who have
assumed responsibility for the summary, including any translations thereof, or for its issuance
(von denen der Erlass ausgeht), can be held liable, but only if this summary is misleading,
inaccurate or inconsistent when read together with the other party of the Prospectus or if it
does not provide, when read together with the other parts of the Prospectus, all necessary key
information.

B.3   Operations and principal      Overview of Our Business
      business activities of the
                                    We are an insurance company that was licensed by the Federal Financial Supervisory Authority
      issuer and principal
                                    (Bundesanstalt für Finanzdienstleistungsaufsicht – “BaFin”) to conduct business in accordance
      markets in which the
                                    with the provisions of the German Insurance Supervision Act (Versicherungsaufsichtsgesetz –
      issuer competes.
                                    “VAG”) by order of December 29, 2006. We offer supplementary insurance cover for the
                                    health, care and accident risks of natural persons and tangible assets owned by natural persons
                                    in Germany.

We see ourselves as the first insurer in Germany with a unique, fully digitalized platform. We
started our activities in 2007. Within eleven years, we have developed from an analogue
insurance company into a profitable InsurTech company with around 420,000 existing
contracts (as of June 30, 2018) as well as gross written premiums of around €71 million and an
annual profit of around €1.5 million in 2017.

We consider the development of innovative, digital solutions for supplementary dental, health
and long-term care insurance as one of our core competencies. Our products are continuously
awarded top marks by Stiftung Warentest, a leading German consumer organization
(Source: Finanztest, issues 08/2014, 11/2016, 05/2018). Our growing customer base and the
recognition of our products by Stiftung Warentest demonstrate our competitiveness in the
already largely fragmented insurance market. Despite our investments in our digitalization
processes, we have been achieving positive operating results for years with growing business
volumes. With a solvency ratio, i.e. a ratio of the available capital (own funds) to the solvency
capital requirement (SCR), of around 214% in 2017, we also benefit from a good equity base
compared with our competitors and measured against regulatory requirements.
We are active in the following segments and business areas:

•   Private supplementary health and long-term care insurance. With our private
    supplementary health and long-term care insurance, we offer our customers in-
    surance protection against financial losses in the event of illness and the need
    for care. The private supplementary health and long-term care insurance covers
    benefits for the policyholder that are not covered by the statutory and private
    health and long-term care insurance. In 2017, the segment “private supplemen-
    tary health and long-term care insurance” accounted for €53.5 million (or
    around 76%) of our gross written premiums and an annual profit of about €1.1
    million.

•   Property and accident insurance. This segment includes our supplementary in-
    surance products such as accident insurance, liability insurance, legal expenses
    insurance, household insurance, animal insurance and electronics insurance (in
    run-off). Our property insurance protects policyholders against financial losses
    caused by the occurrence of defined risks. Through liability insurance, the
    Company offers protection against claims for damages from injured third par-
    ties. Accident insurance covers personal injury resulting from accident events.
    In 2017, the segment “property and accident insurance” accounted for €17.1
    million (or around 24%) of our gross written premiums and an annual profit of
    about €0.4 million.

In addition, the Company is licensed to operate as reinsurer in the same fields for which the
Company holds a license as primary insurer. However, since 2017, the Company had not
conducted reinsurance business.
Our Digital Approach

We want to offer reasonable and excellent products that are easy to understand at the same
time, and to combine this approach with a simple process of contracting. From the overview of
our products, the customer can immediately recognize the essential benefits and premiums of
each insurance product at a glance. As a mass market player, we offer insurance products and
price levels that are suitable for the majority of potential customers.

Our goal is to offer our customers simple and paperless document management. In our digital
customer portal, our customers find everything at a glance and without paper. They can view
and download their contract documents. If a customer has concluded more than one contract,
all contracts are on our customer portal. The administration center of our customer portal
opens up the possibility of adapting insurance contracts, e.g. in the event of a necessary
change of address or payment. In addition, our customers have access to our service center.
Finally, they can use our quick regulation.

Finally, they can use our quick regulation.

We also offer all functions via our insurance app which is the mobile version of our customer
portal. In addition, customers of our accident insurance can adjust their insurance cover
flexibly on a daily basis. With our accident insurance, customers can insure their family, friends
and acquaintances, depending on the situation.

We strive for a quick and uncomplicated settlement of claims. When settling claims in
supplementary health insurance, we rely on the use of artificial intelligence (“AI”). AI helps us
decide which insurance claims are justified and which are not. This leads to cost savings and
contributes to simplicity and speed of reimbursement. When the customer submits an invoice,
AI determines what type of document is involved and assigns the invoice to a service. In the
next step, the system checks whether the damage or medical service is covered by the
contract. This works fully automatically through AI and digital added value. Our customers
benefit from a particularly fast reimbursement of their costs. We guarantee our clients claims
settlement within 48 hours of receipt of all relevant documents. Since there is a high
probability of fraud in property insurance segment, the claim history in this segment is checked
manually by a claim handler. In future, most of our insurance products could be processed
automatically.

The processes and services mentioned above are not yet available for all products and services.
However, we have developed a platform that allows us to further expand the above processes
and complement the insurance tariffs.
Our 16 matrix

With the development of our 16 matrix for our supplementary insurance products, we have
laid the foundation for the digitalization of our insurance products. Our goal is to enable our
customers to take out insurance quickly and easily online. This is why we have simplified our
insurance products and grouped them into four product families.
The following table shows the 16 matrix for our health and long-term care insurance products
at a glance:

The core idea of the 16 matrix is to offer our supplementary insurance products sorted by
insurance families (e.g., supplementary dental insurance), whereby the customer can choose
one of four alternatives with different insurance cover. The customer can choose between the
categories ”basic”, “comfort”, “premium” and “exclusive” for each insurance family to
determine the scope of his insurance cover. Because we want to serve the mass market, we
offer insurance products and price levels to suit all customer groups. In our supplementary
dental insurance “DFV-Zahnschutz”, the customer can choose between a reimbursement scope
of 50%, 70%, 90% and 100% on all dental treatment. This means that in the “exclusive”
category, all measures taken by the dentist would be reimbursed.

The use of the 16 matrix benefits us in two ways: From the customer’s point of view, the use of
the Matrix increases the overall understanding of the insurance products offered. From the
Company’s point of view, the 16 matrix system also significantly simplifies the process, as only
one condition record and one product information sheet are required for each product family
and only one customer information sheet for all product families. The matrix system also has
the advantage that it is scalable: The reimbursement scope can be adjusted and/or product
families can be extended without changing the matrix system. The expansion of the product
families will therefore only lead to a slight increase in process complexity, as we have already
demonstrated with the successful introduction of the 16 matrix for our property insurance
products.
Our Market Opportunity
The online penetration in the insurance industry is still relatively low, with only 16.9% of

accident insurance policies sold through direct sales (Direktvertrieb) in 2016, of which only a
portion was agreed online. Nevertheless, this is a growing trend as customers increasingly use
messenger apps in insurance matters (Source: GDV, Analysis 2018, p. 17 et seqq.).

We believe that this represents a material catch-up potential driven by the general trend
towards the use of online media for the acquisition of new products. Favorable demographic
developments will further accelerate the migration from offline to online in the insurance
industry, driven by the so-called millennials with high affinity to internet in general and e-
commerce in particular, which are beginning to spend their rising revenues on online
purchases. We believe that the insurance industry is particularly attractive for an online offer.
Since insurance policies can be easily simplified and standardized for the majority of potential
customers, they are well suited for this sales channel.

We believe that, compared to our competitors, we offer a wide range of insurance at very
competitive premiums that are easy for our customers to understand and specifically tailored
to the new digitalized distribution channels.
Key Strengths
We believe the development of our business is supported by the following strengths:

•   We are the first insurer in Germany to use a fully digitalized platform.

•   Our digital insurance products are awarded regularly by Stiftung Warentest.

•   We follow an uncompromisingly digital approach.
•   We have a lean, profitable and scalable business model.
Our Strategy
The key elements of our strategy are:
We strive to fully digitalize our business.
We want to expand our product portfolio.
We aim to establish holistic insurance solutions.
We want to grow our business internationally.

As of the date of this Prospectus, SK Beteiligungen GmbH, the Community of Heirs
(Erbengemeinschaft) Vogel and Luca Pesarini (directly and indirectly through ETHENEA
Independent Investors S.A.) (the “Major Shareholders”) each hold more than 30% of the
voting rights in the Company and are, therefore, considered to hold a controlling interest in
the Company pursuant to the German Securities Acquisition and Takeover Act
(Wertpapiererwerbs- und Übernahmegesetz – “WpÜG”).
Direct or indirect control
over the issuer and nature
of such control.

Following the completion of the Offering, the SK Beteiligungen GmbH, the Community of Heirs
(Erbengemeinschaft) Vogel and Luca Pesarini (directly and indirectly through ETHENEA
Independent Investors S.A.) will hold at least 22.63%, 22.39% and 25.58%, respectively, of the
Company’s shares (assuming placement of all New Shares and no exercise of the Greenshoe
Option). As a result, none of the Major Shareholders will continue to hold more than 30% of
the voting rights in the Company and, thus, will continue to hold a controlling interest in the
Company pursuant to the WpÜG.

Financial information presented in parentheses denotes the negative of such number
presented. In respect of financial information set out in this Prospectus, a dash (“-“) signifies
that the relevant figures is not available, while a zero (“0.0”) signifies that the relevant figure is
available but has been rounded to zero.

Our historical results are not necessarily indicative of our future results, and our interim result
as of and for the six months ended June 30, 2018 are not necessarily indicative of the results
that should be expected for the full fiscal year ending December 31, 2018 or any other period.

Additional Key Performance Indicators

We have included the following non-IFRS financial measures as additional key performance indicators (“Additional KPIs”). We
believe that the Additional KPIs are meaningful supplemental information for measuring the operating and financial performance of
the Group’s business for the Company’s management and investors. We believe that the Additional KPIs are useful in evaluating the
Group’s financial performance, because a number of companies, in particular companies in the insurance or InsurTech business, also
publish these figures as key performance indicators. However, the Additional KPIs are not recognized as line items under IFRS and
should not be considered as substitutes for figures on net assets, result before taxes, net earnings, cash flow from operating
activities or other income statement, cash flow or balance sheet data, as determined in accordance with IFRS, or as indicators of
profitability or liquidity. The Additional KPIs do not necessarily indicate whether cash flow will be sufficient or available for the
Group’s cash requirements, nor whether any such measure is indicative of the Group’s historical operating results. They are also not
meant to be indicative of future results. Because not all companies calculate these Additional KPIs in the same way, our presentation
of the Additional KPIs is not necessarily comparable with similarly-titled measures used by other companies.

Our cash flow from operating activities increased from a cash inflow of €14.8 million in 2016 by
€1.8 million (or 12.2%) to a cash inflow of €16.6 million in 2017. This increase is attributable to
the continued growth of our core business, i.e. our private supplementary health and long-
term care insurance segment. Premiums in supplementary health insurance rose by 20.5% and
contributed to the strong operating cash flow due to the long-term nature of this business. In
addition, premium income from long-term care insurance rose by 12.0% in 2017, which led to
a continuous increase in underwriting provisions and thus to a strong operating cash flow.
Six Months Ended June 30, 2017 and June 30, 2018

Our gross written premium decreased from €35.9 million in the six months ended June 30,
2017 by €5.7 million (or 15.9%) to €30.2 million in the six months ended June 30, 2018. This
decrease was mainly due to a decline in premiums in household insurance following our
decision to terminate a coinsurance contract with RheinLand Versicherungen. In addition,
premium income from our discontinued electronics insurance declined as expected.
Nonetheless, our core business, i.e. our private supplementary health and long-term care
insurance segment remained unaffected by this development. In the six months ended
June 30, 2018, we reported in the private supplementary health and long-term care insurance
segment a premium growth of approximately 14% compared to the six months ended June 30,
2017. In particular, this applies to our dental supplementary insurance
(Zahnzusatzversicherung). Adjusted for the aforementioned declines in our household and
electronics insurance, the gross written premium in our other business areas grew by around
5.5% compared to the previous-year period.

Total assets increased from €94.3 million as of December 31, 2017 by €14.1 million (or 14.9%)
to €108.4 million as of June 30, 2018. This increase was attributable to the continued strong
growth of our business resulting in an increase of our total investments from €46.4 million by
€8.7 million (or 18.8%) to €55.1 million. In addition, our receivables increased from €1.9 million
by €1.9 million (or 98.5%) to €3.8 million due to the higher receivables from reinsurers.

In the six months ended June 30, 2018, our cash flow from operating activities increased from
a cash inflow of €7.9 million in the six months ended June 30, 2017 by €1.4 million (or 17.8%)
to a cash inflow of €9.3 million. This is primarily attributable to the continued growth of our
core business, i.e. our private supplementary health and long-term care insurance segment.
Premiums in supplementary health insurance rose significantly and contributed to the strong
operating cash flow due to the long-term nature of this business. In addition, premium income
from long-term care insurance continued to grow steadily, leading to a continuous increase in
underwriting provisions and thus to a strong operating cash flow.
Recent Developments

As of August 23, 2018, two former subsidiaries of the Company, Stiftung PflegeZukunft
gestalten GmbH and MeinPlus Servicegesellschaft mbH, were merged into DFVV Deutsche
Familienversicherung-Vertriebsgesellschaft mbH, another wholly-owned subsidiary of the
Company. The merger with Stiftung PflegeZukunft gestalten GmbH was registered on
August 31, 2018, and the merger with MeinPlus Servicegesellschaft mbH was registered on
September 3, 2018 with the Commercial Register.

On June 28, 2018, the Company entered into a share purchase and transfer agreement with
bbg Betriebsberatungs GmbH, Bayreuth, Germany (“bbg”). Based on this share purchase and
transfer agreement, bbg as seller sold and transferred to the Company as buyer 467,948 shares
in BCA AG, Oberursel, Germany (“BCA”), one of the large broker pools in Germany. These
shares in BCA correspond to a 10% stake in the share capital of BCA minus one share. Antitrust
clearance to the concentration between these undertakings has been granted by decision of
the Federal Cartel Office (Bundeskartellamt) dated October 8, 2018.

Except for the developments mentioned above, no significant change in the Group’s financial
or trading position has occurred since June 30, 2018.

We currently intend to retain all available funds and any future earnings to support operations
and to finance the growth and development of our business. Therefore, we currently do not
intend to pay dividends in the foreseeable future. Any future decision to pay dividends will be
made in accordance with applicable laws and will depend upon, inter alia, our results of
operations, financial condition, contractual restrictions and capital requirements. Our ability to
pay dividends may also be limited by the terms of our financial liabilities or preference shares
that might be issued in the future.
Dividend policy.
D–
Risks

An investment in the Company’s Shares is subject to risks. In addition to the other information
contained in this Prospectus, investors should carefully consider the following risks when
deciding whether to invest in the Company’s shares. The market price of the Company’s shares
could decline if any of these risks were to materialize, in which case investors could lose some
or all of their investment.

The following risks, alone or together with additional risks and uncertainties not currently
known to the Company, or that the Company might currently deem immaterial, could have a
material adverse effect on our business, financial conditions, cash flows, results of operations
and prospects. The order in which the risks are presented is not an indication of the likelihood
of the risks actually materializing, or the significance or degree of the risks or the scope of any
potential harm to our business, financial condition, cash flows, results of operations and
prospects. The risks mentioned herein may materialize individually or cumulatively.

Risks Related to the Company’s Business, Operations and Financial Position

       •      Our business is largely dependent on economic conditions, and the economic
              outlook remains uncertain.

       •      We are subject to substantial general market risks that could have a material
              adverse effect on the value of our investment portfolio and financial position
              and could, in an extreme case, leave us with insufficient funds to pay our insur-
              ance liabilities.

       •      Higher inflation could lead to higher costs for claims settlements and lower
              earnings.

       •      Deterioration in market conditions for insurance could reduce our revenues
              and limit our growth.

       •      We are exposed to an underwriting risk consisting of a premium risk and a
              claims risk.

       •      Our reserves set aside to pay insurance claims could prove insufficient, which
              could necessitate additional reserves.

       •      We bear significant credit risks as a result of our business activities.
       •      Actuarial appraisals of insured risks, which are used to estimate the amount of
              potential claims under insurance policies, could prove to be incorrect.

       •      Reinsurance for our insurance business might prove insufficient, or might not
              be available in the required scope or only on less favorable terms in the future.

       •      We rely to a certain extent on insurance intermediaries to distribute our insur-
              ance products. Disruptions to this distribution network could materially reduce
              the volume of new policies.

       •      We could lose important cooperation partners and therefore important cus-
              tomers.

       •      Our risk management systems could fail to identify or control for material risks.

       •      Previously unknown risks, so-called “emerging risks”, which cannot be reliably

                              12
Key risks specific to the
issuer and its industry.

assessed, could lead to unforeseeable damages.

       •      The growth and success of our business depends on the continued growth of
              the online market, the corresponding shift from offline to online and mobile
              devices as well customers’ acceptance of online platforms.

       •      We face intense competition from traditional insurer as well as other online in-
              surer, which may intensify even further.

       •      Any failure to maintain, protect and enhance our reputation and brands may
              adversely affect our business.

       •      Our significant investments in marketing may fail to yield the desired results.

       •      If our websites and apps do not achieve a high ranking in organic search results,
              this could reduce traffic to our websites and apps.

       •      We may be subject to negative publicity, including inaccurate adverse infor-
              mation.

       •      Our payment systems could fail to function properly.

       •      Dissatisfaction with our customer service could prevent us from retaining our
              customers.

       •      We may experience significant termination cases.

       •      We may fail to operate, maintain, integrate and upgrade our IT-infrastructure,
              or to adopt and apply technological advances.

       •      We depend on the reliable functioning of our own and third-party IT systems,
              and a major failure in these systems could disrupt our business.

       •      We may experience malfunctions or disruptions of our IT-systems.

       •      We may experience security breaches and disruptions due to hacking, viruses,
              fraud and malicious attacks.

       •      We depend on our personnel to grow and operate our business and may not be
              able to retain and replace existing personnel or to attract new personnel.

       •      We may not be able to adapt our accounting, our internal controls as well as
              our reporting and risk management procedures to our rapid growth and the
              requirements of being a public company.

Risks Related to Regulatory, Legal and Tax Matters

Related to Regulatory, Legal and Tax Matters

 •       We are subject to legal uncertainties, resulting inter alia from the implementa-
         tion of Solvency II and further changes in the existing regulatory requirements.

 •       Valuation could be adversely affected by a change of accounting standards.

 •       Other developments in European and German legislation may adversely affect
         our business.

 •       We might be subject to stress tests and similar regulatory analyses, which
         might adversely affect our reputation and our business in general.

 •       We may lose or fail to obtain required approvals, licenses and permits.

 •       If we are unable to meet statutory requirements in connection with the distri-
         bution of insurance contracts, this might trigger regulatory measures or dis-
         putes with intermediaries or customers.

 •       Failure to comply with applicable laws, standards of conduct or accounting
         rules or other irregularities at ours or other companies in the insurance and fi-
         nancial service industry may adversely affect our business.

 •       We may be adversely affected by changes in the regulations applicable to the
         use of the Internet and the online sector.

 •       We may be involved in litigation or other proceedings that could adversely af-
fect our business.

•   Our business is subject to the general tax environment in the jurisdictions in
    which we operate and any changes to this tax environment may increase our
    tax burden.
D.3   Key risks specific to the   Risk Related to the Company’s Shareholder Structure, its Shares and the Offering
securities.

•   There is no existing market for the Company’s shares and an active or liquid
    market might not develop.

•   The Company’s share price could fluctuate significantly, and investors could
    lose part or all of their investment in the Company’s shares.

•   Following the Offering, some of the Existing Shareholders will retain a signifi-
    cant interest in the Company and their interests may conflict with those of the
    Company and its other shareholders.

•   The Company does not expect to pay any dividends in the foreseeable future.

•   The Company may fail to comply with the additional regulatory requirements,
    which will be applicable to the Company following the listing of the Company’s
    shares.

•   Future offerings of debt or equity securities by the Company could adversely af-
    fect the market price of the Company’s shares, and future issuances of shares
    could lead to a substantial dilution of the Company’s shareholders (i.e., a re-
    duction in the value of existing shareholders’ interests in the Company).

•   Future sales of shares or anticipated sales of a substantial number of shares in
    the Company or similar transactions conducted by the Major Shareholders or
    other groups of shareholders could adversely affect the share price.

E–    Offer

E.1     Total net proceeds.
The Company will only receive the proceeds of the Offering resulting from the sale of the New
Shares.

At the mid-point of the price range for the Offering within which purchase orders may be
placed of €17.00 to €23.00 per Offer Share (the “Price Range”) and assuming full exercise of
the Preferential Allocation (as defined in E.3), the Company will issue 3,500,000 New Shares
and receive gross proceeds from the Offering in an amount of approximately €69.4 million.

After deduction of the costs of the Company relating to the Offering (based on the foregoing
assumptions), the Company estimates that the total net proceeds from the placement of the
New Shares assuming full exercise of the Preferential Allocation (as defined in E.3), would
amount to approximately €65.0 million.

The costs of the Company related to the Offering of the Offer Shares and the listing of the
Company’s entire share capital, including underwriting and placement commissions payable to
the Joint Bookrunners, are expected to total approximately €4.4 million (assuming placement

The Company currently intends to use the total net proceeds from the Offering of
approximately €65.0 million (assuming placement of all New Shares at the mid-point of the
Price Range, full exercise of the Preferential Allocation (as defined in E.3) and payment of the
discretionary fee in full) in the following order:
Use of proceeds.

•   approximately €46.4 million to fund additional spending for sales and market-
    ing purposes, in particular by increasing advertising budgets for Google, Bing,
    as well as state of the art TV channels and by financing offline campaigns with
    leading German magazines;

•   approximately €9.4 million to introduce new insurance products and bundles
    (such as the reinvention of our property and accident insurance products on
    the basis of our 16 matrix) as well as to internationalize our business, starting
    in Benelux, France and/or Spain;

•   approximately €4.6 million for investing in our IT infrastructure, in particular
    by adding functionality to our core insurance platform, and refining our AI in-
    telligence processes; and

•   approximately €4.6 million for safeguarding and matching Solvency II levels.

Price Range.              The Price Range for the Offering within purchase orders may be placed is €17.00 to €23.00 per
Offer Share.

The period during which investors may submit purchase orders for the Offer Shares is expected
to begin on October 30, 2018 and to expire on November 9, 2018 (the “Offer Period”).
Offer Period

The Offer Price and the final number of Offer Shares placed in the Offering will be determined
at the end of the bookbuilding process by the Company after consultation with the Joint
Bookrunner and are expected to be published on or about November 9, 2018. Should the
placement volume prove insufficient to satisfy all orders placed at the offer price, the Joint
Bookrunner reserve the right to reject orders, or to only accept them in part.
Offer Price.

Delivery of the Offer Shares against payment of the Offer Price is expected to take place on
November 15, 2018. The Offer Shares will be made available to investors as co-ownership
interests in the global share certificates.
Delivery and Settlement

As part of the Offering, the Company has set up a preferential allocation program (the
“Preferential Allocation”) for the benefit of employees of the Group, employed and tax
resident in Germany, as well as certain members of the Management Board in the total
amount of up to 35,000 New Shares at the issue price of €2.00 per New Share. In the event
that the New Shares are not fully placed, the number of New Shares allotted under the
Preferential Allocation will be adjusted accordingly. All New Shares granted pursuant to the
Preferential Allocation will be subject to a lock-up period of 24 months beginning on the first
day of trading of the Company’s shares.
Preferential Allocation

In connection with the placement of the Offer Shares, Hauck & Aufhäuser, acting for the
account of the Joint Bookrunners, will act as the stabilization manager (the “Stabilization
Manager”) and may, as Stabilization Manager, make over-allotments and take stabilization
measures in accordance with Article 5 paras. 4 and 5 of the Regulation (EU) No. 596/2014 of
the European Parliament and of the Council of April 16, 2014 on market abuse, as amended, in
conjunction with Articles 5 through 8 of Commission Delegated Regulation (EU) 2016/1052 of
March 8, 2016 to provide support for the market price of the Company’s shares, thus
alleviating selling pressure generated by short-term investors and maintaining an orderly
market in the Company’s shares.

Stabilization Measures,
Over-Allotments and
Greenshoe Option

In connection with these stabilization measures, investors may, in addition to the New Shares,
be allocated up to 525,000 Over-Allotment Shares as part of the allocation of the Offer Shares
(the “Over-Allotment”). For the purpose of such potential Over-Allotments, the Stabilization
Manager, acting for the account of the Joint Bookrunners, will be provided with a
corresponding number of Over-Allotment Shares from the holdings of the Lending Shareholder
in the form of a securities loan. The total number of Over-Allotment Shares will not exceed
15.0% of the New Shares actually placed with investors. In connection with potential Over-
Allotments, the Lending Shareholder has granted the Joint Bookrunners an option to acquire
up to 525,000 existing shares of the Company (such shares, “Greenshoe Shares”) at the Offer
Price, less the agreed commissions, for the sole purpose of enabling the Stabilization Manager
to perform its redelivery obligation under the securities loan from the Lending Shareholder
(the “Greenshoe Option”). The Greenshoe Option may only be exercised during the
stabilization period and will terminate 30 calendar days after the commencement of stock
exchange trading of the Company’s shares (i.e., December 13, 2018).

The Stabilization Manager, acting for the account of the Joint Bookrunners, is entitled to
exercise the Greenshoe Option to the extent Over-Allotment Shares were allocated to
investors in the Offering. The number of Over-Allotment Shares acquired under the Greenshoe
Option is to be reduced by any shares of the Company held by the Stabilization Manager on
the date when the Greenshoe Option is exercised, if such shares were acquired by the
Stabilization Manager in the context of stabilization measures.

Joint Bookrunners have formed contractual relationships with the Company and the Lending

business.

ZUSAMMENFASSUNG DES PROSPEKTS

Zusammenfassungen bestehen aus geforderten Angaben, die als Punkte („Punkte”) bezeichnet werden. Diese Punkte sind
in den Abschnitten A – E (A.1 – E.7) fortlaufend nummeriert. Diese Zusammenfassung enthält alle Punkte, die für die vorliegende Art
von Wertpapier und Emittentin in eine Zusammenfassung aufzunehmen sind. Da einige Punkte nicht behandelt werden müssen,
können in der Nummerierungsreihenfolge Lücken auftreten. Selbst wenn ein Punkt wegen der Art des Wertpapiers und der Emittentin
in die Zusammenfassung aufgenommen werden muss, ist es möglich, dass in Bezug auf diesen Punkt keine relevanten Informationen
gegeben werden können. In solchen Fällen enthält die Zusammenfassung eine kurze Beschreibung des Punkts mit dem Hinweis
„Entfällt”.

A–    Einleitung und Warnhinweise

A.1   Warnhinweise

Diese Zusammenfassung sollte als Einführung zu diesem Prospekt (der „Prospekt“) verstanden
werden.

Der Anleger sollte jede Entscheidung zur Anlage in die betreffenden Wertpapiere auf die
Prüfung des gesamten Prospekts stützen.

Für den Fall, dass vor einem Gericht Ansprüche aufgrund der in diesem Prospekt enthaltenen
Informationen geltend gemacht werden, könnte der als Kläger auftretende Anleger in
Anwendung der einzelstaatlichen Rechtsvorschriften der Mitgliedstaaten des Europäischen

Faktoren.

Wir verstehen uns als erster Versicherer in Deutschland mit einer einzigartigen, voll
digitalisierten Plattform. Wir haben unsere Tätigkeit im Jahr 2007 aufgenommen. Innerhalb
von elf Jahren haben wir uns von einem analogen Versicherungsunternehmen zu einem
profitablen InsurTech-Unternehmen mit rund 420.000 bestehenden Verträgen (Stand: 30. Juni
2018) sowie Bruttobeiträgen von rund €71 Mio. und einem Jahresüberschuss von rund
€1,5 Mio. im Jahr 2017 entwickelt.

Wir betrachten die Entwicklung innovativer, digitaler Lösungen für die Zahn-, Kranken- und
Pflegezusatzversicherung als eine unserer Kernkompetenzen. Unsere Produkte werden von
Stiftung Warentest, eine führende deutsche Verbraucherorganisation, kontinuierlich mit
Bestnoten ausgezeichnet (Quelle: Finanztest, Ausgaben 08/2014, 11/2016, 05/2018). Unsere
wachsende Kundenbasis und die Anerkennung unserer Produkte durch Stiftung Warentest
zeigen unsere Wettbewerbsfähigkeit auf dem bereits weitestgehend aufgeteilten
Versicherungsmarkt. Trotz unserer Investitionen in unsere Digitalisierungsprozesse erzielen
wir seit Jahren positive operative Ergebnisse bei steigendem Geschäftsvolumen. Mit einer
Solvabilitätsquote, d.h. einem Verhältnis des verfügbaren Kapitals (Eigenmittel) zum
Solvabilitätskapitalbedarf (SCR), von rund 214 % im Jahr 2017 profitieren wir zudem von einer
guten Eigenkapitalausstattung im Vergleich zu unseren Wettbewerbern und gemessen an den
regulatorischen Anforderungen.
Wir sind in den folgenden Segmenten und Geschäftsfeldern tätig:

Private Kranken- und Pflegezusatzversicherung. Mit unserer privaten Kran-
ken- und Pflegezusatzversicherung bieten wir unseren Kunden Versicherungs-
schutz gegen Vermögensschäden bei Krankheit und Pflegebedürftigkeit. Die
private Kranken- und Pflegezusatzversicherung deckt Leistungen für den Versi-
cherungsnehmer, die nicht durch die gesetzliche und private Kranken- und
Pflegeversicherung abgedeckt sind. Im Jahr 2017 entfielen auf das Segment
„private Kranken- und Pflegezusatzversicherung“ €53,5 Mio. (oder rund 76 %)
unserer Bruttoprämien und ein Jahresüberschuss von rund €1,1 Mio.

Sach- und Unfallversicherung. Dieses Segment umfasst unsere Zusatzversiche-
rungsprodukte wie Unfallversicherung, Haftpflichtversicherung, Rechtsschutz-
versicherung, Hausratversicherung, Tierversicherung und Elektronikversiche-
rung (in Abwicklung). Unsere Sachversicherung schützt die Versicherungsneh-
mer vor finanziellen Schäden, die durch den Eintritt definierter Risiken entste-
hen. Durch eine Haftpflichtversicherung bietet die Gesellschaft Schutz vor
Schadenersatzansprüchen von geschädigten Dritten. Die Unfallversicherung
deckt Personenschäden infolge von Unfallereignissen. Im Jahr 2017 entfielen
auf das Segment „Sach- und Unfallversicherung“ €17,1 Mio. (oder rund 24 %)
unserer Bruttoprämien und ein Jahresüberschuss von rund €0,4 Mio.

Darüber hinaus ist die Gesellschaft als Rückversicherer in den gleichen Bereichen zugelassen,
für die sie eine Lizenz als Erstversicherer besitzt. Seit 2017 hat die Gesellschaft das
Rückversicherungsgeschäft jedoch nicht betrieben.
Unser digitaler Ansatz

Wir wollen vernünftige und exzellente Produkte anbieten, die gleichzeitig leicht verständlich
sind, und diesen Ansatz mit einem einfachen Vertragsprozess zu verbinden. Aus der Übersicht
unserer Produkte erkennt der Kunde auf einen Blick die wesentlichen Vorteile und Prämien
eines jeden Versicherungsproduktes. Als Massenmarktteilnehmer bieten wir
Versicherungsprodukte und Preisniveaus an, die für die Mehrheit der potenziellen Kunden
geeignet sind.

Unser Ziel ist es, unseren Kunden ein einfaches und papierloses Dokumentenmanagement
anzubieten. Im digitalen DFV-Kundenportal finden unsere Kunden alles auf einen Blick und
ohne Papier. Sie können ihre Vertragsunterlagen einsehen und herunterladen. Hat ein Kunde
mehr als einen Vertrag abgeschlossen, befinden sich alle Verträge auf dem DFV-Kundenportal.
Das    Verwaltungszentrum      des    DFV-Kundenportals        eröffnet   die  Möglichkeit,
Versicherungsverträge anzupassen, z.B. bei einer notwendigen Adress- oder

Zahlungsänderung. Darüber hinaus haben unsere Kunden Zugang zu unserem Service-Center.
Schließlich können sie die DFV-Schnellregulierung nutzen.

Alle Funktionen bieten wir auch über unsere DFV-Versicherungs- App an. Die DFV-
Versicherungs-App ist die mobile Version des DFV-Kundenportals. Darüber hinaus können
Kunden unserer Unfallversicherung ihren Versicherungsschutz täglich flexibel anpassen. Mit
unserer Unfallversicherung können Kunden ihre Familie, Freunde und Bekannte je nach
Situation versichern.

Wir streben eine schnelle und unkomplizierte Schadenregulierung an. Bei der
Schadenregulierung in der Krankenzusatzversicherung setzen wir auf den Einsatz künstlicher
Intelligenz („KI“). KI hilft uns zu entscheiden, welche Versicherungsansprüche berechtigt sind
und welche nicht. Dies führt zu Kosteneinsparungen und trägt zur Einfachheit und
Schnelligkeit der Erstattung bei. Wenn der Kunde eine Rechnung einreicht, bestimmt die KI,
um welche Art von Dokument es sich handelt und ordnet die Rechnung einer Leistung zu. Im
nächsten Schritt prüft das System, ob der Schaden oder die medizinische Dienstleistung durch
den Vertrag abgedeckt ist. Dies funktioniert vollautomatisch durch KI und digitalen Mehrwert.
Unsere Kunden profitieren von einer besonders schnellen Erstattung ihrer Kosten. Wir
garantieren unseren Kunden eine Schadenregulierung innerhalb von 48 Stunden nach Erhalt
aller relevanten Dokumente. Da eine hohe Betrugswahrscheinlichkeit im Segment der
Sachversicherung besteht, wird in diesem Segment die Anspruchshistorie von einem
Sachbearbeiter manuell geprüft. In Zukunft könnten die meisten unserer
Versicherungsprodukte automatisch verarbeitet werden.

Die oben genannten Verfahren und Services stehen noch nicht für alle Produkte und
Leistungsarten zur Verfügung. Wir haben jedoch eine Plattform entwickelt, die es uns
ermöglicht die oben genannten Verfahren weiter auszubauen und die Versicherungstarife zu
ergänzen.
Unsere 16er-Matrix

Mit der Entwicklung unserer 16er-Matrix für unsere Zusatzversicherungsprodukte haben wir
den Grundstein für die Digitalisierung unserer Versicherungsprodukte gelegt. Unser Ziel ist es,
unseren Kunden den Abschluss einer Versicherung schnell und einfach online zu ermöglichen.
Deshalb haben wir unsere Versicherungsprodukte vereinfacht und in vier Produktfamilien

zusammengefasst.

Die folgende Tabelle zeigt die 16er-Matrix              für   unsere    Kranken-    und
Pflegeversicherungsprodukte auf einen Blick:




Grundgedanke der 16er-Matrix ist es, unsere Zusatzversicherungsprodukte nach
Versicherungsfamilien sortiert anzubieten (z.B. Zahnzusatzversicherung), wobei der Kunde
zwischen vier Varianten mit unterschiedlichem Versicherungsschutz wählen kann. Der Kunde
kann für jede Versicherungsfamilie zwischen den Kategorien „Basis“, „Komfort“, „Premium“
und „Exklusiv“ wählen, um den Umfang seines Versicherungsschutzes zu bestimmen. Weil wir
den Massenmarkt bedienen wollen, bieten wir Versicherungsprodukte und Preisniveaus für
alle Kundengruppen an. In unserer Zusatzversicherung „DFV-Zahnschutz“ kann der Kunde
zwischen einem Erstattungsumfang von 50 %, 70 %, 90 % und 100 % wählen. Dies bedeutet,
dass in der Kategorie „Exklusiv“ alle Maßnahmen des Zahnarztes erstattet würden.

Der Einsatz der 16er-Matrix kommt uns in zweierlei Hinsicht zugute: Aus Kundensicht erhöht
der Einsatz der 16er-Matrix das Gesamtverständnis der angebotenen Versicherungsprodukte.
Aus Sicht des Unternehmens vereinfacht das 16er-Matrix-System auch den Prozess erheblich,
da nur ein Konditionssatz und ein Produktinformationsblatt pro Produktfamilie und nur ein
Kundeninformationsblatt für alle Produktfamilien benötigt werden. Das Matrixsystem hat
zudem den Vorteil, dass es skalierbar ist: Der Erstattungsumfang kann angepasst und/oder
Produktfamilien erweitert werden, ohne das Matrixsystem zu verändern. Die Erweiterung der
Produktfamilien wird daher nur zu einer leichten Erhöhung der Prozesskomplexität führen,
wie wir bereits mit der erfolgreichen Einführung der 16er-Matrix für unsere
Sachversicherungsprodukte gezeigt haben.
Unsere Marktchancen

Die Online-Durchdringung in der Versicherungswirtschaft ist mit nur 16,9 % der im
Direktvertrieb verkauften Unfallversicherungen im Jahr 2016, von denen nur ein Teil online
vereinbart wurde, noch relativ gering. Dennoch ist dies ein wachsender Trend, da Kunden
zunehmend Messenger-Apps und soziale Netzwerke in Versicherungsfragen nutzen
(Quelle: Gesamtverband der deutschen Versicherungswirtschaft, “Anbieterlandschaft am
Versicherungsmarkt: Ein Ausblick, Stand 2018”, Seite 17 ff.).

Wir sehen hierin ein erhebliches Nachholpotenzial, das durch den allgemeinen Trend zur
Nutzung von Online-Medien für die Akquisition neuer Produkte getrieben wird. Günstige
demografische Entwicklungen werden die Migration von Offline zu Online in der
Versicherungswirtschaft weiter beschleunigen, getrieben durch die so genannten „Millennials“
(zu Deutsch: Jahrtausender) mit hoher Affinität zum Internet im Allgemeinen und zum E-
Commerce im Besonderen, die beginnen, ihre steigenden Einkünfte für Online-Käufe
auszugeben. Wir glauben, dass die Versicherungswirtschaft für ein Online-Angebot besonders
attraktiv ist. Da sich Versicherungspolicen für die Mehrzahl der potenziellen Kunden leicht
vereinfachen und standardisieren lassen, sind sie für diesen Vertriebskanal gut geeignet.

Wir glauben, dass wir im Vergleich zu unseren Wettbewerbern eine breite Palette von
Versicherungen zu sehr wettbewerbsfähigen Prämien anbieten, die für unsere Kunden leicht
verständlich und speziell auf die neuen digitalisierten Vertriebskanäle zugeschnitten sind.
Unsere Stärken
Wir glauben, dass die Entwicklung unseres Geschäfts durch folgende Stärken unterstützt wird:

•   Wir sind der erste Versicherer in Deutschland, der eine vollständig digitalisierte
    Plattform nutzt.

•   Unsere digitalen Versicherungsprodukte werden regelmäßig von der Stiftung
    Warentest ausgezeichnet.

•   Wir verfolgen einen kompromisslos digitalen Ansatz.

•   Wir haben ein schlankes, profitables und skalierbares Geschäftsmodell.
Unsere Strategie
Die Schlüsselelemente unserer Strategie sind:

•   Wir streben eine vollständige Digitalisierung unseres Geschäfts an.

•   Wir wollen unser Produktportfolio erweitern.

•   Unser Ziel ist es, ganzheitliche Versicherungslösungen zu etablieren.

•   Wir wollen unser Geschäft international ausbauen.

Zusätzliche Leistungsindikatoren

Als zusätzliche Wichtige Leistungsindikatoren (“Zusätzliche Leistungsindikatoren”) haben wir die folgenden Nicht-IFRS-
Finanzkennzahlen aufgenommen. Wir glauben, dass die Zusätzliche Leistungsindikatoren aussagekräftige Zusatzinformationen zur
Bemessung der operativen und finanziellen Performance der Gruppe für dessen Management und die Investoren des Unternehmens
darstellen. Wir glauben, dass die Zusätzliche Leistungsindikatoren für die Beurteilung der wirtschaftlichen Leistungsfähigkeit der
Gruppe nützlich sind, da eine Reihe von Unternehmen, insbesondere Unternehmen aus dem Versicherungs- oder InsurTech-
Geschäft, diese Zahlen ebenfalls als Zusätzliche Leistungsindikatoren veröffentlichen. Die Zusätzliche Leistungsindikatoren werden
jedoch nach IFRS nicht als Einzelposten ausgewiesen und sind nicht als Ersatz für die nach IFRS ermittelten Zahlen zu Nettovermögen,
Ergebnis vor Steuern, Jahresüberschuss, Cashflow aus laufender Geschäftstätigkeit oder sonstigen Gewinn- und Verlustrechnungen,
Cashflow- oder Bilanzdaten oder als Indikatoren für die Rentabilität oder Liquidität anzusehen. Die Zusätzliche Leistungsindikatoren
geben nicht notwendigerweise an, ob der Cashflow für den Liquiditätsbedarf der Gruppe ausreicht oder verfügbar ist oder ob eine
solche Kennzahl die historischen Betriebsergebnisse der Gruppe angibt. Sie sind auch nicht als Indikator für zukünftige Ergebnisse
gedacht. Da nicht alle Unternehmen diese Zusätzliche Leistungsindikatoren gleich berechnen, ist unsere Darstellung der Zusätzliche
Leistungsindikatoren nicht unbedingt mit ähnlich benannten Kennzahlen anderer Unternehmen vergleichbar.
Die folgende Tabelle zeigt eine Zusammenfassung der zusätzlichen Leistungsindikatoren für die dargestellten Zeiträume:

(1) Definiert als Verhältnis der versicherungstechnischen Netto-Aufwendungen (Schadenleistungsaufwendungen, sonstiges versicherungstechnisches Ergebnis) und dem Ergebnis aus Kapitalanla-
gen zu den verdienten Nettobeiträgen.
(2) Unser Ergebnis vor Zinsen und Steuern (EBIT) entspricht dem in der Konzern-Gesamtergebnisrechnung ausgewiesenen Ergebnis vor Steuern.
(3) Definiert als Verhältnis der Anzahl der bestehenden Versicherungsverträge zur durchschnittlichen Mitarbeiterzahl.
(4) Definiert als Verhältnis der gebuchten Bruttobeiträge zur durchschnittlichen Mitarbeiterzahl.

(5) Definiert als Anzahl der gesamten Werbe- und Abschlusskosten im Verhältnis zum Gesamtbetrag der Beiträge aus dem neu generierten Geschäft; das Verhältnis wird auf der Basis der monatli-
   chen Beitragszahlungen berechnet.

Hausratversicherung zurückzuführen, nachdem wir beschlossen hatten, einen
Mitversicherungsvertrag mit RheinLand Versicherungen zu kündigen. Darüber hinaus gingen
die Beitragseinnahmen aus unserer nicht fortgeführten Elektronikversicherung
erwartungsgemäß zurück. Dennoch blieb unser Kerngeschäft, d.h. unser privates
Krankenzusatz- und Pflegeversicherungssegment, von dieser Entwicklung unberührt. Im
Segment der privaten Krankenzusatz- und Pflegeversicherung verzeichneten wir in den sechs
Monaten bis zum 30. Juni 2018 ein Beitragswachstum von rund 14 % gegenüber dem ersten
Halbjahr 2017. Dies gilt insbesondere für unsere Zahnzusatzversicherung. Bereinigt um die
oben genannten Rückgänge in der Hausrat- und Elektronikversicherung wuchsen die
gebuchten Bruttobeiträge in unseren anderen Geschäftsfeldern gegenüber dem
Vorjahreszeitraum um rund 5,5 %.

Deutschland (“bbg”), einen Anteilskauf- und -übertragungsvertrag abgeschlossen. Aufgrund
dieses Aktienkauf- und Übertragungsvertrages hat die bbg als Verkäufer 467.948 Aktien der
BCA AG, Oberursel, Deutschland („BCA“), einem der großen Maklerpools in Deutschland,

des Zusammenschlusses zwischen diesen Unternehmen wurde mit Bescheid des
Bundeskartellamtes vom 8. Oktober 2018 erteilt.

Investitionen ganz oder teilweise verlieren.

Im Rahmen des Angebots hat die Gesellschaft ein Mitarbeiterprogramm zur bevorrechtigten
Zuteilung („Bevorrechtigte Zuteilung“) für in Deutschland beschäftigte und steuerlich ansäs-
sige Mitarbeiter der Gruppe sowie für bestimmte Mitglieder des Vorstands im Gesamtbetrag
von bis zu 35.000 Neuen Aktien, jeweils zum Ausgabepreis von €2,00 je Neuer Aktie, aufge-
legt. Für den Fall, dass die Neuen Aktien nicht vollständig platziert werden, wird die Anzahl
der Neuen Aktien, die im Rahmen der Bevorrechtigten Zuteilung zugeteilt werden, entspre-
chend angepasst. Alle neuen Aktien, die im Rahmen der Bevorrechtigten Zuteilung gewährt
werden, unterliegen einer Sperrfrist von 24 Monaten ab dem ersten Handelstag der Aktien
der Gesellschaft.

Stabilisierungsmaßnahme
n, Mehrzuteilung und
Greenshoe Option

Im Zusammenhang mit solchen Stabilisierungsmaßnahmen können Anlegern zusätzlich zu den
Neuen Aktien bis zu 525.000 Mehrzuteilungsaktien als Teil der Zuteilung der Angebotsaktien
zugeteilt werden (die „Mehrzuteilung“). Zu diesem Zweck wird der Stabilisierungsmanager,
für Rechnung der Joint Bookrunner, bis zu 525.000 Mehrzuteilungsaktien aus dem Bestand
der Verleihenden Aktionärin in Form eines Wertpapierdarlehens zur Verfügung gestellt. Die
Gesamtzahl der Mehrzuteilungsaktien wird dabei 15 % der tatsächlich bei Anlegern
platzierten Neuen Aktien nicht übersteigen. Im Zusammenhang mit potentiellen
Mehrzuteilungen hat die Verleihende Aktionärin den Joint Bookrunnern eine Option zum
Erwerb von bis zu 525.000 bestehenden Aktien der Gesellschaft (diese Aktien, die
„Greenshoe-Aktien“) zum Angebotspreis, abzüglich einer vereinbarten Provisionen,
eingeräumt (die „Greenshoe Option“). Diese hat den ausschließlichen Zweck, dem
Stabilisierungsmanager die Erfüllung seiner Rückgabeverpflichtung aus dem
Wertpapierdarlehen gegenüber der Verleihenden Aktionärin zu ermöglichen. Die Greenshoe
Option darf nur während des Stabilisierungszeitraums ausgeübt werden und endet 30
Kalendertage nach der Handelsaufnahme der Aktien der Gesellschaft(also am 13. Dezember
2018).

Der Stabilisierungsmanager, der für Rechnung der Joint Bookrunner handelt, ist berechtigt,
die Greenshoe Option in dem Umfang auszuüben, in dem Anlegern Mehrzuteilungsaktien im
Rahmen des Angebots zugeteilt wurden. Die Anzahl der Mehrzuteilungsaktien, die im Rahmen
der Greenshoe Option erworben werden, wird um die Anzahl der Aktien der Gesellschaft
reduziert, die am Tag der Ausübung der Greenshoe Option vom Stabilisierungsmanager
gehalten werden, sofern diese Aktien vom Stabilisierungsmanager im Rahmen von
Stabilisierungsmaßnahmen erworben wurden.

1.   RISK FACTORS

An investment in the shares of DFV Deutsche Familienversicherung AG (the “Company” and, together with its consolidated
subsidiaries, “we”, “us”, “our”, or the “Group”) is subject to risks. In addition to the other information contained in this prospectus
(the “Prospectus”), investors should carefully consider the following risks when deciding whether to invest in the Company’s shares.
The market price of the Company’s shares could decline if any of these risks were to materialize, in which case investors could lose
some or all of their investment.

The following risks, alone or together with additional risks and uncertainties not currently known to the Company, or that the
Company might currently deem immaterial, could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial conditions, cash flows, re-
sults of operations and prospects. The order in which the risks are presented is not an indication of the likelihood of the risks actually
materializing, or the significance or degree of the risks or the scope of any potential harm to our business, financial condition, cash
flows, results of operations and prospects. The risks mentioned herein may materialize individually or cumulatively.

results of operations and prospects. The risks mentioned herein may materialize individually or cumulatively.

 1.1.    Risks Related to the Company’s Business, Operations and Financial Position

 1.1.1   Our business is largely dependent on economic conditions, and the economic outlook remains uncert

risk_factor: Our business is largely dependent on economic conditions, and the economic outlook remains uncertain.

blobs.text:
Our business depends in many ways on economic conditions. In general, the global economy has remained volatile and could
be further negatively affected by many factors, including but not limited to rising national debt, investor concerns about the cohe-
sion of and disruptions within the Eurozone (for example a disorderly exit of one or more member states of the European Economic
Area (“EEA”) (each, an “EEA Member State”)), increased concerns over restrictions of global trade, inadequate liquidity, volatility in
the capital markets, lower consumer spending, higher inflation, political instability, terrorism or natural disasters.

Another global recession or recessions affecting significant parts of the global economy could reduce demand for our insur-
ance products. If a large number of consumers delay purchasing new insurance or terminate existing coverage, for example, due to
high unemployment or lower disposable income, demand for insurance coverage could decline. Weaker demand for insurance cov-
erage also tends to increase pressure on pricing and competition, adversely affecting profitability. In addition, uncertainty among
policyholders might lead to a significant higher cancellation rate than expected.

The occurrence of any of the risks set out above could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition,
cash flows, results of operations and prospects.

.1.2   We are subject to substantial general market risks that could have a material adverse effect on the value of our in-
       vestment portfolio and financial position and could, in an extreme case, leave us with insufficient funds to pay our
       insurance liabilities.

risk_factor: We are subject to substantial general market risks that could have a material adverse effect on the value of our in-vestment portfolio and financial position and could, in an extreme case, leave us with insufficient funds to pay ourinsurance liabilities.

blobs.text:
Our assets consist primarily of investments made using funds from premiums received under insurance contracts. Premiums
from insurance contracts are mainly allocated to our investment fund “DFV Sondervermögen”. Although we believe our investment
strategy in relation to investing collected premiums is adequately conservative and compliant with regulatory requirements, our in-
vestment portfolio is subject to substantial general market risks. This risk results primarily from the corporate bonds and the equity
investments contained in our investment fund “DFV Sondervermögen”. These equity investments mainly relate to shares listed on
regulated markets in the EEA Member States or in another member state of the Organization for Economic Co-operation and Devel-
opment (“OECD”).

The market value of fixed income securities is generally subject to changes in prevailing interest rates. Decreases in prevailing
interest rates generally lead to increases in the market value of fixed income securities, while increases in prevailing interest rates
lead to decreases in market value. Credit-spread risks are another important factor for our fixed income security holdings. Credit
spread refers to the difference in the rate of interest between a risk-bearing security and a risk-free security of the same quality (du-
ration/currency). Market changes in these risk premiums lead to changes in the market value of the corresponding securities in a
manner analogous to changes in prevailing interest rates. A decline in the prevailing interest rates can lead to lower income from in-
vestments. If interest rates continue to be low, technical insurance reserves may need to be increased because the actuarial calcula-
tion of certain reserves (for example benefit reserves under supplementary health insurance offered by type of life insurance) is
based on long-term interest rate forecasts.

Similarly, the market value of securities held by us generally tends to decline when equity markets in general lose value.
Losses in the value of investments can necessitate write-downs or lead to losses on the sale of investments, either of which would
adversely affect investment income. In an extreme case, such losses could affect our capability to settle our general insurance liabili-
ties or other liabilities. Furthermore, we are subject to currency exchange risks due to currency fluctuations, especially if there is a
currency mismatch between our investments and its liabilities.
The occurrence of any of the risks set out above could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition,
cash flows, results of operations and prospects.
1.1.3   Higher inflation could lead to higher costs for claims settlements and lower earnings.

risk_factor: Higher inflation could lead to higher costs for claims settlements and lower earnings.

blobs.text:
Monetary policies of the central banks in the Eurozone give rise to significant concern about inflation. There is a risk that the
European Central Bank could target higher inflation in the Eurozone to enable financially distressed EEA Member States to reduce
their sovereign debt burdens. Higher energy and raw material prices could also drive higher inflation, in addition to limiting economic
growth. If inflation increases, claims costs could increase. With regard to supplementary health insurance, premium adjustments un-
der running contracts are admissible in narrow lines. Besides agreed premiums generally can only be adjusted to inflation in the con-
text of contract renewals and cannot be adjusted under running contracts. Therefore, if we make incorrect assumptions about future
inflation, our premiums and reserves for payment of claims on existing policies could prove inadequate.

The occurrence of any of the risks set out above could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition,
cash flows, results of operations and prospects.
1.1.4   Deterioration in market conditions for insurance could reduce our revenues and limit our growth.

risk_factor: Deterioration in market conditions for insurance could reduce our revenues and limit our growth.

blobs.text:
The markets in which we operate are characterized by intense domestic and foreign competition by other insurance compa-
nies. Our ability to compete in these markets depends on several factors, such as the quality of our products and services, the effi-
ciency of our claims management, the ability to adapt to changing customer needs, the ability to respond quickly to changing market
conditions and customer demands, local presence and reputation as well as our financial strength. Changes in law, the social envi-
ronment or market conditions can influence demand for our existing products, and there is no guarantee that new products will be
met with sufficient customer demand or obtain all necessary regulatory approvals.

Overall, competition has increased in recent years in the online insurance markets, especially as a result of market entry by
new competitors, in particular legacy insurance companies, other InsurTech companies and so-called disruptors, i.e. market entrants
coming from other industries who start offering insurance policies. The growing use of the internet by consumers to research com-
peting insurance offers has also led to increased price transparency and increased price competition. In certain markets, consumers
focus on the price or the amount of premiums and do not attach value to other competitive factors, such as service, proximity to the
customer, quality of claims management, or scope of coverage. Therefore, insurance providers are finding it difficult to compete
against its competitors because many competitors often operate with lower distribution costs and can offer lower premiums. The
pressure on prices can make it difficult for us to underwrite policies on a profitable basis.

If increased competition causes us to lose market share, we could face disadvantages in terms of cost, especially fixed costs.
Since a substantial portion of our total costs constitute fixed costs (including general administrative costs), such losses would also
adversely affect margins in the remaining business.

If competitive pressures continue to increase or if we fail to respond to these changes or otherwise adapt to new develop-
ments in the market, we could suffer a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, cash flows, results of operations
and prospects.
1.1.5   We are exposed to an underwriting risk consisting of a premium risk and a claims risk.

risk_factor: We are exposed to an underwriting risk consisting of a premium risk and a claims risk.

blobs.text:
The underwriting risk results from the premium and claims risk. Premiums paid by policyholders might not be sufficient to
cover future claims for which the insurance company is liable. Future contractually stipulated claims will arise from the calculated
premiums, the amount of which is not known with certainty when premiums are determined (random and change risk). For example,
because we miscalculated the premiums for our electronics insurance in the past we stopped offering the electronics insurance and
the respective portfolio is in run-off. In addition, the risk of a lapse rate exceeding expectations could lead to an unexpected capital
loss that could adversely affect our ability to settle claims.

The premium and claims risks differ depending on the respective insurance line. In case of the supplementary health insur-
ance by type of life insurance risks must be taken into account that could arise from the fact that the calculation parameters, such as
mortality assumptions, cancellation rates or health cost rates, could change negatively in the future. In addition, the so-called catas-
trophe risks in the casualty insurance sector must be taken into account. These consist of the following risks:

•   Mass accident risk. The mass accident risk is the risk that a large number of people are affected by an accident at the
    same time.

•   Accumulation risk. The accumulation risk is the risk that a large number of the persons insured by us are affected by
    an accident.

•   Pandemic risk. The pandemic risk is the risk that insured events could result from the spread of infectious diseases
    can be caused.

In the case of property insurance, catastrophe risks consist of natural catastrophes (storms, floods, etc.) and man-made ca-
tastrophes (e.g. fire). Due to the occurrence of the above-mentioned catastrophe, there is a high risk of particularly high or a particu-
larly large number of individual insured events.

The occurrence of any of the risks set out above could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition,
cash flows, results of operations and prospects.
1.1.6   Our reserves set aside to pay insurance claims could prove insufficient, which could necessitate additional reserves

risk_factor: Our reserves set aside to pay insurance claims could prove insufficient, which could necessitate additional reserves.

blobs.text:
We determine the amount of the technical insurance reserves using actuarial methods and statistical models. Adjustments
are continuously made to take into account the most current market information available to us. Nonetheless, the reserves estab-
lished in this manner can turn out to be inadequate if the calculations of future insured events differ from actual claims experience.
Even a conservative assessment of the reserves as well as a regular actuarial examination cannot completely overcome this risk. In
property/casualty insurance, there is a risk that the reserves are not sufficient to anticipate damage from risks which are not yet fully
known or appreciated. Inadequate technical insurance reserves and the resulting need for additional reserves could have a material
adverse effect on our business, financial condition, cash flows, results of operations and prospects.
1.1.7   We bear significant credit risks as a result of our business activities.

risk_factor: We bear significant credit risks as a result of our business activities.

blobs.text:
As part of our business, we acquire a large number of receivables against counterparties, especially policyholders, reinsurers,
financial institutions, cooperation partners and insurance intermediaries. If our obligors experience financial difficulty and cannot or
do not pay the full amounts owed to us, we would be exposed to risks of financial losses, and might be required to write down or
write off certain assets. If our internal guidelines on concentration of credit and counterparty risks are not followed or turn out to be
inadequate, this could result in significant losses. In addition, we are exposed to systemic risk, which means that as a result of an ex-
traordinary strain on one or more market participants (for example, if a large reinsurer incurs high losses as a result of a major in-
sured event), the solvency of other companies that have contracted with such market participants and acquired receivables against
them could also be detrimentally affected. In view of the uncertain development of the capital markets and the general global eco-
nomic development, the decline in value in certain asset classes (such as real estate) and similar factors, counterparty risks could in-
crease in the future if such factors simultaneously impact the solvency of a multitude of market participants. The occurrence of any
of the risks set out above could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, cash flows, results of operations
and prospects.

1.1.8   Actuarial appraisals of insured risks, which are used to estimate the amount of potential claims under insurance
        policies, could prove to be incorrect.

risk_factor: Actuarial appraisals of insured risks, which are used to estimate the amount of potential claims under insurancepolicies, could prove to be incorrect.

blobs.text:
Our revenues depend to a substantial degree on the extent to which the actual future claims development corresponds to
the underwriting assumptions used to determine the price of such coverage. When setting-up a new insurance product, we must es-
timate the expenditures and the amount of potential claims under such insurance portfolio in order to determine commensurate
premiums to be paid on each policy. These actuarial calculations are based on past experience with similar policies, forecasts regard-
ing the future, and actuarial models. Over time, these assumptions could prove to be inaccurate and might therefore necessitate ad-
ditional expenditures. Despite efforts to minimize such risk, deviations can occur if data is interpreted incorrectly or external factors
outside the influence of our change. A price determination commensurate with the risk is also complicated in the property/casualty
business due to the increasing complexity, the volatility of expenditures in the property segment and the long-term nature of the
run-off, in particular in the casualty segment. If calculated premiums are insufficient to cover claims arising from insured events, it
could materially and adversely affect our business, financial condition, cash flows, results of operations and prospects.

1.1.9   Reinsurance for our insurance business might prove insufficient, or might not be available in the required scope or
        only on less favorable terms in the future.

risk_factor: Reinsurance for our insurance business might prove insufficient, or might not be available in the required scope oronly on less favorable terms in the future.

blobs.text:
The risks insured by us are partly transferred to reinsurance companies to finance premium growth and to protect ourselves
against major losses. Decisions about which insured risks are transferred and which risks are retained by us are made by us on the
basis of a large number of criteria. These include the risk strategy set by our management board (“Management Board”), the type
and level of the underwritten risks, the individual business segment’s ability to bear risks, the availability and the terms of reinsur-
ance as well as the reputation and financial strength of the relevant reinsurers. If the assumptions and forecasts used as a basis for
this decision differ from the actual circumstances and developments, there is a risk of an inadequate protection through reinsurance.

For reinsurance purposes, we use proportional reinsurance agreements with reputable reinsurers with excellent credit rat-
ings. In order to prevent cluster risks, we usually work together with a large number of partners in this area, whose solvency we
regularly prove. However, disruptions in the reinsurance markets, failure to come to terms with financially strong partners in the re-
insurance sector or, in the event that an existing reinsurance contract is terminated, to adequately replace this partner could prevent
us from being able to transfer underwritten risks to the extent desired or on acceptable terms. We could experience increased diffi-

culty obtaining these coverages on acceptable terms if increases in the frequency of natural disasters cause demand for reinsurance
coverage to increase at a time when underwriting capacity in the reinsurance market is decreasing. An increase in the frequency or
the volume of other major events causing damage could also worsen our risk position. In the future, only a few reinsurers with
strong capital bases might be able to write capital-intensive reinsurance, which could, together with limited access to capital, make it
more difficult for us to obtain reinsurance coverage on acceptable terms.

The occurrence of any of the risks set out above could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition,
cash flows, results of operations and prospects.
1.1.10 Our agreements with reinsurers could, in the event of claim expenses, be detrimental for us and limit our ability to

risk_factor: Our agreements with reinsurers could, in the event of claim expenses, be detrimental for us and limit our ability topay dividends.

blobs.text:
In the past, we have used proportional and non-proportional reinsurance for the purpose of reducing risk and replacing capi-
tal to finance further business growth. As a rule, an initial commission is paid when someone takes out insurance coverage. Since
generally accepted accounting principles do not permit complete deferral and subsequent amortization of such commission expens-
es over the term of an insurance contract, the upfront commission is recognized as an expense in the income statement. In the past,
we have used proportional reinsurance contracts to offset these expenses with an advance commission from the reinsurer. Under
the terms of these proportional reinsurance treaties, however, we must share a substantial part of its subsequent underwriting prof-
its with the reinsurer. In the event of claims expenses, the overall result of such a proportional reinsurance agreement may, there-
fore, be more in favor of the reinsurer than in favor of us.

Our intention to raise additional capital through an IPO offers the possibility of using its own capital to finance further busi-
ness growth and thus reducing the reinsurer's share in our business. However, we have and will in particular use reinsurance treaties
and non-proportional reinsurance treaties for the purpose of risk reduction and capital management. In view of the ban on postpon-
ing upfront commissions in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles, however, this change in the financing of future
growth will be a limiting factor for our ability to pay dividends in the first few years.

1.1.11 We rely to a certain extent on insurance intermediaries to distribute our insurance products. Disruptions to this dis-
       tribution network could materially reduce the volume of new policies.

risk_factor: We rely to a certain extent on insurance intermediaries to distribute our insurance products. Disruptions to this dis-tribution network could materially reduce the volume of new policies.

blobs.text:
However, we mainly distribute our insurances online, we also market our insurance products to a substantial extent through
a network of intermediaries, for example tied and independent agents as well as brokers. Our commercial success therefore depends
on our ability to retain a sufficient number of qualified, reliable and successful distribution intermediaries. Our business volume
could materially decline if our distribution strategy is unsuccessful or if our relationship with our distributors deteriorates. Failure to
maintain or expand these distribution relationships could lead to a decline in our business, as could the acquisition of our distribution
partners by a third party who does not intend to maintain the same level of cooperation with us. For example, we recently acquired
a 10% stake minus one share in the share capital of BCA AG, Oberursel, Germany (“BCA”), which could be taken over by a third party.

In addition, distribution risks could arise due to the existence of pools and combinations of brokers with significant market
power. The trend towards broker consolidation improves the negotiating power of the insurance brokers, including in relation to
commission rates and other terms for distribution, and could adversely affect the results of our operations.

Distribution risks also result from changes in the legal environment for insurance distribution. For example, there is no guar-
antee that the model for insurance brokerage currently prevalent in the Federal Republic of Germany (“Germany”) and elsewhere,
according to which the broker/agent receives a commission from the insurance company on the successful conclusion of an insur-
ance contract, which is then completely or partially passed on to the insurance customer in the calculation of the premiums, can con-
tinue to be viable.

If any of these distribution-related risks materializes, this could have an adverse material effect on our business, financial
condition, cash flows, results of operations and prospects.
1.1.12 We could lose important cooperation partners and therefore important customers.

risk_factor: We could lose important cooperation partners and therefore important customers

blobs.text:
We work with major cooperation partners who offer our products to their employees or members, as for example the in-
sured persons in a statutory health insurance, and therefore generate a high volume of premiums. If we lose a certain number of im-
portant cooperation partners, for example because competing insurance companies make better offers to these cooperation part-
ners or because the cooperation partners forgo insurance protection for their employees, this could materially and adversely affect
our business, financial condition, cash flows, results of operations and prospects.
1.1.13 Our risk management systems could fail to identify or control for material risks.

risk_factor: Our risk management systems could fail to identify or control for material risks.

blobs.text: We rely on complex and comprehensive systems for assessing and controlling risks. Despite detailed risk management guide-

lines subject to legal and regulatory requirements as well as supervision by the German Federal Financial Supervisory Authority
(Bundesanstalt für Finanzdienstleistungsaufsicht – “BaFin”), mistakes and disruptions in these systems cannot always be prevented.
For example, human error or disregard of applicable standards in the identification, assessment and handling of relevant risk infor-
mation and the disclosure of this information to the relevant decision makers, can result in a failure to recognize, assess or address
material risks in a timely manner.
