Our risk management aims to identify, control and ultimately systematically manage these risks at an early stage. Active risk
management is carried out by the Management Board and executives. The heads of department report routinely to the divisional or
full Management Board on the current course of business, also from a potentially risky perspective. In addition, the supervisory
board of the Company (the “Supervisory Board”) regularly deals with risk strategy issues at its meetings and is informed by the
Management board about business development and planning. The risk strategy of the company also includes risk shifting to sol-
vent-based reinsurance companies with first-class ratings via proportional risk assumption and flexibly expandable coverage for ma-
jor losses and natural catastrophes as well as an annually adjusted insurance cover for loss of earnings/operating interruptions, pub-
lic liability, office buildings, inventory and cyber risks. However, these measures may not be sufficient to identify or control all mate-
rial risks.

If the risk monitoring and risk management systems used by us inadequately reflect material risks or otherwise turn out to be
inadequate in any material respect, this could materially and adversely affect our business, financial condition, cash flows, results of
operations and prospects.
1.1.14 Operational risks could materially and adversely affect our business, results of operations and financial condition.

risk_factor: Operational risks could materially and adversely affect our business, results of operations and financial condition.

blobs.text:
We are subject to a large number of operational risks, including risks from internal operational failings (human or systems er-
ror), risks from third parties and risks from external events.

Internal operational risks can include the risk of employee misconduct, including violations of our own guidelines, applicable
laws or regulations (for example in handling confidential information, processing payments, executing investment strategies, han-
dling client accounts, and underwriting or transferring risks in the insurance business), as well as risks relating to on-the-job safety
and security. Operational risks can also result from authorized, legal conduct by employees, for example, strikes and labor disputes
that interrupt operations.

Operational risks resulting from a failure of internal processes or systems include the incorrect or incomplete storage of files,
data and important information; inadequate documentation of contracts; incorrect structure of products (especially insurance con-
tracts); mistakes in the settlement of claims; errors in monitoring the credit status of debtors; mistakes in planning resulting from
false information or false accounts; and failures of risk management processes. These risks could result in financial losses (including
lost sales, lost receivables or fines) or reputational damage for us.

Third parties can create operational risks for us through poor performance of contracted-for services or criminal or other in-
tentional misconduct, including theft, misappropriation, fraud, money laundering, sabotage, corporate espionage, arson or similar
crimes.

Operational risks resulting from external events include, for example, the risk that operations are interrupted due to infra-
structure failures (for example, a blockage of important traffic routes or outages of power, water or heat), or as a result of natural
disasters, fires or epidemics. Changes in the legal environment can also lead to operational risks.

If any of the operational risks above materializes, it could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition,
cash flows, results of operations and prospects.
1.1.15 Cost saving measures or measures to increase efficiency could fail or cause labour disputes.

risk_factor: Cost saving measures or measures to increase efficiency could fail or cause labour disputes.

blobs.text:
There is substantial competitive pressure in all markets in which we operate. Some competing insurance companies have
cost advantages as a result of their larger corporate size (economies of scale) or their distribution strategy. Managing expenses is
therefore of critical importance for our profitability, especially in mature markets. As a result, premiums at current levels - particular-
ly in property/casualty insurance - may not always be sufficient to generate positive margins. We have implemented various cost re-
duction and efficiency enhancement programs and will continue to do so in the future. However, there is no guarantee that these
initiatives can be successfully implemented or that they will yield the desired results. Cost reduction has been achieved by the digital-
ization of inter alia policy administration and claims handling which lead to a reduction in staff of about 100 employees. A complete
or partial failure of these cost saving and efficiency enhancement measures as well as employees’ actions could materially and ad-
versely affect our business, financial condition, cash flows, results of operations and prospects.

1.1.16 Previously unknown risks, so-called “emerging risks”, which cannot be reliably assessed, could lead to unforeseea-
       ble damages.

risk_factor: Previously unknown risks, so-called “emerging risks”, which cannot be reliably assessed, could lead to unforeseea-ble damages.

blobs.text:
The term “emerging risks” is used in the insurance industry to refer to previously unknown risks that could cause substantial
future losses and, therefore, are of major concern to insurance companies. Unlike traditional risks, emerging risks are difficult to ana-
lyze because they often exist as a hidden risk. Insurance premiums for emerging risks are difficult to calculate due to lack of historical
data about or experience with such risks or their consequences. For example, inadequate reserves for the cases involving thalido-
mide or asbestos have caused extremely high losses in the insurance industry. Presently, the consequences of potential, worldwide
climate change is considered an emerging risk. There are a wide scientific consensus and a growing public concern that globally in-
creasing emissions of greenhouse gases, especially carbon dioxide, are causing an increase in the average worldwide surface temper-
atures. This increase in average temperatures could increase the frequency of hurricanes, floods, droughts, forest fires, and could
cause sea levels to rise due to the melting of the polar ice caps. Other examples of emerging risks are epidemics and pandemics, as
well as risks stemming from the development of nanotechnology or genetic engineering. The losses and environmental damage
caused by the explosion of the oil platform “Deepwater Horizon” in April 2010 can also be considered to be an emerging risk. In an
attempt to contain the leaking crude oil, the prohibition on using the chemical Corexit was temporarily lifted in order to permit use
of this chemical to eliminate the crude oil. Since this chemical can cause serious illness, collect in organisms and persist in the envi-
ronment decades later, future insurance claims in connection therewith are possible.

Despite our efforts at early identification and continuous monitoring of emerging risks, we cannot guarantee that we will be
able to identify all emerging risks and implement measures to avoid or minimize claims exposure to them. Defects and inadequacies
in the identification and response to emerging risks could lead to unforeseen damages and could materially and adversely affect our
business, financial condition, cash flows, results of operations and prospects.
1.1.17 Acceptance of our online insurance products offering may decrease or fail to improv

risk_factor: Acceptance of our online insurance products offering may decrease or fail to improve.

blobs.text:
The online penetration in the insurance industry is still relatively low, with only 16.9% of accident insurance policies sold
through direct sales (Direktvertrieb) in 2016, of which only a portion was agreed online. Nevertheless, this is a growing trend as cus-
tomers increasingly use messenger apps in insurance matters (Source: GDV, Analysis 2018, p. 17 et seqq.). If the acceptance of our
online insurance product offering decreases or fails to improve, our business may be adversely affected.

Our success will largely depend on our ability to attract customers who have historically concluded insurance products
through intermediaries and brokers and a number of factors may deter them from concluding such products online, including:

If our online offering fails to meet the expectations of existing or future customers, this could lead to lower demand for our
products and adversely affect our business.

A lack of acceptance for our online offering of insurance products could have a material adverse effect on our business, fi-
nancial condition, cash flows, results of operations and prospects.

1.1.18 The growth and success of our business depends on the continued growth of the online market, the corresponding
       shift from offline to online and mobile devices as well customers’ acceptance of online platforms.

risk_factor: The growth and success of our business depends on the continued growth of the online market, the correspondingshift from offline to online and mobile devices as well customers’ acceptance of online platforms.

blobs.text:
Customers may not readily adapt to the use of online channels for insurances, particularly in regions where face-to-face
transactions remain predominant. There is no guarantee that the markets in which we operate will continue to grow at rates experi-
enced in the past. Competitors may provide alternatives or substitutes for the current form of online insurances that could render
our business obsolete.

Our growth depends to a large extent on the growth of the internet and mobiles devices as channels for online customer
transactions. We believe that online insurance market will continue to grow only if acceptance of the internet and mobile devices as
distribution channels continues, and if we can maintain the availability and user-friendliness of our platforms to attract new custom-

ers. Even if customers desire to make use of the internet for insurances and other transactions, the difficulties of developing internet
and mobile infrastructures in emerging and developing markets may limit their ability to do so and may limit our growth opportuni-
ties.

In order for us to be successful and grow, customers have to accept our value proposition. However, there is no guarantee
that additional customers will use the services provided by our online platform. There is also a risk that our business model may
come under pressure as a result of political and lobby activism against online insurances.

The materialization of any of these risks could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, cash flows,
results of operations and prospects.
1.1.19 We face intense competition from traditional insurer as well as other online insurer, which may intensify even fur-

risk_factor: We face intense competition from traditional insurer as well as other online insurer, which may intensify even fur-ther.

blobs.text:
The market for online insurance products is highly competitive, fragmented and rapidly changing. We face competition from
a diversified group of competitors operating under various brands. The competitors we face differ between our geographic markets
as well as different product categories and include:
Iduna,

Many of our competitors have longer operating histories, greater brand recognition, larger fulfillment infrastructures, greater
technical capabilities, faster and less costly IT-systems, significantly greater financial, marketing and other resources and a larger cus-
tomer base compared to us. These advantages may allow our competitors to derive higher revenue and profits from their existing
customer base, acquire customers at lower costs or respond faster to new or emerging products and changes in consumer habits.
Our competitors may undertake more far-reaching marketing campaigns and adopt more aggressive pricing policies, which may ad-
versely impact our competitive position. In addition, many of the traditional insurers are increasingly investing in their online offer-
ings, leading to growing competition in the online insurance industry. Furthermore, new competitors may emerge, or insurers that
currently operate in other countries may choose to enter, or expand into, our markets. Furthermore, some of our competitors may
merge or form strategic partnerships, increasing their size even further.

Competitive pressure from our current or future competitors or an inability to adapt effectively and quickly to a changing
competitive landscape could adversely affect demand for our products, force us to cut prices and thereby adversely affect our
growth. We compete for customers mainly on the basis of the simplicity and speed of our product offering, the attractiveness of our
prices relative to the offered coverage, the strength of our brand and the quality of our services, including our customer service, the
convenience and functionality of our IT-platform as well as the speed of our claim settlement. If we fail to compete effectively in any
one of these areas, we may lose existing consumers and fail to attract new customers.

Intense competition from other insurer could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, cash flows,
results of operations and prospects.
1.1.20 Any failure to maintain, protect and enhance our reputation and brands may adversely affect our business.

risk_factor: Any failure to maintain, protect and enhance our reputation and brands may adversely affect our business.

blobs.text:
The recognition and reputation of our brands, in particular "Deutsche Familienversicherung", among customers and suppliers
are critical for the growth and continued success of our business as well as for our competitiveness in our target market. Maintaining
a leading brand is key in the online insurance industry and competition among online insurers typically favors the market participants
with the strongest brands. While lesser brands may also be able to operate profitably, the market participant with the strongest
brand typically captures a very large market share. Therefore, any developments that harm our brands could materially adversely
affect our business.

As competition in our markets intensifies, we anticipate that maintaining and enhancing our brand will become increasingly
difficult and expensive, and investments to increase the value of our brands may not be successful. Many factors, some of which are
beyond our control, are important for maintaining and enhancing our brands, including our ability to:

•   compile an attractive insurance product offering sold at attractive prices;

•   increase brand awareness through marketing and brand promotion activities;

Any failure to offer simple but also reliable products and excellent customer service could damage our reputation and brands
and result in the loss of customers.

We rely on social media (e.g., Facebook, Instagram and Twitter) for the promotion of our brand and marketing efforts, and
any negative publicity may be accelerated through social media due to its immediacy and accessibility as a means of communication.
Such negative publicity, even if factually incorrect or based on isolated incidents, could damage our reputation, diminish the value of
our brands, undermine the trust and credibility we have established and have a negative impact on our ability to attract new or re-
tain existing customers. Given the rapid nature of social media, we may be unable to react to such negative publicity in a timely
manner.

Any failure to maintain, protect and enhance our reputation and brands could have a material adverse effect on our business,
financial condition, cash flows, results of operations and prospects.
1.1.21 Our significant investments in marketing may fail to yield the desired results.

risk_factor: Our significant investments in marketing may fail to yield the desired results.

blobs.text:
We have made, and will continue to make, significant investments in our marketing efforts. In order to reach a diverse cus-
tomer base in the insurance industry, we employ a wide range of both paid and unpaid marketing channels. Our paid marketing
channels primarily focus on online marketing, including through search engine marketing (in particular in cooperation with Google
and Bing), retargeting (in particular in cooperation with Facebook and Google), price comparison marketing as well as paid social
media. We also use traditional marketing channels such as TV advertising for Germany. Our unpaid marketing channels (i.e., market-
ing efforts that do not require us to make payments to any third parties) include search engine optimization, unpaid social media
(e.g., Facebook, Instagram and Twitter) as well as newsletters in the form of emails.

Furthermore, we cannot guarantee that our current marketing channels will continue to be effective, permissible and gener-
ally available to us in the future. Our online partners might be unable to deliver the anticipated number of customer visits, or visitors
that are attracted to our websites by such campaigns might not make the anticipated conclusions of contracts. In addition, new regu-
lation may adversely affect certain marketing channels, in particular regulation aimed at controlling and censoring social media and
increasing data protection of natural persons. If we are unable to attract sufficient traffic to our websites, translate a sufficient num-
ber of website visits into purchasers with sufficiently large order values, build and maintain a loyal customer base, increase the fre-
quency of agreement conclusion, or do any of the foregoing on a cost effective basis, this could adversely affect our business. In ad-
dition, in the context of online marketing, acquisition costs incur irrespective of future cancellations of the insurance contract by pol-
icyholders.

If we are unable to successfully market our insurance product offering, this could have a material adverse effect on our busi-
ness, financial condition, cash flows, results of operations and prospects.

1.1.22 If our websites and apps do not achieve a high ranking in organic search results, this could reduce traffic to o
       websites and apps.

risk_factor: If our websites and apps do not achieve a high ranking in organic search results, this could reduce traffic to ourwebsites and apps.

blobs.text:
A significant number of our customers access our websites and apps by clicking on a link contained in organic search results
generated by search engines such as Google and Bing and we endeavor to increase such relevant traffic by increasing the ranking of
our websites and apps in organic searches, a process known as search engine optimization. However, the algorithms and ranking cri-
teria of such search engines are confidential. Consequently, we do not have complete information on such algorithms and ranking
criteria, making our efforts at search engine optimization considerably more difficult. Furthermore, search engines frequently modify
their algorithms and ranking criteria to prevent their organic search results from being manipulated, which could impair our search
engine optimization efforts. If we are unable to quickly recognize and adapt our techniques to such modifications in search engine
algorithms or if our search engine optimization efforts prove otherwise ineffective, we may need to increase our spending on other
forms of marketing or may potentially suffer a significant decrease in traffic to our websites and apps.
In addition, search engines may consider our search engine optimization efforts manipulative or deceptive and therefore see

them as a violation their terms of services. This may result in our websites and apps being excluded from organic search results. The
same may occur if search engines modify their terms of service to prohibit our search engine optimization efforts. Any exclusion of
our websites and apps from organic search results could significantly reduce our ability to attract relevant traffic to our websites and
materially adversely affect our business.

An inability to achieve a high ranking for our websites and apps in organic search engine results could have a material ad-
verse effect on our business, financial condition, cash flows, results of operations and prospects.

1.1.23 We may be unable to effectively communicate with our customers through email and other messages as well as so-
       cial media.

risk_factor: We may be unable to effectively communicate with our customers through email and other messages as well as so-cial media.

blobs.text:
We use newsletters in the form of emails and other messaging services as an unpaid marketing channel to promote our web-
sites and inform customers of our insurance product offering. However, changes in how webmail services organize and prioritize
emails could reduce the number of customers opening our emails. For example, Google Inc.'s Gmail service provides a feature that
organizes incoming emails into categories (e.g., primary, social and promotions). Such tools and features could result in our emails
and other messages being shown as "spam" or lower priority to our customers, which could reduce the likelihood of customers
opening or responding positively to them. Actions by third parties to block, impose restrictions on, or charge for the delivery of,
emails and other messages, as well as legal or regulatory changes limiting our right to send such messages or imposing additional
requirements, could impair our ability to communicate with our customers. If we are unable to send emails or other messages to our
customers, if such messages are delayed, or if customers do not receive or decline to open them, we can no longer use this unpaid
marketing channel. This could impair our marketing efforts or make them more expensive if we have to increase spending on paid
marketing channels to compensate and as a result, our business could be adversely affected.

Malfunctions of our email and messaging services could result in erroneous messages being sent and customers no longer
wanting to receive any messages from us. Furthermore, our process to obtain consent from visitors to our websites to receive news-
letters and other messages from us and to allow us to use their data may be insufficient or invalid. As a result, such individuals or
third parties may accuse us of sending unsolicited advertisements and other messages. In addition, our use of email and other mes-
saging services could result in claims being brought against us.

Since we also rely on social media to communicate with our customers, changes to the terms and conditions of the relevant
providers could limit our ability to communicate through social media. These services may change their algorithms or interfaces
without notifying us, which may reduce our visibility. In addition, there could be a decline in the use of such social media by our cus-
tomers, in which case we may be required to find other, potentially more expensive communication channels.

An inability to communicate through emails and other messages as well as social media could have a material adverse effect
on our business, financial condition, cash flows, results of operations and prospects.
1.1.24 We may be subject to negative publicity, including inaccurate adverse information.

risk_factor: We may be subject to negative publicity, including inaccurate adverse information.

blobs.text:
Customers value readily available information concerning online insurer and often act on such information without further
investigation or authentication or regard to its accuracy. Social media and websites immediately publish posts from users, often
without filters or checks on the accuracy of the content posted. Allegations against us may be posted on social media, in Internet
chat rooms or on blogs or websites by anyone on an anonymous basis. In addition, we may be the target of harassment or other det-
rimental conduct by third parties, including from our competitors. Our reputation may be negatively affected as a result of the public
dissemination of anonymous allegations or demeaning statements about our business, even if these allegations or statements are
unfounded and we may be required to spend significant time and money to address such allegations. Inaccurate adverse information
may harm our business and we may not be able to redress or correct inaccurate posts in a timely manner, or at all.

Our business may become the subject of negative media coverage and public attention, which may develop strong dynamics
and adversely affect our business. In addition, third parties may communicate complaints to regulatory agencies and we may be sub-
ject to government or regulatory investigation as a result of such complaints. There is no assurance that we will be able to conclu-
sively refute such allegations in a timely manner, or at all.

Negative publicity and complaints could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, cash flows, re-
sults of operations and prospects.

In the future, we intend to introduce new products and product bundles to our offering. We cannot guarantee that we will at
all times be able to source and successfully introduce attractive products at suitable prices for our product offering. In particular, we
cannot assess whether the new products will arouse interest among customers in the online insurance market. When developing
new products, we are limited to those products that are in line with our licenses. At the time of this prospectus our license to con-

duct insurance business is limited to supplementary health insurance, property and casualty insurance, general liability, several fi-
nancial losses, legal expenses insurance as well as reinsurance of the aforementioned insurance lines. We may not be able to receive
the required licenses with regard to new products which we intend to offer.

In addition, customer preferences regarding price, insured amount and services of insurance products may change rapidly,
requiring us to quickly adapt our product offering to meet such evolving customer demands. However, there is no guarantee that we
will be able to source and successfully introduce new and innovative products in time. Should our competitors be able to introduce
particularly attractive products, e.g. in cooperation with a specific partner, for which they hold exclusive rights, we may not be able
to provide our customers with a comparable offering.

An inability to maintain and expand our product offering could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial con-
dition, cash flows, results of operations and prospects.

n, cash flows, results of operations and prospects.

   1.1.26 Our payment systems could fail to function properly.

risk_factor: Our payment systems could fail to function properly.

blobs.text:
In order to provide an easy subscription procedure, we offer a broad range of payment options, in particular Amazon Pay,
PayPal, invoicing and advance payments. We cannot guarantee that all of these payment options will always be available for our cus-
tomers. The business policy of the providers of such payment methods or the legal framework for the use of these payment systems
could change. This could affect or even eliminate our ability to offer such payment options to our customers at all. As a result, we
might not be able to attract further customers or we could lose existing customers. Due to the variety and complexity of these pay-
ment methods, we may also experience failures in our checkout process which could adversely affect our conversion rate (i.e., the
share of potential customers visiting our websites and apps who actually place an order) and business. Furthermore, permitting new
and innovative online payment options may increase the risk of fraud. High levels of fraud could result in us having to comply with
additional requirements or pay higher payment processing fees or fines.

We generally rely on third parties to provide payment processing services and on third-party payment processors and en-
cryption and authentication technology licensed from third parties that is designed to effect secure transmission of personal infor-
mation of our customers. If these companies become unwilling or unable to provide these services or increase their fees, our opera-
tions may be disrupted and our operating costs could increase. In addition, our invoice and billing systems may malfunction due to
the implementation of new payment methods and technology, errors in existing codes or other IT-issues, which may impair our abil-
ity to create correct invoices, avoid the recording of duplicate invoices or payments and collect payments in a timely manner, or at
all. We could also be excluded from using these new payment methods and technology.

Additional legal and regulatory requirements, both domestic and abroad, may restrict our ability to deploy these payment
systems as planned and needed for business purposes. Such additional limitations may include, but are not restricted to, tax, data
privacy, or anti-money laundering regulations. In case our ability to use the payments methods we offer is restricted due to legal and
regulatory requirements, we may become less attractive to customers and we may not be able to collect contributions from or to
make refunds to certain customers in part or at all.

The materialization of any of these risks could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, cash flows,
results of operations and prospects.
1.1.27 Dissatisfaction with our customer service could prevent us from retaining our customers.

risk_factor: Dissatisfaction with our customer service could prevent us from retaining our customers.

blobs.text:
Other than in our headquarter in Frankfurt, Germany, we do not have the direct face-to-face contact with our customers and
customers may quickly become frustrated when they cannot find a representative to talk to. To provide customer service, we pursue
a multi-channel support approach, responding by email and live chat, through our hotlines and via social media. The satisfaction of
our customers depends in particular on the effectiveness of our customer service, in particular our ability to deal with complaints
(e.g., with respect to products, withdrawals, technical problems, payment, invoicing and claim settlement) in a timely and satisfying
manner. In addition, as we continue to grow, we may need to add customer service capabilities and may not be able to do so in a
timely manner, or at all. Any unsatisfactory response or lack of responsiveness (e.g., due to interruptions of our customer portal or
hotlines) by our customer service team could adversely affect customer satisfaction and loyalty. In addition, our customers could dis-
approve the increasing use of AI and force us to limit the use of AI on our platform, in particular in our customer journey. As a result,
we may no longer or only partially be able to operate our automated claims and settlement processes and may, thus, require addi-
tional personnel, which may lead to considerable higher costs. As part of our complaints management system, customer complaints
are recorded and evaluated in order to detect any reputational risk at an early stage. However, the reputational risks due to various
complaints cannot be excluded.

Dissatisfaction with our customer service could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, cash
flows, results of operations and prospects.
1.1.28 We may experience significant termination cases.

risk_factor: We may experience significant termination cases.

blobs.text:
We offer our customers a right of termination on a daily basis which is generally more generous than the legally required
termination periods and termination periods of competitors. Due to the right of daily termination (e.g., due to consumers being dis-
satisfied with our products or customer service), we cannot guarantee that we have constant customer numbers over a longer peri-
od of time. For instance, reputational risks may have a strong impact on the Company´s number of customers in connection with the
daily termination right. In addition, we offer an extended right of withdrawal for a period of two months. If customers make use of
their termination rights or right of withdrawal, we may have to repay all or parts of the contributions already received from those
customers.

If a significant number of customers terminate their contract, this could have a material adverse effect on our business, fi-
nancial condition, cash flows, results of operations and prospects.
1.1.29 Investments in our IlT-platform and IT-infrastructure may not vield the desired results.

risk_factor: Investments in our IT-platform and IT-infrastructure may not yield the desired results.

blobs.text:
We develop or purchase proprietary software to facilitate our business operations, data gathering analysis and online mar-
keting capabilities and have invested significant capital and man hours into building and updating our IT-platform and IT-
infrastructure. In order to remain competitive, we expect to continue to make significant investments in our IT. However, there is no
guarantee that the resources we have invested or will invest in the future will allow us to develop suitable IT-solutions and maintain
and expand our IT-platform and IT-infrastructure as intended, which may adversely affect our ability to compete or require us to pur-
chase expensive software solutions from third-party developers. In addition, changes in the license terms of the software we use
could result in considerable additional expenses for further use. As a result, we may no longer or only partially be able to operate the
automated claims and settlement process and thus require additional personnel, which may lead to considerable higher costs.

If our investments in our IT-platform and IT-infrastructure do not yield the desired results, this could have a material adverse
effect on our business, financial condition, cash flows, results of operations and prospects.

1.1.30 We may fail to operate, maintain, integrate and upgrade our IT-infrastructure, or to adopt and apply technological
       advances.

risk_factor: We may fail to operate, maintain, integrate and upgrade our IT-infrastructure, or to adopt and apply technologicaladvances.

blobs.text:
Our success depends on our websites and app being accessible to potential and existing customers at all times. It may be-
come increasingly difficult to maintain and improve the availability of our websites and app. We have previously experienced disrup-
tions and may experience further disruptions, outages, or other issues in the future (e.g., due to changes in our IT-infrastructure,
human or software errors). If we fail to effectively address capacity constraints, respond adequately to disruptions or upgrade our IT-
infrastructure our mobile apps or websites could become unavailable or fail to load quickly and customers may decide to inform
themselves about insurances elsewhere, and may not return, which would adversely affect our business.

Given that the Internet and mobile devices are characterized by rapid technological advances, our future success will depend
on our ability to adapt our websites, app and other parts of our IT-platform to such advances (e.g., advances in the field of machine
learning, artificial intelligence (“AI”), augmented reality and virtual reality) and to sustain their interoperability with relevant operat-
ing systems. In particular, the consolation of contracts from mobile devices has increased rapidly since we introduced our app. How-
ever, the variety of technical and other configurations across mobile devices and platforms (e.g., screen resolutions, functionality,
features and memory) makes it more difficult to develop websites and apps that are suitable for multiple channels. In addition, any
changes in popular operating systems (e.g., iOS or Android) may reduce the functionality of our websites and apps or give preferen-
tial treatment to competitors. Any failure to adapt to technological advances in a timely manner and to integrate our offerings
through our websites and apps could decrease the attractiveness of our apps and websites and adversely affect our business.

The materialization of any of these risks could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, cash flows,
results of operations and prospects.

1.1.31 We depend on the reliable functioning of our own and third-party IT systems, and a major failure in these systems
       could disrupt our business.

risk_factor: We depend on the reliable functioning of our own and third-party IT systems, and a major failure in these systemscould disrupt our business.

blobs.text:
We depend on the reliable and efficient functioning of computer and data processing systems and telecommunication sys-
tems to conduct our operations. Since these systems are susceptible to failures and problems (for example as a result of power fail-
ures, computer viruses, harmful software, hacker attacks, misuse by employees, or hardware, software or network problems), fail-
ures or problems cannot necessarily be prevented despite the adoption of comprehensive protective and back-up measures. Fur-
thermore, regular maintenance of the IT systems is required, for example when changing software or migrating processes following
the acquisition of companies or business units. If done incorrectly, such maintenance can also lead to failures, problems and delays.

A major failure or disruption in one or more computer or data processing systems operated by us or third-party IT providers
could disrupt our operations. A broad or ongoing disruption of operations could materially and adversely affect our business, finan-
cial condition, cash flows, results of operations and prospects.
1.1.32 We are subject to business policy decisions of large IT companies such as Google, Amazon or Apple.

risk_factor: We are subject to business policy decisions of large IT companies such as Google, Amazon or Apple.

blobs.text:
We rely on the ongoing use of third-party IT-based services (e.g. Apple App Store, Amazon's Alexa, Google Play) for our busi-
ness model. Nevertheless, it is possible that changes in the business policy of these third-parties (e.g. by Amazon, Google or Apple) or
changes in the legal framework conditions may prevent us from using these services or restrict their use. Our business model de-
pends heavily on these services, as we use them both for customer acquisition and customer communication. Exclusion or restriction
in the use of these services could therefore result in us being able to reach fewer potential customers or losing existing customers.

The exclusion or the restriction in the use of these services could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial
condition, cash flows, results of operations and prospects.
1.1.33 We may experience malfunctions or disruptions of our IT-systems.

risk_factor: We may experience malfunctions or disruptions of our IT-systems.

blobs.text:
We rely on a complex IT-platform and IT-systems to operate our websites and app. While we analyze our IT-systems regular-
ly, we may not be able to correctly assess how prone to errors or viruses they are. Any failure of or disruptions to our IT-systems may
lead to significant malfunctions and downtimes of our websites and app, all of which could adversely affect our business. In addition,
our management of malfunctions may be inadequate. If we cannot fix any malfunctions ourselves, we might have to pay third parties
to either fix the malfunctions or to license functioning software, which might prove costly.

We depend on certain third-party service providers to maintain our IT-systems, and we may have to further outsource our IT
infrastructure so that we can respond better to future requirements and changes to the applicable legal framework in the markets in
which we operate. If such service providers were to increase their prices, this could adversely affect our margins. In addition, if we
were forced to switch service providers (e.g., because their software is no longer fully compatible with our IT-platform), there is no
guarantee that alternative service providers will be available to us or to acceptable terms or that we can manage the transition suc-
cessfully. In the event of termination of existing software agreements, the source code of third-party commercial software that we
have used for some of our software and systems, including our position management system, may be made available to the public or
our competitors.

As we continue to grow our business, we may be required to further scale our IT-platform and IT-systems, including by add-
ing new systems and proprietary software, replacing outdated hardware and increasing the integration of our IT-systems. Such
changes may, however, be delayed or fail due to malfunctions or an inability to integrate new software and functions with our exist-
ing IT-platform, resulting in disruptions to our operations and insufficient scale to support our future growth.

Any malfunctions and disruptions of our IT-systems could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition,
cash flows, results of operations and prospects.
1.1.34 We may experience security breaches and disruptions due to hacking, viruses, fraud and malicious attacks.

risk_factor: We may experience security breaches and disruptions due to hacking, viruses, fraud and malicious attacks.

blobs.text:
We operate websites, app and other IT-systems through which we collect, maintain, transmit and store sensitive information
about our customers, suppliers and other third parties (e.g., payment information and personal information) as well as proprietary
information and business secrets. We also employ third-party service providers that store, process and transmit such information on
our behalf, in particular payment details. Furthermore, we rely on encryption and authentication technology licensed from third par-
ties to securely transmit sensitive and confidential information. While we take steps to protect the security, integrity and confidenti-
ality of sensitive and confidential information (e.g., password policies and firewalls), our security practices may be insufficient and
third parties may access our IT-systems without authorization (e.g., through Trojans, spyware, ransomware or other malware at-
tacks), which may result in unauthorized use or disclosure of such information. Such attacks might lead to blackmailing attempts,
forcing us to pay substantial amounts to release our captured data or resulting in the unauthorized release of such data. Given that
techniques used in these attacks change frequently and often are not recognized until launched against a target, it may be impossi-
ble to properly secure our IT-systems. In addition, technical advances or a continued expansion and increased complexity of our IT-
platform could increase the likelihood of security breaches.

Security breaches may also occur as a result of non-technical issues, including intentional or inadvertent breaches by our em-
ployees or third-party service providers. Insufficient security practices, such as inadequate policies to enforce password complexity,
the saving of username and password combinations on local browsers, the use of default credentials or their reuse coupled with the
use of cloud services, the use of unauthorized and unprotected software as well as inadequate physical protection against unauthor-
ized access may make our IT-systems vulnerable and lead to unauthorized disclosure of sensitive information.

Any leakage of sensitive information could lead to a misuse of data (e.g., unsolicited emails or other messages based on spam
lists fed with such data). Inefficient management of administrator and user accounts may increase the risk of fraud and malfunctions.
In addition, any such breach could violate applicable privacy, data security and other laws, and cause significant legal and financial

risks, negative publicity and adversely affect our business and reputation. In addition, we may need to devote significant resources to
protect ourselves against security breaches or to address such breaches and there is no guarantee that our resources will be suffi-
cient to do so. Furthermore, we provide certain information to third-party service providers who help us assess the performance of
our business (e.g., Google Analytics). Consequently, we only have limited control over the protection of such information by the rele-
vant third-party service providers and may be adversely affected by breaches and disruptions of their respective IT-systems.

Security breaches and disruptions could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, cash flows, re-
sults of operations and prospects.
1.1.35 We may require additional capital which might not be available on economically acceptable terms, or at all.

risk_factor: We may require additional capital which might not be available on economically acceptable terms, or at all.

blobs.text:
In the medium to long term, we will likely require additional capital to finance our future growth or further scale our online
platform. If we are not able to raise the required capital on economically acceptable terms, or at all, we may be forced to limit or
even scale back our operations, which may adversely affect our growth, business and market share and could ultimately lead to an
insolvency of the Company. In addition, we may fail to accurately project and anticipate our capital needs.

If we chose to raise capital by issuing new shares, our ability to place such shares at attractive prices, or at all, depends on the
condition of equity capital markets in general and the share price of the Company in particular, and such share price may be subject
to considerable fluctuations.

Our opportunities to raise capital through debt financing are subject to regulatory requirements and therefore limited. If we
chose to raise capital through debt financing in line with the rules on insurance regulation, such financing may require us to post col-
lateral in favor of the relevant lenders or impose other restrictions on our business and financial position (e.g., in the form of cove-
nants). Such restrictions may adversely affect our operations and ability to grow our business as intended. A breach of the relevant
covenants or other contractual obligations contained in our external financing agreements may trigger immediate prepayment obli-
gations or may lead the relevant lenders to seize collateral posted by us, all of which may adversely affect our business. In addition, if
we raise capital through debt financing on unfavorable terms, this could adversely affect our operational flexibility and profitability.

Any inability to obtain capital on economically acceptable terms, or at all, could have a material adverse effect on our busi-
ness, financial condition, cash flows, results of operations and prospects and, ultimately, also lead to an insolvency of the Company.
1.1.36 We may be unable to successfully integrate, or achieve the expected benefits from, future acquisitions.

risk_factor: We may be unable to successfully integrate, or achieve the expected benefits from, future acquisitions.

blobs.text:
We recently acquired a 10% stake minus one share in the share capital of BCA, a brokerage company based in Oberursel,
Germany, in order to expand our distribution channels. In the future, we may acquire other business, assets and licenses on an op-
portunistic basis. However, there is no guarantee that we will find suitable acquisition targets to grow our business at reasonable
prices, or at all. If we do complete any acquisitions, we may have to finance them with significant amounts of cash or shares, incur
additional debt, assume loss making businesses and incur other expenses. Such acquisitions could result in a significant commitment
of management resources and dilute the holdings of our existing shareholders (the “Existing Shareholders”).

There is no guarantee that we will be able to integrate future acquisitions and achieve the anticipated cost savings, synergies
or other benefits, and such benefits may be more than offset by integration costs. In addition, we may not be in a position to carry
out substantive due diligence and if we fail to identify and correctly assess all issues, liabilities, risks or other shortcomings or chal-
lenges (e.g., issues related to intellectual property, data protection, compliance, licenses accounting practices or employee or cus-
tomer issues), our business may be adversely affected and we could incur unexpected costs.

An inability to integrate future acquisitions and achieve the expected benefits therefrom could have a material adverse effect
on our business, financial condition, cash flows, results of operations and prospects.

1.1.37 We depend on our personnel to grow and operate our business and may not be able to retain and replace existing
       personnel or to attract new personnel.

risk_factor: We depend on our personnel to grow and operate our business and may not be able to retain and replace existingpersonnel or to attract new personnel.

blobs.text:
As digitalized insurance company, we depend in particular upon the continued services of the members of our governing
bodies, senior management and other qualified personnel. With regard to the management and senior management as well as other
persons carrying out key functions in the Company, insurance supervisory law stipulates fit and proper requirements which include
adequate theoretical and practical knowledge of insurance business. Our future success will depend upon our ability to identify, hire,
develop, motivate and retain qualified personnel not only in the management of the company but in general. Some of our employ-
ees have a short employment history with us and are still in the onboarding phase and we experience significant fluctuation which
makes it difficult to effectively integrate and align our workforce with our strategic goals. We may not be able to retain the services
of our qualified employees (e.g., due to higher salaries paid by our competitors) and there is no guarantee that we will be able to at-
tract suitable replacements in a timely manner, or at all. We may also incur significant additional costs to recruit such suitable re-
placements. Changes in our senior management may be disruptive to our business and if our senior management fails to cooperate

effectively and to execute our plans and strategies, our business could be adversely affected. In addition, we are particularly affected
by the high demand and the small number of qualified software developers with regard to our digital business model. This can lead
to the fact that we cannot fill all necessary positions in the desired time or software developers are enticed away. Thus, this can de-
lay the development of our IT and result in considerable costs for commissioning external software developers.

Our continued growth depends on our ability to expand our business by identifying, attracting, recruiting, training, integrat-
ing, managing and motivating new personnel, which may require significant time, investments, and management attention. Competi-
tion for personnel is intense, particularly for IT-experts and other qualified personnel in the online sector. In addition, new employ-
ment and immigration regulations may adversely affect our ability to find the required personnel. In addition, employer rating web-
sites are of increasing importance in the online sector and if we receive negative ratings from current or former employees, this
could adversely affect our ability to attract new personnel, even if these ratings are unjustified or malicious.

An inability to retain and replace existing personnel or to attract new personnel could have a material adverse effect on our
business, financial condition, cash flows, results of operations and prospects.
1.1.38 We are subject to various risks for which we may not be adequately insured.

risk_factor: We are subject to various risks for which we may not be adequately insured.

blobs.text:
While we have purchased what we consider to be market standard insurance coverage customary in our industry (e.g., direc-
tors and officers (D&O) insurance, public and professional liability insurance, building insurance, business content insurance, elec-
tronics insurance, loss of income insurance, industrial criminal legal expenses insurance and fidelity insurance), such insurance does
not cover all risks associated with our business. Accidents and other events, including interruptions or security breaches of our IT-
platform, could potentially lead to interruptions of our operations or cause us to incur significant costs, all of which may not be fully
covered by our insurance policies. In addition, our insurance coverage is subject to various limitations and exclusions, retentions
amounts and limits. For instance, the Offering is regarded as an increase of risk according to the terms and conditions of the D&O
insurance. The insurer must agree with the increase of risk, otherwise insurance coverage will be at risk. Furthermore, if any of our
insurance providers becomes insolvent, we may not be able to successfully claim payment from such insurance provider. In the fu-
ture, we may not be able to obtain coverage at current levels, or at all, and premiums for our insurance may increase significantly.

A lack of adequate insurance coverage could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, cash flows,
results of operations and prospects.
1.1.39 We have no prior experience as a public company, which may adversely affect our business.

risk_factor: We have no prior experience as a public company, which may adversely affect our business.

blobs.text:
We have no prior experience operating as a public company, interacting with public investors and complying with the in-
creasingly complex laws pertaining to public companies (e.g., reporting obligations, public disclosure requirements, corporate gov-
ernance and accounting standards). New obligations applicable to us will require substantial attention from our senior management
and could divert their attention away from the day to day management of our business. There is no guarantee that we will be able to
achieve a smooth and efficient transition to being a public company and fully comply with all new requirements. Such requirements
will increase our costs (e.g., when hiring new employees or outside consultants to help us comply with these requirements) and such
increased costs may turn out higher than currently anticipated, and additional requirements may make certain activities more diffi-
cult and time consuming.

The consequences of being a public company could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, cash
flows, results of operations and prospects.

1.1.40 We may not be able to adapt our accounting, our internal controls as well as our reporting and risk management
       procedures to our rapid growth and the requirements of being a public company.

risk_factor: We may not be able to adapt our accounting, our internal controls as well as our reporting and risk managementprocedures to our rapid growth and the requirements of being a public company.

blobs.text:
The rapid growth of our business to date has placed, and any future growth is expected to continue to place, significant de-
mands on our management, our operational and financial infrastructure and our accounting. We are in the process of adapting our
accounting, our internal controls as well as our reporting and risk management procedures to the rapid growth of our business, but
there is no guarantee that we will be able to implement adequate procedures in a timely manner, or at all. As our operations grow
further, we will need to continue to improve and upgrade our accounting, our management systems and our internal procedures to
deal with the greater scale and complexity of our operations and the increasing legal and regulatory demands of the applicable ac-
counting requirements. Such expansion will require us to commit substantial management, operational and other resources in ad-
vance of any increase in the size of the business, with no assurance that our revenue and profit will increase accordingly.

In addition, becoming a public company represents another challenge which will put pressure on our resources and lead to
even more complexity. Consequently, we may be unable to manage our growth effectively and to detect and react to risks arising in
the course of our business. In addition, any failure to establish or maintain an effective system of internal controls over financial re-
porting could limit our ability to report our financial results accurately and in a timely manner or to detect and prevent fraud.

Any failure to effectively manage the increasing size and complexity of our business resulting from future growth and any in-
ability to adapt our accounting, our internal controls as well as our reporting and risk management procedures to our growth and the
requirements of being a public company could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, cash flows, results
of operations and prospects.
1.1.41 We may not be able to fully control some of our subsidiaries.

risk_factor: We may not be able to fully control some of our subsidiaries.

blobs.text:
In the future, we may acquire interests in entities with majority shareholders, participate in joint ventures or sell minority in-
terests in its existing or future subsidiaries. Minority shareholders in such entities may be protected by German laws or the laws of
their respective jurisdiction, including provisions requiring unanimous consent to structural changes. In addition, as insurance com-
pany we have to observe certain regulatory requirements regarding the monitoring of the governance system of our subsidiaries.
Thus, the management of subsidiaries with minority shareholders may prove difficult for us.

If we are unable to fully control our subsidiaries, this could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condi-
tion, cash flows, results of operations and prospects.
1.1.42 If we are unable to accurately assess our performance through certain key performance indicators, this may ad-

risk_factor: If we are unable to accurately assess our performance through certain key performance indicators, this may ad-versely affect our ability to determine and implement appropriate strategies.

blobs.text:
We assess our operating performance through a set of key performance indicators (“Key Performance Indicators”), including
traditional indicators such as the Combined Ratio as well as indicators to measure the degree of digitalization as for example the
proportion of online concluded contracts and applications processed in the dark. Our Key Performance Indicators may not be compa-
rable to similarly named indicators used by our competitors.

Capturing accurate data to calculate our Key Performance Indicators may be difficult, in particular due to our limited operat-
ing history. Furthermore, we obtain certain information from third-party service providers who help us assess the performance of
our business (e.g., Google Analytics). Consequently, the relevant third-party service providers may not fully disclose the methods of
how they compile such information and we cannot guarantee that such information is correct.

There is no guarantee that the information we have collected thus far is accurate or reliable. In addition, accurately tracking
cross-device journeys is particularly difficult and we therefore currently cannot fully trace customer journeys and connect them to
our own marketing efforts. As a result, our Key Performance Indicators may not reflect our actual operating or financial performance
and are not reliable indicators of our current or future revenue or profitability. Potential investors should therefore not place undue
reliance on these Key Performance Indicators in connection with an investment in the Company’s shares. The management of our
business depends on our Key Performance Indicators and other indicators derived from them, and if these are inaccurate, we may
end up making bad business and strategic decisions. Furthermore, if we report Key Performance Indicators that are significantly
wrong, investors may lose confidence in the accuracy and reliability of information we report.

The materialization of any of these risks could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, cash flows,
results of operations and prospects.

1.2.    Risks Related to Regulatory, Legal and Tax Matters

1.2.1   We are subject to legal uncertainties, resulting inter alia from the implementation of Solvency II and further chang-
        es in the existing regulatory requirements.

risk_factor: We are subject to legal uncertainties, resulting inter alia from the implementation of Solvency II and further chang-es in the existing regulatory requirements.

blobs.text:
Implementation of Solvency II led to extensive regulatory changes which forced us to adapt our business and products. We
must comply with numerous insurance rules and regulations including a number of technical regulatory and enforcement standards
developed by the European Insurance and Occupational Pensions Authority (“EIOPA”) and accepted by the European Commission.
Such statutory regulations are accompanied by BaFin guidance, interpretation decisions or circulars. In addition, EIOPA issued a
number of recommendations and guidelines at European level which BaFin largely adheres to. We incur substantial costs to remain
in compliance with applicable insurance rules and regulations. Further increase of bureaucracy and supervisory costs must be ex-
pected due to ongoing changes of regulatory law. For instance, the European Commission initiated a review of the standard form for
the calculation of solvency requirements only two years after the implementation of Solvency II. Such review shall be completed by
the end of 2018. Amendments to the standard form for example regarding the calculation of the interest-change risk can have a ma-
terial effect on our capital adequacy assessment. There is a high risk, that the current coverage ratio will no longer be achieved in the
future without contribution of own funds. Changes of the standard form could lead to significantly higher capital requirements, rat-
ing downgrades and other adverse effects.

Implementation of Solvency II came along with far reaching reporting requirements of insurance undertakings. Compliance
with such reporting requirements incurs substantial costs for us. We have implemented the respective reporting procedures and
filed the required financial reports with BaFin. In addition the solvency and financial report must be published at least on an annual

basis. We may be compared with other competitors based on the information published which might have adverse effects on our
competitive strength, share price and credit rating. Furthermore, if an important development significantly changes relevance of the
information published in the annual solvency and financial report, the insurance undertaking concerned shall publish appropriate
information on the nature and effects of the important development. This is in particular the case, if the minimum or solvency capital
requirements are not met any longer and no realistic recovery plan is provided or failure to comply with the minimum or solvency
capital requirements has not been remedied within a period of three or respectively six months. Such publications are connected
with a strong reputational risk and the risk to lose customers.

If any of the legal or regulatory risks above materializes, this could have material adverse effects on our business, financial
condition, cash flows, results of operations and prospects.
13722 £xV¥Valuation could he adversely affected hv a chanae of accountina standard:

risk_factor: Valuation could be adversely affected by a change of accounting standards.

blobs.text:
The IFRS accounting standard (IFRS4) applicable for the accounting of insurance contracts as of the date of this prospectus
will be replaced by the IFRS standard IFRS17. IFRS17 will apply for the future business years starting from or after January 1, 2021.
Changes in valuation criteria could cause changes in valuation, which would be reflected directly in our profit and loss statement.
This could cause an increase in volatility of our revenues and equity capital which could lead to various disadvantages for us. Above
all, an increase in volatility could cause an increase in the cost of capital and a corresponding decrease in the share price. Adjust-
ments with regard to the accounting of capital investments used to cover technical insurance reserves as well as adjustments in the
structure of insurance products and structuring of premiums might also be necessary. Changes in the valuation of insurance con-
tracts could also impose substantial new demands on the internal data processing and accounting systems. In addition, key numbers
in our reporting might no longer be completely comparable with the corresponding key numbers after the change is implemented.

The change of accounting standards could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, cash flows, re-
sults of operations and prospects.
1.2.3   Other developments in European and German legislation may adversely affect our business.

risk_factor: Other developments in European and German legislation may adversely affect our business.

blobs.text:
We are not only affected by financial and insurance regulation but also by many other legal provisions. Relevant provisions
are for example regulations concerning retirement pensions and social insurance systems, labor law, general civil law and insurance
contract law including rules against unfair terms and conditions, consumer protection provisions, anti-discrimination rules, the law
against unfair competition as well as rules about access to information and data protection law.

For example, we were forced to restructure our long-term care insurance portfolio. Eligible insurance products needed to be
restructured until January 1, 2017 due to the reformation of statutory long-term care insurance within the framework of the Care
Strengthening Act II. Simultaneously, we restructured our non-eligible private long-term care insurance, which triggered a significant
rate of recalls.

In general, German law strongly focuses on consumer protection. For example, various courts have interpreted insurance
contracts in manners favorable to policyholders, who has retroactively expanded the scope of coverage and benefits provided by the
insurer, or have found certain stipulations to be invalid and unenforceable. This is in particular the case, if such stipulations are based
on general terms and conditions. In light of these, certain stipulations used by us in our insurance policies might be invalid and unen-
forceable. In addition, the risk that the revocation instruction is invalid cannot be ruled out. The revocation instruction used by us
slightly differs from the one suggested in the annex to sec. 8 Insurance Contract Act (“VVG”). In case of an invalid revocation instruc-
tion, the revocation period would not commence and the right of revocation would persist. However, such risk is only relevant as far
as the daily termination right of the policyholder is excluded. In general, the insurance policies we offer provide for the right of the
policyholder to terminate the insurance contract on a daily basis. Such right is excluded in some of the policies for a period of 12
months only, if the customer has claimed insurance services within the first 24 months of the insurance contract. The right to termi-
nate insurance policies on a daily basis leads to an increased risk of mass termination e.g. due to a loss of reputation.

The new insurance distribution directive (EU) 2016/97 (“IDD“) has drawn the attention of supervisory authorities to coopera-
tion with intermediaries and the distribution of insurance products in general. We cooperate with insurance agents and brokers.
Changes regarding the law on insurance distribution might force us to restructure our distribution processes. For instance, coopera-
tion with insurance brokers regarding claims handling has lastly been subject of a judicial decision. Based on the respective judge-
ment there are uncertainties to what extent insurance brokers can be instructed with the handling of claims. Restructuring of distri-
bution processes would be connected with further costs which could be material for us. In addition we were forced to implement
new contract documentation including inter alia a product information sheet on the respective insurance product. The insurer´s or
insurance mediator´s information or advisory duties vis-à-vis the customer and any amendments thereto could require redesign of
insurance products. This is in particular the case taking into account our specific challenges to ensure adequate advice in connection
with online sales.
The rules about free access to information of public authorities bear the risk that business secrets which we are obliged to
disclose to regulatory authorities as BaFin, become public knowledge, to our detriment.

Legal risks as the ones laid out above and other legal risks, including from other areas of law could have a material adverse
effect on our business, financial condition, cash flows, results of operations and prospects.
