on our business, financial condition, cash flows, results of operations and prospects.

 1.2.4   Our digital business concept could be adversely affected by changes in European and German legislation.

risk_factor: Our digital business concept could be adversely affected by changes in European and German legislation.

blobs.text:
Our digital business model focuses on the electronic conclusion and processing of insurance contracts via our fully digitalized
IT platform. In addition, as an insurance company we are also subject to specific legal and regulatory requirements regarding IT-
systems of insurance undertakings. Changes in European and German legislation could make it more difficult or even impossible to
conclude insurance contracts on the Internet. Insurance companies are confronted with far-reaching information and documentation
obligations. If, for example, formal requirements were implemented in writing with regard to the necessary contract documents, this
would have considerable adverse effects on our digital business model. In general, the legal requirements for offering insurance con-
tracts may increase further, e.g. with regard to the obligation to advise the customer, which could make online sales more difficult or
even prohibit it. Further, changes in European and German legislation could lead to the consequence that we are no longer being
able to use certain parts of software solutions at all or in the usual way, such as the use of AI (e.g., the use of the language assistant
Alexa from Amazon). As a result, we may no longer or only partially be able to operate the automated claims and benefits process
and thus require additional personnel, which may lead to considerable higher costs.

A change in legislation could have significant adverse effects on our business, financial position, cash flows, operating results
and prospects.

1.2.5   We might be subject to stress tests and similar regulatory analyses, which might adversely affect our reputation
        and our business in general.

risk_factor: We might be subject to stress tests and similar regulatory analyses, which might adversely affect our reputationand our business in general.

blobs.text:
In order to assess the level of capital in the insurance sector, BaFin, as well as supra-national regulatory authorities such as
EIOPA periodically require solvency calculations and conduct stress test where they examine resilience of the insurance sector
against possible adverse developments. In contrast to the 2016 stress test, which focused on life insurance companies, the 2018
stress test will focus on major European insurance groups. Announcements by regulatory authorities about carrying out stress tests
or similar regulatory analyses can destabilize the insurance sector and lead to a loss of trust with regard to individual companies or
the insurance sector as a whole. In addition, if we would be part of such a stress test or any other calculations or analyses of public
authorities and our results are worse than those of our competitors and these results become known, this could adversely affect our
financing costs, customer demand for our insurance products and our reputation in general. Loss of reputation could result in cus-
tomers terminating their insurance contracts. As most of the insurance contracts underwritten by us can be terminated on a daily
basis, the risk of premium loss due to cancellations is increased. Furthermore, poor results in stress tests or similar regulatory anal-
yses could trigger regulatory measures by BaFin, which could have adverse effects for us.

If any of the risks above occurs, this could materially and adversely affect our business, results of operations and financial
condition.
1.2.6   We may lose or fail to obtain required approvals, licenses and permits.

risk_factor: We may lose or fail to obtain required approvals, licenses and permits.

blobs.text:
Our business depends on a large number of approvals, licenses and permits. For instance, primary insurance and reinsurance
companies require authorization by BaFin to carry out insurance business in Germany unless they already hold a license from anoth-
er EEA Member State. When considering applicants for an insurance license, BaFin will examine whether the organizational, financial
and other legal requirements applicable to insurance companies have been satisfied. Inter alia, managing directors, other persons
that effectively run the undertaking, board members, the actuary in charge as well as other persons responsible for key functions
must be reliable and technically suitable. We are notably dependent on our personnel. Loss of human resources could adversely af-
fect our performance. Examination by BaFin also includes a background check on shareholders with a qualifying holding (bedeutende
Beteiligung). Furthermore, applicants must submit a business plan setting out information regarding the type and scope of the pro-
posed business. In addition, applicants must demonstrate that they have adequate capitalization to support the insurance lines they
propose to write.

In addition, numerous approval requirements also exist as part of the ongoing supervision process. For example, amend-
ments to the articles of association (except those which involve a capital increase) and other material changes to the business plan
may not be put into effect unless they have been approved by BaFin.

Further approvals are required with regard to the Group Companies. The Group includes a mediation company, DFVV
Deutsche Familienversicherung-Vertriebsgesellschaft mbH, acting as insurance agent for the Group. In general insurance agents need
to be authorized by the German Chamber of Industry and Commerce and must be registered with the intermediary register accord-
ing to the German trade regulations.

If the required approvals, licenses or permits are cancelled or declined or if the Group fails to obtain or maintain the approv-
als, licenses or permits, we or if applicable our subsidiaries could be forced to discontinue our business operations. This could mate-
rially and adversely affect our or if applicable our subsidiaries business, results of operations and financial condition.

1.2.7   If we are unable to meet statutory requirements in connection with the distribution of insurance contracts, this
        might trigger regulatory measures or disputes with intermediaries or customers.

risk_factor: If we are unable to meet statutory requirements in connection with the distribution of insurance contracts, thismight trigger regulatory measures or disputes with intermediaries or customers.

blobs.text:
Our insurance products are distributed either directly by us via phone or direct response television, online via our website,
via insurance intermediaries including intermediary pools and “Assekuradeur” firms or in cooperation with cooperation partners as,
for example, the statutory health insurers Knappschaft and the insurance intermediary IG BCE Bonusagentur GmbH via its subsidiary
IG BCE Bonusassekuranz GmbH.

Before signing of the insurance contract, insurance companies and intermediaries are inter alia obliged to provide specific in-
formation in relation to the insurance undertaking as well as the particular insurance product. In addition, insurance companies and
intermediaries have to advise the potential policyholder taking into account the policyholder´s personal wishes and needs. The ad-
vice provided needs to be documented. Inadequate advice or documentation might lead to customer claims. Under certain circum-
stances, we may be liable for misconduct on the part of intermediaries in connection with the signing of an insurance contract or the
customer service and advice prior to and after signing a contract ourselves. This is in particular but not solely the case with regard to
the so called tied-agent. A tied-agent is an insurance agent, who carries on its intermediary activity solely on behalf of one or, if the
insurance products are not in competition, several insurance undertakings authorized to conduct insurance business in Germany
while the insurance undertaking or undertakings have assumed full liability from the agent resulting from its intermediary activities.
In addition, we have contractually assumed liability with regard to the mediation of our insurance policies in several agency agree-
ments. Misconduct, or alleged misconduct, by insurance intermediaries or other persons directly involved in the distribution of in-
surance contracts, could damage our reputation and lead to adverse legal or regulatory consequences such as contract termination
or damages or fines. With regard to contract termination our risk is increased due to a daily termination right stipulated in most of
the insurance contracts offered. Failure to comply with the duties laid out above by ourselves or by our intermediaries could materi-
ally and adversely affect our business, results of operations and financial condition. This is in particular the case, if such failures occur
regularly or are prominently published.

With regard to online distribution, the specific requirements in connection with the insurer´s or insurance intermediary´s du-
ty to inform and advise the customer imply legal uncertainties. For example the regional court Munich recently dealt with the ques-
tion of how the initial information pursuant to section 11 Insurance Mediation Act must be provided on an insurance intermediary´s
website. As far as we are concerned potential risks result in particular from the obligation to advise the customer. The obligation to
provide proper advice includes the obligation to identify the customers’ wishes and needs by asking the right questions. Online con-
sulting tools must comply with those requirements. The former exemption for insurance companies from the obligation to advise
customers in case of a distance contract has been abolished since 23 February 2018 in connection with the implementation of the
IDD in German law. We issue a consultation paper in order to demonstrate provision of adequate advice. However, as the consulta-
tion protocol is not individualized, evidential value of the consultation protocol could be challenged in case policyholders claim for
compensation due to inadequate advice.

We cooperate with a large number of insurance intermediaries, in particular in connection with intermediary pools operated
by DFVV Deutsche Familienversicherung Vertriebsgesellschaft mbH. Termination of a large number of agency agreements, for exam-
ple in case of a restructuring of the distribution concept, could lead to a large number of claims for compensation. However, alt-
hough direct and online distribution has increased in the last two years, cooperation with insurance intermediaries remains of special
importance for us and shall be further expanded.

As far as we cooperate with insurance brokers, such brokers have to act in the interest of the potential policyholder. Far
reaching authorities granted to the broker by us, e.g. regarding claims handling, could lead to a conflict of interest of the broker.
Such brokerage agreements would have to be terminated and we would have to provide the services as for example claims handling
either by ourselves or by another service provider. In addition, we could be subject to BaFin measurers and our reputation could be
adversely affected.

If any of the risks above occurs, this could materially and adversely affect our business, financial condition, cash flows, results
of operations and prospects.
1.2.8   We use standardized documents, which increases the impact if any clause is held to be void or information provid-

risk_factor: We use standardized documents, which increases the impact if any clause is held to be void or information provid-ed is regarded insufficient, misleading or incorrect.

blobs.text:
We offer insurance coverage which is mainly defined by standardized documents, including terms and conditions, general
customer information as well as a product information sheet. If such documents are found to contain provisions which are interpret-
ed in a manner disadvantageous to us, or if any clauses are held to be void and thus replaced by statutory provisions which are dis-
advantageous to us, a large number of our contractual relationships could be affected.

Standardized terms and conditions have to comply with the statutory laws on general terms and conditions (allgemeine
Geschäftsbedingungen). The standard is even stricter if such terms and conditions are used vis-a-vis consumers. As a general rule,
standardized terms and conditions are invalid if they are not transparent, not clearly worded, unbalanced or discriminate against the
respective other party. In addition, there have been constant changes regarding the legal framework applicable to such terms and
conditions as well as the interpretation thereof by the courts. As a result, we cannot guarantee that all standardized terms and con-
ditions we use currently comply and will continue to comply with these strict requirements. Even if terms and conditions are pre-
pared with legal advice, it is impossible for us to guarantee that they are valid, given that changes may continue to occur in the laws
applicable to such terms and conditions and/or their interpretation by the courts.

Furthermore, we issue standardized customer information and product information sheets. If the information provided is
regarded to be insufficient, misleading or incorrect a large number of contractual relationships could be affected. This is in particular
but not solely relevant with regard to the revocation instruction. The risk that the revocation instruction is invalid cannot be ruled
out. The revocation instruction used by the Company slightly differs from the one suggested in the annex to Section 8 VVG. In case of
an invalid revocation instruction, the revocation period would not commence and the right of revocation would persist.

In addition, we are legally required to issue a consultation protocol to the policyholder in order to demonstrate that the
policyholder has been duly advised when entering into the insurance contract. However, as the consultation protocol is not individu-
alized, evidential value of the consultation protocol could be challenged in case policyholders claim for compensation due to inade-
quate advice.

If clauses in our standardized documents are found to be void or information provided in such documents is insufficient,
misleading or incorrect this could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, cash flows, results of operations
and prospects.

1.2.9   Failure to comply with applicable laws, standards of conduct or accounting rules or other irregularities at ours or
        other companies in the insurance and financial service industry may adversely affect our business.

risk_factor: Failure to comply with applicable laws, standards of conduct or accounting rules or other irregularities at ours orother companies in the insurance and financial service industry may adversely affect our business.

blobs.text:
We have to comply with a large number of regulations, including numerous European regulations, provisions and standards
of conduct. Therefore, there is an inherent risk of liability due to actual or alleged violations of such norms. We have established a
comprehensive compliance program, in particular a compliance function and a compliance guideline, to minimise the risk of viola-
tions of applicable norms. However, the compliance program may fail to prevent such violations.

Special challenges arise from our digital business activities. This concerns above all data protection law. We handle person-
al and other sensitive data that is subject to rules about access to information and data protection law. Personal and other sensitive
data, including health-related data, is shared with different other persons and legal entities, such as agents, external service provid-
ers, other insurers and reinsurance companies and recognized trade, governing, and regulatory bodies. Data is collected and pro-
cessed for purposes of, inter alia insurance administration, including underwriting, claims handling, reinsurance and fraud preven-
tion. Data protection requirements have recently increased again and been of particular public interest. The European General Data
Protection Regulation (“GDPR”) and the amended German law on data protection came into force on May 25, 2018. Violations of
data protection law might lead to compensation claims of the affected persons. In addition, the GDPR imposes heavy fines in case of
a violation. Although we aim to ensure that we comply with all data protection requirements and also try to ensure that those per-
sons with whom the Company shares protected data also handle such data responsibly, it cannot be excluded that, for example due
to criminal action, protected data is made available to a third party in violation of data protection law. In addition, data protection
requirements may prevent us from offering certain customer applications such as our customer portal in the usual way or at all. This
may affect or even jeopardize our aim to become a fully digitalized insurance company.

Given our digital business model, regulations on e-commerce and the implied consumer protection provisions play a signif-
icant role for us. For example, failures to comply with technical requirements for the conclusion of the insurance contract may result
in the contract not being effectively concluded. In connection with the conclusion of the insurance contract, we further have to com-
ply with our obligations to inform and advise the client. With regard to online distribution, the specific actual requirements are not
finally determined. Therefore, there is a high risk of violations of the requirements stipulated by law. In particular system-induced
breaches of e.g. the obligation to advise the customer bear the risk of numerous customer claims. Also BaFin will keep a special eye
on digital distribution.

In addition, we may also suffer reputational risks due to actual or alleged violations of the various applicable laws. This is in
particular the case in connection with consumer protection provisions including the law on data protection, e-commerce and insur-
ance contract law. Consumer protection is subject to increased public attention while media reporting often takes a very critical view
of the insurance industry. We could suffer from negative reporting either if it is presented in a negative light itself or by being associ-
ated with a generally negative image of the insurance industry. Negative reporting on us might lead to a loss of customers and mar-
ket share, while for example questionable business practice at insurance companies in general might harm the reputation of the

nsurance

whole insurance sector. Our risk of customer loss is increased as most of the insurance contracts underwritten by us stipulate a right
to terminate the contract on a daily basis.

The occurrence of any of the risks set out above could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition,
cash flows, results of operations and prospects.
1.2.10 We may not be able to adequately protect our intellectual property against infringements from third parties.

risk_factor: We may not be able to adequately protect our intellectual property against infringements from third parties.

blobs.text:
We believe that our intellectual property (e.g., customer data, copyrights, brands, trademarks and trade secrets) is critical to
our success. In addition, we have developed, and will continue to develop, a substantial number of proprietary software, processes
and other know-how, including product-related know-how, that are of key importance to our operations. However, we may not be
able to obtain effective protection for such intellectual property or other proprietary know-how in all relevant countries. If the laws
and regulations applicable to our intellectual property change, this may make it even more difficult to protect such intellectual prop-
erty effectively.

In addition, we may be required to spend significant funds on monitoring and protecting our intellectual property and there
is no guarantee that we can successfully discover all infringements, misappropriations or other violations of our intellectual property
and pursue them successfully. We provide certain information to third-party service providers who help us assess the performance
of our business (e.g., Google Analytics). Consequently, we only have limited control to ensure that such information is not misused
by the relevant third-party service providers or passed on to other third parties, including our competitors.

If we initiate litigation against infringements of our intellectual property, such litigation may prove costly and there is no
guarantee that it will ultimately be successful and that the rulings we obtain will adequately remedy the damage we have suffered.
Where we rely on contractual agreements to protect our intellectual property, such agreements may be found to be invalid or unen-
forceable. Furthermore, some of our intellectual property could be challenged or found invalid through administrative processes or
litigation, and third parties may independently develop or otherwise acquire equivalent intellectual property.

An inability to adequately protect our intellectual property could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial
condition, cash flows, results of operations and prospects.
1.2.11 We may be accused of infringing on the intellectual property of third parties.

risk_factor: We may be accused of infringing on the intellectual property of third parties.

blobs.text:
As we utilize a variety of intellectual property for our business, customers, regulatory authorities or other third parties may
allege that intellectual property we use infringes on their intellectual property, and we may therefore become subject to allegations
and litigation against us. Even unfounded allegations of infringement may adversely affect our reputation and business and may re-
quire significant resources to defend against. If we try to obtain licenses from such third parties to settle any disputes, there is no
guarantee that such licenses will be available to us on acceptable terms, or at all, in which case we may be required to alter our
brands and change the way we operate.

Furthermore, some of the agreements we entered into with third parties may contain clauses regarding the protection of
their intellectual property licensed to us. A violation of these clauses, such as the unauthorized sub-licensing or disclosure of a confi-
dential source code, may require us to pay significant penalties, prevent us from utilizing such intellectual property in the future and
may result in litigation against us.

Any infringements on the intellectual property of third parties could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial
condition, cash flows, results of operations and prospects.
1.2.12 We may be unable to acquire, utilize and maintain our domains and trademarks.

risk_factor: We may be unable to acquire, utilize and maintain our domains and trademarks.

blobs.text:
We have registered various word and figurative trademarks as well as Internet domains and expect to register additional sim-
ilar rights in the future, in particular in connection with our private label offering. These rights are regulated by the relevant regulato-
ry bodies and subject to trademark laws and other related laws in the jurisdictions in which we have registered them. If we cannot
obtain or maintain our existing or future word and figurative trademarks as well as Internet domains on reasonable terms, we may
be forced to incur significant additional expenses or be unable to operate our business as intended. Furthermore, the regulations
governing domain names and laws protecting trademarks and similar proprietary rights could change (e.g., through the establish-
ment of additional generic or country code top level domains or changes in registration processes), which may prevent us from using
these rights as intended. In addition, we may not be able to prevent third parties from registering utilizing domains and trademarks
that interfere with those that we have registered.

An inability to maintain our domains and trademarks could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condi-
tion, cash flows, results of operations and prospects.

1.2.13 We may be adversely affected by changes in the regulations applicable to the use of the Internet and the online
       sector.

risk_factor: We may be adversely affected by changes in the regulations applicable to the use of the Internet and the onlinesector.

blobs.text:
As the Internet continues to revolutionize commercial relationships on a global scale and online penetration increases, new
laws and regulations relating to the use of the Internet in general and the e-commerce sector in particular may be adopted. These
laws and regulations may govern the collection, use and protection of data, online payments, pricing, anti-bribery, tax, country-
specific prices and website contents and other aspects relevant to our business. For example, Directive (EU) 2015/2366 of the Euro-
pean Parliament and of the Council of November 25, 2015 on payment services in the internal market, which became effective in
January 2016 and covers, inter alia, online-based payment services, provides for a uniform regulation of payments via Internet and
mobile phones and increased customer protection and requirements for user authentication. The adoption or modification of such
laws or regulations relating to our operations could adversely affect our business by increasing compliance costs, including as a result
of confidentiality or security breaches in case of noncompliance, and administrative burdens.

In particular, privacy-related regulation could interfere with our strategy to collect and use personal information as part of
our data-driven approach along the value chain. We must comply with such regulations to the extent they are applicable to us and
any noncompliance could lead to fines and other sanctions. For instance, Regulation (EU) 2016/679 of the European Parliament and
of the Council of April 27, 2016 on the protection of natural persons with regard to the processing of personal data and on the free
movement of such data (the “Data Protection Regulation”) entered into effect in May 2018 and imposes stricter limitations on the
processing, use and transmission of personal data. In case of a violation of the provisions of the Data Protection Regulation, we may
be fined for a maximum amount that corresponds to the higher of €20.0 million and 4% of our annual global turnover for the last fis-
cal year. In addition, local authorities may construe new regulations in a way that is even more restrictive and there is no guarantee
that we will be able to comply with such restrictive approaches.

Changes to the regulation applicable to the use of the Internet and the online sector could have a material adverse effect on
our business, financial condition, cash flows, results of operations and prospects.
1.2.14 We may be involved in litigation or other proceedings that could adversely affect our business.

risk_factor: We may be involved in litigation or other proceedings that could adversely affect our business.

blobs.text:
In the ordinary course of our business activities, we are regularly exposed to various litigation, particularly in the areas of
claim settlement, competition law, intellectual property disputes, labor disputes and tax matters. Such litigation is subject to inher-
ent uncertainties, and unfavorable rulings could require us to pay monetary damages or provide for an injunction prohibiting us from
performing a critical activity (e.g. marketing certain products). Even if legal claims brought against us are without merit, defending
such claims could be time-consuming and expensive, could divert management’s attention from other business concerns and we
may decide to settle such claims, which prove expensive to us.

If we become involved in litigation or other proceedings, this could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial
condition, cash flows, results of operations and prospects.

1.2.15 Our business is subject to the general tax environment in the jurisdictions in which we operate and any changes to
       this tax environment may increase our tax burden.

risk_factor: Our business is subject to the general tax environment in the jurisdictions in which we operate and any changes tothis tax environment may increase our tax burden.

blobs.text:
Our business is subject to the general tax environment in the jurisdictions in which we operate. Our ability to use tax loss car-
ryforwards and other favorable tax provisions depends on national tax laws and their interpretation in these countries. Changes in
tax legislation, administrative practices or case law could increase our tax burden and such changes might even occur retroactively.
Furthermore, tax laws may be interpreted differently by the competent tax authorities and courts, and their interpretation may
change at any time, which could lead to an increase of our tax burden. In addition, court decisions are sometimes ignored by compe-
tent tax authorities or overruled by higher courts, which could lead to higher legal and tax advisory costs and create significant un-
certainty.

The last binding tax audit of the Company took place in 2017 with respect to the audit period from January 1, 2014, until De-
cember 31, 2016. Taxes actually assessed in future tax audits for periods not yet covered by this last tax audit may exceed the taxes
already paid by us. As a result, we may be required to make significant additional tax payments with respect to previous periods. Fur-
thermore, the competent tax authorities could revise their original tax assessments (e.g., with respect to the recognition of invoiced
value added taxes). Any tax assessments that deviate from our expectations could lead to an increase in our tax burden. In addition,
we may be required to pay interest on these additional taxes as well as late filing penalties.

Changes in the tax environment and future tax audits could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condi-
tion, cash flows, results of operations and prospects.

1.3.    Risk Related to the Company’s Shareholder Structure, its Shares and the Offering

1.3.1   There is no existing market for the Shares and an active or liquid market might not develo

risk_factor: There is no existing market for the Shares and an active or liquid market might not develop.

blobs.text:
This prospectus is for the initial public offering of 3,500,000 new shares of the Company (the “Offering”). There can be no as-
surance that an active, liquid trading market for the shares will develop or be sustained following the Offering and the listing of the
shares on the regulated market segment (regulierter Markt) of the Frankfurt Stock Exchange (Frankfurter Wertpapierbörse) and,
simultaneously, on the sub-segment thereof with additional post-admission obligations (Prime Standard) of the Frankfurt Stock Ex-
change (Frankfurter Wertpapierbörse) (the “Listing”). The offer price of the new shares in the Offering will be determined and estab-
lished following a book-building procedure. The offer price determined and established in this manner may not correspond to the
price at which the shares will be traded on the Frankfurt Stock Exchange (Frankfurter Wertpapierbörse) after the Offering. Active
trading in the shares might not develop or continue after the Offering. If fewer than all shares offered hereunder are sold, the free
float and thus the liquidity of the shares after the Listing will be lower than investors may anticipate, which may have an additional
adverse effect on investors’ ability to trade the shares. Investors may not be in a position to sell their Shares quickly or at the market
price if there is no active trading in the Shares. If an active market for the shares does not develop after the Listing, the liquidity and
market price of the shares may be adversely affected which could adversely affect our prospects.

risk_factor: The Company's share price could fluctuate significantly, and investors could lose part or all of their investment inthe Company's shares.

blobs.text:
1.3.2   The Company's share price could fluctuate significantly, and investors could lose part or all of their investment in
        the Company's shares.

Following the Offering, the price of the Company’s shares will be affected by the supply and demand for the Company’s
shares, which may be influenced by numerous factors, many of which are beyond the Company’s control or can only be partly con-
trolled by the Company, including:

In addition, general market conditions and fluctuations of share prices and trading volumes, especially those of companies in
the same industry in which we operate, or general market conditions or a general downturn in worldwide or local stock markets
could lead to pressure on the Company’s share price, even though there may not be a reason for this based on our business perfor-
mance, actual results, financial condition or earnings outlook. Further, the comparatively small free float in terms of absolute num-
ber of shares may intensify these share price fluctuations. Fluctuations in the price of the Shares could themselves have a material
adverse effect on the overall price of the shares. Fluctuations could also make it more difficult for the Company to issue new shares
in the future at a time and price that the Company deems appropriate. Furthermore, investors in the secondary market may view our
business more critically than investors in the Offering, which could adversely affect the Company’s share price in the secondary mar-
ket. In addition, prices for technology companies such as the Company have traditionally been more volatile compared to share pric-
es for companies from other industries. This could adversely affect our business, financial condition, prospects and results of opera-
tions.

If the Company’s share price declines as a result of the realization of any of these risks, investors could lose part or all of their
investment in the Company’s shares.
1.3.3   The Shares may not be delivered and the transaction not consummated.

risk_factor: The Shares may not be delivered and the transaction not consummated.

blobs.text:
The underwriting agreement entered into by the Company, SK Beteiligungen GmbH and Hauck & Aufhäuser Privatbankiers
Aktiengesellschaft, Frankfurt am Main, Germany (“Hauck & Aufhäuser” or “Sole Global Coordinator”), and MainFirst Bank Aktieng-
esellschaft, Frankfurt am Main, Germany (“MainFirst” and, together with Hauck & Aufhäuser, the “Joint Bookrunners”) (the “Un-
derwriting Agreement”), provides for the obligations of the Joint Bookrunners to be subject to various conditions, including, among
other things, the conclusion of a pricing agreement and termination of the Underwriting Agreement under certain circumstances. In
the event of a non-occurrence of conditions or a termination of the Underwriting Agreement, the transaction will not be completed.
Allotments to shareholders already affected will become void. In such a case, investors have no claim to receive Shares of the Com-
pany and no such Shares will be required to be delivered. Claims for securities commissions already paid and other costs incurred by
investors in connection with their purchase are solely subject to the legal relationship between the respective investor and the insti-
tution where the purchase order was placed. Short sellers bear the risk of not being able to meet their share delivery obligations.
This could adversely affect our reputation and our ability to have a successful offering of our Shares in the future, impacting our pro-
spects, business and potentially our financial condition and results of operations.

1.3.4   Following the Offering, some of the Existing Shareholders will retain a significant interest in the Company and their
        interests may conflict with those of the Company and its other shareholders.

risk_factor: Following the Offering, some of the Existing Shareholders will retain a significant interest in the Company and theirinterests may conflict with those of the Company and its other shareholders.

blobs.text:
Following the successful completion of the Offering, SK Beteiligungen GmbH, the community of heirs (Erbengemeinschaft)
Vogel (“Community of Heirs (Erbengemeinschaft) Vogel”) and Luca Pesarini (directly and indirectly through ETHENEA Independent
Investors S.A.) (the “Major Shareholders”) will continue to hold at least 22.63%, 22.39% and 25.58%, respectively, of the Company’s
outstanding share capital (assuming placement of all New Shares) and therefore retain a majority of the votes in the Company’s
shareholders’ meeting.

The interests of the Major Shareholders may deviate from the Company’s interests or those of other shareholders. Certain
measures and transactions as well as dividend payments may be impossible to implement without the support of the Major Share-
holders. The stake of the Major Shareholders might endow it, depending on attendances at the Company’s shareholders’ meeting,
with the ability to block certain corporate measures that require the approval of the Company’s shareholders’ meeting. In addition,
the interests of the Major Shareholders may substantially deviate from, or conflict with, the Company’s interests or the interest of
the Company’s other shareholders. There is no assurance that the Major Shareholders will exercise their influence over the Company
in a way that serves the interests of the Company’s other shareholders.
The influence of the Major Shareholders may even increase if they acquire additional shares in the Company.

Conflicts between the interests of the Major Shareholders and those of the Company or its other shareholders may have
material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, cash flows, results of operations and prospects.
ea
1.3.5   The Company does not expect to pay any dividends in the foreseeable future.

risk_factor: The Company does not expect to pay any dividends in the foreseeable future.

blobs.text:
The Company has never paid any dividends and currently does not intend to pay dividends for the foreseeable future. Under
German corporate law, dividends may only be distributed from the net retained profit (Bilanzgewinn) of the Company. Furthermore,
as a result of the simplified capital reduction resolved by an extraordinary shareholders’ meeting of the Company on September 5,
2018, the net retained profit may only be distributed to the Company’s shareholders if the legal reserve and capital reserve together
have reached at least 10% of the share capital. Consequently, the Company will only be able to make dividend payments if the legal
reserve and capital reserve together have reached at least 10% of the share capital and sufficient net retained profits are available to
the Company. The net retained profit is calculated based on the Company’s unconsolidated financial statements prepared in accord-
ance with the German Commercial Code (Handelsgesetzbuch – “HGB”). Such accounting principles differ from International Financial
Reporting Standards, as adopted by the European Union (“EU”), in material respects.

The Company’s ability to pay dividends therefore largely depends upon the availability of net retained profits. Furthermore,
the continued operation and expansion of our business will require substantial funding. As a further consequence of the simplified
capital reduction, the distribution of the net retained profit is limited to a maximum of 4% of the share capital. The limitation applies
to the financial year in which the resolution on the simplified capital reduction is passed and to the two subsequent financial years.
Any determination to pay dividends in the future will be – to the extent legally permitted – at the discretion of the Management
Board and will depend upon the Company’s results of operations, financial condition, contractual restrictions, including restrictions
imposed by existing or future financing agreements, restrictions imposed by applicable laws and other factors management deems
relevant.
Consequently, the Company may not be able to pay dividends in the foreseeable future, or at all.

1.3.6   The Company may fail to comply with the additional regulatory requirements, which will be applicable to the Com-
        pany following the listing of the Company’s shares.

risk_factor: The Company may fail to comply with the additional regulatory requirements, which will be applicable to the Com-pany following the listing of the Company’s shares.

blobs.text:
Following the Listing, the Company will for the first time be subject to the legal requirements of a company listed on the reg-
ulated market (regulierter Markt) of the Frankfurt Stock Exchange (Frankfurter Wertpapierbörse) and the sub-segment of the regu-
lated market with additional post admission obligations (Prime Standard) of the Frankfurt Stock Exchange (Frankfurter Wertpa-
pierbörse). As a public company, the Company will incur significant accounting, legal and other expenses that it did not incur as a pri-
vate stock corporation. In particular, the Company will be required to issue half-year interim financial statements for the Group as
well as quarterly statements (Quartalsmitteilungen) for the first time. The Company will also incur other significant costs associated
with its compliance with the public company reporting requirements of the German Securities Trading Act (Wertpapierhandelsgesetz
– “WpHG”) (which have been partly replaced as of July 3, 2016 by the Regulation (EU) No. 596/2014 of the European Parliament and
of the Council of April 16, 2014 on market abuse (market abuse regulation) and repealing Directive No. 2003/6/EC of the European
Parliament and of the Council and Commission Directives No. 2003/124/EC, No. 2003/125/EC and No. 2004/72/EC (“Market Abuse
Regulation”), the German Stock Exchange Act (Börsengesetz) and the Stock Exchange Regulation of the Frankfurt Stock Exchange
(Börsenordnung für die Frankfurter Wertpapierbörse). Compliance with these rules and regulations will increase the Company’s legal
and financial compliance costs, introduce new costs (including stock exchange listing fees and costs related to investor relations and
shareholder reporting), and make certain activities more time-consuming and costly. They also might make it more difficult for the
Company to obtain directors and officers insurance at reasonable costs and the Company may incur substantial costs to maintain
sufficient coverage.

In addition, changing laws, regulations and standards relating to corporate governance and public disclosure are creating un-
certainty for public companies generally, increasing legal and financial compliance costs and making some activities more time con-
suming. These laws, regulations and standards are subject to varying interpretations, in many cases due to their lack of specificity,
and, as a result, their application in practice may evolve over time as new guidance is provided by regulatory and governing bodies
and the market norms and views from market participants develop over time. This could result in continuing uncertainty regarding
compliance matters and higher costs necessitated by ongoing revisions to disclosure and governance practices. The Company must
invest substantial resources to comply with evolving laws, regulations and standards, and this investment may expose the Company
to risk of fines for non-compliance or result in increased general and administrative expenses and a diversion of management’s time
and attention from income-generating activities to compliance activities or other unexpected costs. If the Company’s efforts to com-
ply with new laws, regulations and standards differ from the activities intended by regulatory or governing bodies due to ambiguities
related to their application and practice, regulatory authorities may initiate legal proceedings against us which could have an adverse
effect. We cannot predict or estimate the amount or timing of additional costs we may incur in the future to respond to these con-
tinually evolving requirements. The impact of these requirements could also make it more difficult for the Company to attract and
retain qualified persons to serve as management on its Management Board or in other senior management positions.

Furthermore, the Company might fail to establish and maintain effective systems of internal control over financial reporting
or other obligations related to the Listing. In addition, the Company has heavily relied on external advisors in preparation for the Of-
fering, and will also need to invest in external and internal resources going forward in order to comply with ongoing disclosure re-
quirements. If the Company fails to provide the necessary data or violates any other applicable rules and regulations, it might be
faced with administrative proceedings which could, among other things, result in fines being imposed on the Company and even the
revocation of the listing order by the Frankfurt Stock Exchange (Frankfurter Wertpapierbörse). Furthermore, such non-compliance
with the applicable rules and regulations would possibly damage the Company’s reputation and may affect an investment in the
Shares.

There can be no guarantee that we will be able to respond to these additional requirements without difficulties or inefficien-
cies and compliance violations could cause us to incur significant additional costs and expose us to regulatory or civil litigation or
penalties. Failure to efficiently comply with the additional requirements applicable to us following the Listing could have a material
adverse effect on our business, financial condition, cash flows, results of operations and prospects.

1.3.7   Future offerings of debt or equity securities by the Company could adversely affect the market price of the Compa-
        ny’s shares, and future issuances of shares could lead to a substantial dilution of the Company’s shareholders (i.e.,
        a reduction in the value of existing shareholders’ interests in the Company).

risk_factor: Future offerings of debt or equity securities by the Company could adversely affect the market price of the Compa-ny’s shares, and future issuances of shares could lead to a substantial dilution of the Company’s shareholders (i.e.,a reduction in the value of existing shareholders’ interests in the Company).

blobs.text:
The Company may require further capital in the future to finance its business operations, growth or to provide regulatory
capital (either to meet its current requirements or due to changes in law, interpretations of applicable laws and rules, or circum-
stances, in any case that require the Group to maintain a greater amount of regulatory capital). Therefore, the Company may seek to
raise such capital through the issuance of additional shares or debt securities with conversion rights (e.g., convertible bonds and op-
tion rights) or to implement possible future stock option or employee stock matching programs. An issuance of additional equity se-
curities or securities with a right to convert into equity, such as convertible bonds or warrant bonds, or the exercise of a stock option
or employee stock matching program could potentially affect the market price of the Company’s shares and the Company currently
cannot predict the amounts and terms of such future offerings.

If such offerings of equity or debt securities with conversion rights are made without granting subscription rights to the Com-
pany’s existing shareholders, these offerings would dilute the economic and voting rights of the Company’s existing shareholders. In
addition, such dilution may arise from the acquisition or investments in companies in exchange, fully or in part, for newly issued
shares of the Company, options granted to our business partners as well as from the exercise of stock options by our employees in
the context of future stock option programs or the issuance of shares to employees in the context of future employee participation
programs.

Even if existing shareholders were granted subscription rights, investors in certain jurisdictions may not be able to acquire or
exercise any subscription rights due to local laws. Because the timing and nature of any future offering would depend on market
conditions, it is not possible to predict or estimate the amount, timing or nature of future offerings. In addition, the acquisition of
other companies or investments in companies in exchange for newly issued shares, as well as a potential exercise of stock options
and the issuance to our employees in the context of possible future stock option or employee stock matching programs, could lead
to a dilution of the economic and voting interests of existing shareholders. Furthermore, a proposal to the Company’s shareholders’
meeting to take any of the abovementioned measures, with dilutive effects on existing shareholders, or any other announcement of
such proposal, could adversely affect the market price of the shares. Until the expiration of a period of six months following the ad-
mission of the Company’s shares to trading on the Frankfurt Stock Exchange (Frankfurter Wertpapierbörse) and for a consecutive pe-
riod of further six months without prior written consent of the Joint Bookrunners, the Company has undertaken not to offer or sell its
shares directly or indirectly, or announce such sale or take any other measures equivalent to a sale in economic terms. Nevertheless,
it cannot be guaranteed that during this period and beyond, the Company will not take such actions or propose such actions to the
Company’s shareholders’ meeting or that the market will not come to the conclusion that this will occur. This could have a material
adverse effect on the price of the Company’s shares and thus adversely affect our business, financial condition, prospects and results
of operations.

1.3.8   Future sales of shares or anticipated sales of a substantial number of shares in the Company or similar transactions
        conducted by the Major Shareholders or other groups of shareholders could adversely affect the share price.

risk_factor: Future sales of shares or anticipated sales of a substantial number of shares in the Company or similar transactionsconducted by the Major Shareholders or other groups of shareholders could adversely affect the share price.

blobs.text:
For various reasons, shareholders may sell all or some of their shares in the Company, including in order diversifying their in-
vestments. If one or more of the Company’s shareholders, in particular the Major Shareholders, were to sell a substantial number of
the Company’s shares, or if market participants believe that such sales are about to occur, the market price of the Company’s shares
as well as our ability to raise new equity financing could be adversely affected.

1.3.9   The Company may invest or spend the proceeds from the Offering in ways that shareholders may not agree with or
        in ways that may not yield a return or benefit the price of the Company’s shares.

risk_factor: The Company may invest or spend the proceeds from the Offering in ways that shareholders may not agree with orin ways that may not yield a return or benefit the price of the Company’s shares.

blobs.text:
The Company currently intends to use the net proceeds from the Offering to (i) fund additional spending for sales and mar-
keting purposes; (ii) introduce new insurance products and bundles as well as to internationalize its business; and (iii) invest in its IT
infrastructure and refine its AI platform. The Company intends to use the remainder of the net proceeds from the Offering, if any, for
general corporate purposes.

However, the Company may decide to use the net proceeds from this Offering differently from its intentions as of the date of
this Prospectus. The Company’s management will have considerable discretion in the application of such net/proceeds, and share-
holders may not be able to assess whether the proceeds are being used appropriately.

Any failure to effectively utilize the net proceeds from the Offering could have a material adverse effect on our business, fi-
nancial condition, cash flows, results of operations and prospects.

1.3.10 An investment in the Company's shares by an investor whose principal currency is not the Euro may be affected by
       exchange rate fluctuations.

risk_factor: An investment in the Company's shares by an investor whose principal currency is not the Euro may be affected byexchange rate fluctuations.

blobs.text:
The Company’s shares are, and any dividends to be paid in respect of them will be, denominated in Euros. An investment in
the Company’s shares by an investor whose principal currency is not the Euro will expose such investor to exchange rate risks. Any
depreciation of the Euro in relation to the principal currency of the respective investor will reduce the value of the investment in the
Company’s shares or any dividends in relation to such currency.

each such share with a notional value of €2.00 and with full dividend rights from January 1, 2018 (the “Offering”), consisting of:

    crease against contributions in cash (the “New Shares”) resolved by an extraordinary shareholders’ meeting of the
    Company on October 24, 2018 (the “IPO Capital Increase”);and

    teiligungen GmbH, Frankfurt am Main, Germany (the “Lending Shareholder”) in connection with a possible over-
    allotment (the “Over-Allotment Shares” and, together with the New Shares, the “Offer Shares”).

furter Wertpapierbörse) and the simultaneous admission to the sub-segment of the regulated market with additional post admission
obligations (Prime Standard) of the Frankfurt Stock Exchange (Frankfurter Wertpapierbörse), this Prospectus relates to 8,953,875 ex-
isting ordinary bearer shares of the Company and up to 3,500,000 New Shares with no-par value (Stückaktien), each such share rep-
resenting a notional value of €2.00.

Presentation of Financial Information

3.   THE OFFERING
3.1.   Subject Matter of the Offering

This Prospectus relates to the Offering of a total of 4,025,000 ordinary bearer shares of the Company with no-par value
(Stückaktien), each such share with a notional value of €2.00 and with full dividend right as of January 1, 2018, comprising:
•   3,500,000 New Shares; and
525,000 Over-Allotment Shares.

At the mid-point of the price range for the Offering within which purchase orders may be placed of €17.00 to €23.00 per Of-
fer Share (the “Price Range”), the Company will issue 3,500,000 New Shares and receive gross proceeds from the Offering in an
amount of approximately €69.4 million. The offer price for the Offering (the “Offer Price”) and the final number of Offer Shares
placed in the Offering will be determined at the end of the bookbuilding process by the Company after consultation with the Joint
Bookrunners.

The Lending Shareholder will provide Hauck & Aufhäuser, acting for the account of the Joint Bookrunners as stabilization
manager (the “Stabilization Manager”), with up to 525,000 Over-Allotment Shares in the form of a securities loan to cover potential
Over-Allotments. In connection with potential Over-Allotments, the Lending Shareholder has granted the Joint Bookrunners an op-
tion to acquire a corresponding number of existing shares of the Company at the Offer Price, less the agreed commissions (the
“Greenshoe Option”), for the sole purpose of enabling the Stabilization Manager to perform its redelivery obligation under the secu-
rities loan from the Lending Shareholder. The Greenshoe Option may only be exercised during the stabilization period and will termi-
nate 30 calendar days after commencement of stock exchange trading of the Company’s shares (i.e., December 13, 2018).

The Offering consists of (i) initial public offerings in the Germany and Luxembourg, and (ii) private placements to qualified in-
stitutional buyers in certain jurisdictions outside of Germany, Luxembourg, and the United States in reliance on Regulation S under
the Securities Act.

Immediately prior to the Offering, all of the Company’s share capital is held by the Existing Shareholders (see
“14. Shareholder Information”). Following the completion of the Offering, the Existing Shareholders will continue to hold at least
67.68% of the Company’s share capital (assuming placement of all New Shares and all Over-Allotment Shares).

The IPO Capital Increase in the amount of 3,500,000 New Shares, which was resolved by an extraordinary shareholders’
meeting of the Company on October 24, 2018, and is expected to be registered with the Commercial Register on November 13,
2018 would result in an increase of the Company’s share capital by up to €7,000,000.00. The Company’s share capital represented by
the Offer Shares that are subject of this Offering, including the Over-Allotment Shares, amounts to €8,050,000.00. Thus, approxi-
mately 45.0% of the Company’s outstanding share capital (following the registration of the IPO Capital Increase for the maximum
number of New Shares) is being offered as part of this Offering.
Hauck & Aufhäuser is acting as Sole Global Coordinator. Hauck & Aufhäuser and MainFirst are acting as Joint Bookrunners.

3.2.   Price Range, Offer Period, Offer Price and Allotment
The Price Range for the Offering within which purchase orders may be placed is €17.00 to €23.00 per Offer Share.

The period during which investors may submit purchase orders for the Offer Shares is expected to begin on October 30, 2018
and to expire on November 9, 2018 (the “Offer Period”). Offers to purchase Offer Shares may be submitted (i) until 12:00 (noon) CET
by private investors and (ii) until 1:00 p.m. CET by institutional investors on the last day of the Offer Period. Multiple purchase orders
are permitted.
Institutional investors may place subscription offers directly with the Joint Bookrunners during the Offer Period.

Private investors can make subscription offers in the Offering in Germany on the day after the beginning of the Offering
through the subscription functionality of the Frankfurt Stock Exchange (Frankfurter Wertpapierbörse) in the XETRA trading system for
the collection and settlement of subscription offers (the “Subscription Functionality”). Investors who want to submit subscription
offers for the Offer Shares through the Subscription Functionality must submit them to their respective depositary bank between
October 31, 2018 and November 9, 2018, at 12:00 (noon) CET. This requires that the depositary bank (i) has been admitted as a trad-
ing participant to the Frankfurt Stock Exchange (Frankfurter Wertpapierbörse) or has access to trading on the Frankfurt Stock Ex-
change (Frankfurter Wertpapierbörse) via an accredited trading participant; (ii) is connected to XETRA; and (iii) is authorized and able
to use the Subscription Functionality according to the Terms and Conditions of Deutsche Börse AG for use of the XETRA subscription
functionality (such depositary bank, a “Trading Participant”). The Trading Participant issues purchase orders for the investor at the
investor's request through the Subscription Functionality. Purchase order can have price limits (in 10 euro cent increments) within
the price range. In its function as order book manager, Wolfgang Steubing AG Wertpapierdienstleister (the “Order Book Manager”)
records the subscription functionality of all subscription requests of the Trading Participant in a central order book and will, at the

end of the subscription period, accept these upon instruction of the Sole Global Coordinator in full or in part or not accept these as
part of the allocation in consideration of any limits. By accepting of the subscription requests, a sale and purchase agreement for the
respective number of shares is concluded. It is subject to the condition precedent that the shares have been created or have been
provided on the settlement date of the Offering, i.e. November 15, 2018.

Investors in Luxembourg whose depositary bank is not a Trading Participant may instruct a Trading Participant via their de-
positary bank to submit a subscription offer through the Subscription Functionality and execute it after acceptance by Wolfgang
Steubing AG Wertpapierdienstleister, Frankfurt am Main, Germany, together with the depositary bank of the investor. Subscription
offers have to be made for at least 40 Offer Shares and the selected offer price has to be provided in full euro amounts and in 10 eu-
ro cent increments for each offer share. Multiple subscriptions by investors are allowed. Subscription offers can be freely revoked
until the end of the Offer Period, unless otherwise agreed individually. It is possible to withdraw from a properly made purchase until
the end of the Offer Period. Usually, even in the event of a partial or full withdrawal or reduction in a purchase offer, it will not be
necessary to reimburse overpaid amounts, since the allocation of the Offer Shares shall take place after the end of the Offer Period
by way of payment against delivery and investors therefore do not pay the offer price in advance. If, in individual cases, an investor
already paid the amounts and then withdraws its purchase offer in full or in part, or reduces its purchase offer, the paid amount will
be reimbursed to the investor immediately to the bank account used for the deposit.

Subject to the publication of a supplement to this Prospectus, if required, the Company and the Sole Global Coordinator re-
serve the right to increase or decrease the total number of Offer Shares, to increase or decrease the upper limit and/or the lower
limit of the Price Range and/or to extend or shorten the Offer Period.

Changes in the number of Offer Shares, changes to the Price Range or an extension or shortening of the Offer Period will not
invalidate any offers to purchase Offer Shares that have already been submitted. If such changes require the publication of a sup-
plement to this Prospectus, investors who submitted purchase orders prior to the publication of the supplement have the right to
withdraw these offers to purchase within two business days following the publication of such supplement (Section 16 para. 3 WpPG).
Instead of withdrawing their offers to purchase placed prior to the publication of the supplement, investors may change their orders
or place new limited or unlimited offers to purchase within two business days following the publication of the supplement.

Any changes to the terms of the Offering will be published by means of electronic media such as Reuters or Bloomberg and, if
required by Regulation (EU) no. 596/2014 of the European Parliament and of the Council of April 16, 2014 on market abuse, as
amended (“MAR”), the WpPG, or the WpHG as an ad-hoc release via an electronic information dissemination system, on the Com-
pany’s website (www.deutsche-familienversicherung.de) under the “Investor Relations” section and as a supplement to this Prospec-
tus. Investors who have submitted purchase orders will not be notified individually. Under certain conditions, the Joint Bookrunners
may terminate the underwriting agreement, entered into between the Company, the Lending Shareholder and the Joint Bookrunners
on October 26, 2018 (the “Underwriting Agreement”), even after commencement of trading (Handelsaufnahme) of the Company’s
shares on the regulated market (regulierter Markt) of the Frankfurt Stock Exchange (Frankfurter Wertpapierbörse) (see
“3.11. Admission to the Frankfurt Stock Exchange and Commencement of Trading”). Investors who engage in short-selling bear the
risk of being unable to satisfy their delivery obligations.

The Offer Price and the final number of Offer Shares placed in the Offering will be determined at the end of the bookbuilding
process by the Company after consultation with the Joint Bookrunners. The Offer Price will be set on the basis of the purchase orders
submitted by investors during the Offer Period that have been collated in the order book prepared during a bookbuilding process.
These orders will be evaluated according to the prices offered and the expected investment horizons of the respective investors. This
method of setting the number of Offer Shares that will be placed at the Offer Price is, in principle, aimed at achieving the highest Of-
fer Price. Consideration will also be given to whether the Offer Price and the number of Offer Shares to be placed allow for the rea-
sonable expectation that the share price will demonstrate a steady performance in the secondary market given the demand for the
Company’s shares as reflected in the order book. Attention will be paid not only to the prices offered by investors and the number of
investors interested in purchasing shares at a particular price, but also to the composition of the Company’s shareholder structure
that would result at a given price, and expected investor behavior. Investors will not be charged any expenses or taxes related to the
Offering by the Company, the Lending Shareholder or the Joint Bookrunners.

The Offer Price and the final number of Offer Shares placed in the Offering (i.e., the results of the Offering) are expected to
be set on November 9, 2018. After the Offer Price has been set, the Offer Shares will be allotted to investors on the basis of the pur-
chase orders then available. The Offer Price and the final number of Offer Shares (i.e., the results of the Offering) are expected to be
published on or about November 9, 2018 by means of an ad-hoc release via an electronic information dissemination system, on the
Company’s website (www.deutsche-familienversicherung.de) under the “Investor Relations” section. Investors who have placed or-
ders to purchase Offer Shares with one of the Joint Bookrunners can obtain information from that Joint Bookrunner about the Offer
Price and the number of Offer Shares allotted to them on the business day following the setting of the Offer Price. Book-entry deliv-
ery of the allotted Offer Shares against payment of the Offer Price is expected to take place one business days after commencement
of trading. Should the placement volume prove insufficient to satisfy all orders placed at the Offer Price, the Joint Bookrunners re-
serve the right to reject orders, or to only accept them in part.

  3.9.    Stabilization Measures, Over-Allotments and Greenshoe Option

In connection with the placement of the Offer Shares, Hauck & Aufhäuser, acting for the account of the Joint Bookrunners,
will act as the Stabilization Manager and may, as Stabilization Manager, make over-allotments and take stabilization measures in ac-
cordance with Articles 5 paras. 4 and 5 MAR in conjunction with Articles 5 through 8 of Commission Delegated Regulation (EU)

2016/1052 of March 8, 2016, to provide support for the market price of the Company’s shares, thus alleviating selling pressure gen-
erated by short-term investors and maintaining an orderly market in the Company’s shares.

The Stabilization Manager is under no obligation to take any stabilization measures. Therefore, no assurance can be provided
that any stabilization measures will be taken. Where stabilization measures are taken, these may be terminated at any time without
notice. Such measures may start from the date the Company’s shares commence trading on the regulated market (regulierter Markt)
of the Frankfurt Stock Exchange (Frankfurter Wertpapierbörse) and must end no later than the 30 calendar days thereafter (i.e. De-
cember 13, 2018 (the “Stabilization Period”)).

Stabilization measures are intended to provide support for the price of the Company’s shares during the Stabilization Period.
There measures may result in the market price of the Company’s shares being higher than would otherwise have been the case.
Moreover, the market price may temporarily be at an unsustainable level.

In connection with these stabilization measures, investors may, in addition to the New Shares, be allocated up to
525,000 Over-Allotment Shares as part of the allocation of the Offer Shares. For the purpose of such potential Over-Allotments, the
Stabilization Manager, acting for the account of the Joint Bookrunners, will be provided with a corresponding number of Over-
Allotment Shares from the holdings of the Lending Shareholder in the form of a securities loan. The total number of Over-Allotment
Shares will not exceed 15% of the New Shares actually placed with investors. In connection with potential Over-Allotments, the Lend-
ing Shareholder has granted the Joint Bookrunners the Greenshoe Option (i.e., an option to acquire up to 525,000 existing shares of
the Company at the Offer Price, less the agreed commissions) for the sole purpose of enabling the Stabilization Manager to perform
its redelivery obligation under the securities loan from the Lending Shareholder (such shares, “Greenshoe Shares”). The Greenshoe
Option may only be exercised during the Stabilization Period and will terminate 30 calendar days after the commencement of stock
exchange trading of the Company’s shares (i.e., December 13, 2018).

The Stabilization Manager, acting for the account of the Joint Bookrunners, is entitled to exercise the Greenshoe Option to
the extent Over-Allotment Shares were allocated to investors in the Offering. The number of Over-Allotment Shares acquired under
the Greenshoe Option is to be reduced by any shares of the Company held by the Stabilization Manager on the date when the
Greenshoe Option is exercised, if such shares were acquired by the Stabilization Manager in the context of stabilization measures.

Public announcements regarding stabilization measures will be made (i) prior to the start of the Offering, (ii) by the end of
the seventh daily trading session following the date on which any stabilization measures were taken, and (iii) within one week after
the end of the Stabilization Period.

Within one week of the end of the Stabilization Period, the Stabilization Manager will ensure adequate public disclosure as to
whether stabilization measures were taken, the date on which stabilization measures started and last occurred, and the price range
within which stabilization measures were carried out, for each of the dates during which stabilization measures were carried out and
the trading venue(s) on which the stabilization measures were carried out, where applicable.

Exercise of the Greenshoe Option will be disclosed to the public promptly, together with all appropriate details, including the
date of exercise of the Greenshoe Option and the number and nature of Over-Allotment Shares involved, in accordance with Arti-
cle 8 (f) of the Commission Delegated Regulation (EU) 2016/1052 of March 8, 2016.
