“Shareholders’ Agreement”) pursuant to which they mutually granted each other a right of first refusal (Vorkaufsrecht) for the Com-
pany’s shares held by them. If none of the aforementioned shareholders makes use of this right of first refusal or if all such share-
holders waive such right, the shares can be sold elsewhere. The Shareholders' Agreement is concluded for an indefinite period and
can be terminated for the first time ordinarily two years after the date of conclusion of the agreement by giving six months’ notice.
3.11.   Admission to the Frankfurt Stock Exchange and Commencement of Trading

The Company expects to apply for the admission of its shares to trading on the regulated market (regulierter Markt) of the
Frankfurt Stock Exchange (Frankfurter Wertpapierbörse) and, simultaneously, to the sub-segment thereof with additional post-
admission obligations (Prime Standard) on or about October 29, 2018. The listing approval (admission decision) for the Company’s
shares is expected to be granted on November 13, 2018. Trading in the Company’s shares on the Frankfurt Stock Exchange (Frankfur-
ter Wertpapierbörse) is expected to commence on November 14, 2018.
3.12.   Designated Sponsor

The Sole Global Coordinator has been mandated as designated sponsor of the Company’s shares traded on the Frankfurt
Stock Exchange (Frankfurter Wertpapierbörse). Pursuant to the designated sponsor agreement expected to be concluded between
the Sole Global Coordinator and the Company, the Sole Global Coordinator will, inter alia, place limited buy and sell orders for the
Company’s shares during regular trading hours. This is intended to achieve greater liquidity in the market for the Company’s shares.
3.13.   Interests of Parties Participating in the Offering

In connection with the Offering and the admission of the Company’ shares to trading in the Frankfurt Stock Exchange (Frank-
furter Wertpapierbörse), the Joint Bookrunners have entered into a contractual relationship with the Company and the Lending
Shareholder. The Joint Bookrunners have been appointed by the Company as Joint Bookrunners. The Joint Bookrunners are advising
the Company. The Joint Bookrunners are acting for the Company on the Offering and coordinate the structuring and execution of the
Offering. Upon successful implementation of the Offering, the Joint Bookrunners will receive a commission. As a result of these con-
tractual relationships, the Joint Bookrunners have a financial interest in the success of the Offering on the best possible term.

Furthermore, in connection with the Offering, each of the Joint Bookrunners and any of their respective affiliates, acting as
investors for their own account, may acquire Shares in the Offering and in that capacity may retain, purchase or sell for its own ac-
count such Shares or related investments and may offer or sell such Shares or other investments otherwise than in connection with
the Offering. In addition, certain of the Joint Bookrunners or their affiliates may enter into financing arrangements (including swaps
or contracts for differences) with investors in connection with which the Joint Bookrunners (or their affiliates) may from time to time
acquire, hold or dispose of Shares. None of the Joint Bookrunners intends to disclose the extent of any such investment or transac-
tions otherwise than in accordance with any legal or regulatory obligation to do so or as disclosed in the Prospectus.

Some of the Joint Bookrunners or their affiliates have, and may, from time to time, in the future continue to have, business
relations with the Company and/or the Lending Shareholder or may perform services for the Company and/or the Lending Share-
holder in the ordinary course of business.

Luca Pesarini has a controlling influence over MainFirst. Therefore, what has been said about the Joint Bookrunners’ interests
in the Offering also applies for Luca Pesarini. For further details, see “18. Certain Relationships and Related-Party Transactions”.

The Lending Shareholder will receive the proceeds, if and to the extent the Greenshoe Option is exercised, from the exercise
of the Greenshoe Option, and, therefore, the Lending Shareholder has an interest in the successful implementation of the Offering.
Assuming a full exercise of the Greenshoe Option at the mid-point of the Price Range, and after deducting fees and expenses to be
paid by the Lending Shareholder in connection with the Offering, the total net offering proceeds to the Lending Shareholder would
amount approximately to €10.0 million.
Other than the interest described above, there are no material interests, in particular no material conflicts of interest, with
respect to the Offering or the listing of the Company’s shares.

3.14.   Subscription by Existing Shareholders, members of the Management Board and Supervisory Board or other persons
        in the amount of more than 5%.

The Existing Shareholders and the members of the Management Board and Supervisory Board will not subscribe for any Offer
Shares as part of the Offering, except for such members of the Management Board which will participate in the Preferential Alloca-
tion Program. The Issuer is not aware that other persons wish to subscribe for more than 5% of the Offering.
4.   PROCEEDS OF THE OFFERING AND COSTS OF THE OFFERING AND LISTING

The Company will only receive the proceeds of the Offering resulting from the sale of the New Shares after deduction of fees
and commissions. The Lending Shareholder will receive the proceeds, if and to the extent the Greenshoe Option is exercised, from
the exercise of the Greenshoe Option.

         At the mid-point of the Price Range, the Company will issue 3,500,000 New Shares and receive gross proceeds from the Of-
fering in an amount of €69.4 million.

Assuming placement of all New Shares at the mid-point of the Price Range, and payment of the discretionary fee in full, the
costs of the Company related to the Offering and the listing of the Company’s entire share capital, including underwriting and place-
ment commissions payable to the Joint Bookrunners, are expected to total approximately €4.4 million. Thereof, €3.5 million com-
prise the commission payable to the Joint Bookrunners, including €0.3 million for the payment of the discretionary fee in full.

prise the commission payable to the Joint Bookrunners, including €0.3 million for the payment of the discretionary fee in full.

       After deduction of the costs of the Company relating to the Offering (based on the foregoing assumptions), the Company es-
timates that the total net proceeds from the placement of the New Shares would amount to approximately €65.0 million.

Investors will not be charged expenses by the Company, the Lending Shareholder or the Joint Bookrunners. Investors will
have to bear customary transaction and handling fees charged by their brokers or other financial institutions through which they
hold their securities.
5.   REASONS FOR THE OFFERING AND LISTING; USE OF PROCEEDS

The Company intends to pursue the Offering and list its shares on the regulated market (regulierter Markt) of the Frankfurt
Stock Exchange (Frankfurter Wertpapierbörse) and, simultaneously, on the sub-segment with additional post admission obligations
(Prime Standard) of the Frankfurt Stock Exchange (Frankfurter Wertpapierbörse) to receive the net proceeds from the Offering and to
gain access to the capital markets.

The Company currently intends to use the net proceeds from the Offering of approximately €65.0 million (assuming place-
ment of all New Shares at the mid-point of the Price Range, full exercise of the Preferential Allocation and payment of the discretion-
ary fee in full) in the following order:

•   approximately €46.4 million to fund additional spending for sales and marketing purposes, in particular by increasing
    advertising budgets for Google, Bing, as well as state of the art TV channels and by financing offline campaigns with
    leading German magazines;

•   approximately €9.4 million to introduce new insurance products and bundles (such as the reinvention of our property
    and accident insurance products on the basis of our 16 matrix) as well as to internationalize our business, starting in
    Benelux, France and/or Spain;

•   approximately €4.6 million for investing in our IT infrastructure, in particular by adding functionality to our core insur-
    ance platform, and refining our AI intelligence processes; and

•   approximately €4.6 million for safeguarding and matching Solvency II levels.
The Company intends to use the remainder of the net proceeds from the Offering, if any, for general corporate purposes.
6.   DIVIDEND POLICY; RESULTS AND DIVIDENDS PER SHARE; USE OF PROFITS
6.1.   General Provisions Relating to Profit Allocation and Dividend Payments

The shareholders’ share of the Company’s profits is determined based on their respective interests in the Company’s share
capital. For a stock corporation (Aktiengesellschaft) under German law, the distribution of dividends for a given fiscal year and the
amount and payment date thereof are resolved by the Company’s shareholders’ meeting (Hauptversammlung) of the subsequent
fiscal year. Proposals for the distribution of dividends will be issued by the Management Board and the Supervisory Board jointly or
by the Management Board and the Supervisory Board separately, with the shareholders’ meeting not bound by those proposals.

Dividends may only be distributed from the distributable profit (Bilanzgewinn) of the Company. The distributable profit is cal-
culated based on the Company’s unconsolidated financial statements prepared in accordance with the requirements of the HGB. Ac-
counting regulations under the HGB differ from the IFRS in material aspects.

When determining the distributable profit, net income or loss for the fiscal year (Jahresüberschuss/-fehlbetrag) must be ad-
justed for profit/loss carry-forwards (Gewinn-/Verlustvorträge) from the previous fiscal year and releases of or allocations to re-
serves. Certain reserves are required to be set up by law and amounts mandatorily allocated to these reserves in the given fiscal year
must be deducted when calculating the distributable profit.

The Management Board must prepare unconsolidated financial statements (balance sheet, income statement and notes to
the unconsolidated financial statements) and a management report for the previous fiscal year by the statutory deadline and present
these to the Supervisory Board and the auditors immediately after preparation. At the same time, the Management Board must pre-
sent to the Supervisory Board a proposal for the allocation of the Company’s distributable profits pursuant to Section 170 para. 2 of
the German Stock Corporation Act (Aktiengesetz – “AktG”). According to Section 171 AktG, the Supervisory Board must review the
unconsolidated financial statements, the Management Board’s report and the proposal for the allocation of the distributable profit
and report to the shareholders’ meeting in writing on the results of such review. The Supervisory Board must submit its report to the
Management Board within one month after the documents were received. If the Supervisory Board approves the financial state-
ments after its review, these are deemed adopted unless the Management Board and the Supervisory Board resolve to assign adop-
tion of the financial statements to the shareholders’ meeting. If the Management Board and the Supervisory Board choose to allow
the shareholders’ meeting to adopt the financial statements or if the Supervisory Board does not approve the financial statements,
the Management Board must convene a shareholders’ meeting without delay.

The shareholders’ meeting’s resolution on the allocation of the distributable profits requires a simple majority of the votes
cast. The Management Board and the Supervisory Board, in adopting the annual financial statements, may allocate an amount of up
to half of the Company’s net profit for the fiscal year to other retained earnings. In addition, pursuant to Section 23 para. 2 of the
Articles of Association, they are authorized to allocate up to 100% of the net profit for the fiscal year to other retained earnings as
long and as far as the other retained earnings do not exceed half of the registered share capital and would not exceed following such
a conversion and as far as the remaining distributable profit does not fall below 4% of the registered share capital. Additions to the
legal reserves and loss carry-forwards must be deducted in advance when calculating the amount of net income or loss for the year
to be allocated to other retained earnings. As a result of the simplified capital reduction resolved by an extraordinary shareholders’
meeting of the Company on September 5, 2018, the net retained profit may only be distributed to the Company’s shareholders if the
legal reserve and capital reserve together have reached at least 10% of the share capital. As a further consequence of the simplified
capital reduction, the distribution of the net retained profit is limited to a maximum of 4% of the share capital. The limitation applies
to the financial year in which the resolution on the simplified capital reduction is passed and to the two subsequent financial years.
Pursuant to Section 24 para. 4 of the Articles of Association, the shareholders’ meeting may also resolve to distribute the distributa-
ble profit by way of a dividend in kind in addition to or instead of a cash dividend, or it may allocate further amounts to retained
earnings or carry such amounts forward as profit in the resolution on the appropriation of the distributable profit.

Dividends resolved by the shareholders’ meeting are due and payable in compliance with the rules of the respective clearing
system on the third business day following the relevant shareholders’ meeting, unless a later due date is specified in the dividend
resolution. Clearstream Banking Aktiengesellschaft (“Clearstream”) will transfer the dividends to the shareholders’ custodian banks
for crediting to their accounts. German custodian banks are under an obligation to distribute these funds to their customers. Share-
holders using a custodian bank located outside Germany must inquire at their respective bank regarding the terms and conditions
applicable in their case. Notifications of any distribution of dividends resolved upon are published in the German Federal Gazette
(Bundesanzeiger) without undue delay after the shareholders’ meeting. To the extent dividends can be distributed by the Company
in accordance with the HGB and corresponding decisions are taken, there are no restrictions on shareholders’ rights to receive such
dividends. Any dividends not claimed within the past three years become time-barred. Once the statute of limitations applies, the
right to receive the relevant dividend payments passes to the Company.

Generally, withholding tax (Kapitalertragsteuer) is withheld from dividends paid. For further information on the taxation of
dividends in Germany, see “20.2.1 Taxation of Dividend Income”.
6.2.   Dividend Policy and Earnings per Share

We currently intend to retain all available funds and any future earnings to support operations and to finance the growth and
development of our business.

Therefore, we currently do not intend to pay dividends in the foreseeable future. Any future decision to pay dividends will be
made in accordance with applicable laws and will depend upon, inter alia, our results of operations, financial condition, contractual
restrictions and capital requirements. Our future ability to pay dividends may also be limited by the terms of our financial liabilities
or preference shares that might be issued in the future.

8.   DILUTION

As of September 30, 2018, the Group’s net book value amounted to €18.3 million, and would amount to €2.05 per share of
the Company based on 8,953,875 outstanding shares of the Company immediately prior to the Offering.

After giving effect to the issuance of the New Shares in the context of the Offering, assuming an Offer Price of €20.00 at the
mid-point of the Price Range and full exercise of the Preferential Allocation, and after subtracting the maximum estimated costs of
the Offering to be borne by the Company in the amount of €4.4 million, the equity attributable to the Company’s shareholders would
have been €83.3 million as of September 30, 2018, or €6.69 per share. That would correspond to a direct dilution of €13.31, corre-
sponding to -66.55%, per share for the parties acquiring the Offer Shares, based on 12,453,875 outstanding shares following the

9.4.   Additional Key Performance Indicators

We have included the following non-IFRS financial measures as additional key performance indicators (“Additional KPIs”).
We believe that the Additional KPIs are meaningful supplemental information for measuring the operating and financial performance
of the Group’s business for the Company’s management and investors. We believe that the Additional KPIs are useful in evaluating
the Group’s financial performance, because a number of companies, in particular companies in the insurance or InsurTech business,
also publish these figures as key performance indicators. However, the Additional KPIs are not recognized as line items under IFRS
and should not be considered as substitutes for figures on net assets, result before taxes, net earnings, cash flow from operating ac-
tivities or other income statement, cash flow or balance sheet data, as determined in accordance with IFRS, or as indicators of profit-
ability or liquidity. The Additional KPIs do not necessarily indicate whether cash flow will be sufficient or available for the Group’s
cash requirements, nor whether any such measure is indicative of the Group’s historical operating results. They are also not meant
to be indicative of future results. Because not all companies calculate these Additional KPIs in the same way, our presentation of the
Additional KPIs is not necessarily comparable with similarly-titled measures used by other companies.

HGB.

WEDDING & Cie. GmbH Wirtschaftsprüfungsgesellschaft, Börsenstraße 15, 60313 Frankfurt am Main, Germany (“WEDDING
& Cie.”), has audited in accordance with German generally accepted standards for financial statement audits the Company’s German-
language consolidated financial statements as of and for the fiscal years ended December 31, 2017, December 31, 2016 and Decem-
ber 31, 2015 and issued independent auditor’s reports thereon. The independent auditor’s reports have been issued without qualifica-
tions. TreuConsult GmbH Wirtschaftsprüfungsgesellschaft, Wintersteinstraße 15, 10587 Berlin, Germany (“TreuConsult”), has audited
in accordance with Section 317 HGB and German generally accepted standards for financial statement audits the Company’s Ger-
man-language unconsolidated financial statements as of and for the fiscal year ended December 31, 2017 and issued an independent
auditor’s report thereon. The independent auditor’s report has been issued without qualifications. The aforementioned audited con-
solidated and unconsolidated financial statements of the Company and the respective independent auditor’s reports and the Compa-
ny’s unaudited condensed consolidated interim financial statements as of and for the six months ended June 30, 2018 are included in
this Prospectus.

Where financial information in the following tables is labeled “audited”, this means that it has been taken from the audited
financial statements mentioned above. The label “unaudited” is used in the following tables to indicate financial information that has
not been taken from the audited financial statements mentioned above, but was taken either from the unaudited condensed consoli-
dated interim financial statements mentioned above, or the Company’s internal reporting system, or has been calculated based on
figures from the aforementioned sources.

All of the financial information presented in the tables and discussion below is shown in thousands of Euro (in € thousand), ex-
cept as otherwise stated. Certain financial information, including percentages, has been rounded according to established commercial
standards. Changes and percentage changes are calculated based on the rounded figures presented in this Prospectus and commer-
cially rounded to one digit after the decimal point. As a result, the aggregate amounts (sum totals or sub totals or differences or if
numbers are put in relation) may not correspond in all cases to the aggregate amounts of the underlying (unrounded) figures appear-
ing elsewhere in this Prospectus. Furthermore, these rounded figures may not add up exactly to the totals contained in the tables in
this Prospectus.

Financial information presented in parentheses denotes the negative of such number presented. In respect of financial infor-
mation set out in this Prospectus, a dash (“–”) signifies that the relevant figure is not available, while a zero (“0.0”) signifies that the
relevant figure is available but has been rounded to zero.

The following discussion and analysis should be read together with the Company’s consolidated financial statements, includ-
ing the related notes, contained in this Prospectus, and additional financial information contained elsewhere in this Prospectus, in
particular in the section “9. Selected Consolidated Financial Information”. Our historical results are not necessarily indicative of our
future results, and our interim results as of and for the six months ended June 30, 2018 are not necessarily indicative of the results
that should be expected for the full fiscal year ending December 31, 2018 or any other period.
10.1.   Overview

We are an insurance company approved by BaFin. We offer insurance cover for the health, care and accident risks of natural
persons and tangible assets owned by natural persons in Germany.

We see ourselves as the first insurer in Germany with a unique, fully digitalized platform. We started our activities in 2007.
Within eleven years, we have developed from an analogue insurance company into a profitable InsurTech company with around
420,000 existing contracts (as of June 30, 2018) as well as gross written premiums of around €71 million and an annual profit of
around €1.5 million in 2017.

We consider the development of innovative, digital solutions for supplementary dental, health and care insurance as one of
our core competencies. Since the introduction of our supplementary health insurance in 2008, we have received more than 130
awards for our products, in particular from Stiftung Warentest, whose rankings regularly place the Company at top positions. For ex-
ample, our dental supplementary insurance (Zahnzusatzversicherung), one of our main insurance products, has been honored as test
winner (Testsieger) in the ratings of Stiftung Warentest three times in a row with the top mark of 0.5 (very good) since 2014
(Source: Finanztest, issues 08/2014, 11/2016, 05/2018).

Our growing customer base and the recognition of our products by Stiftung Warentest demonstrate our competitiveness in
the already widespread insurance market. Despite our investments in our digitalization processes, we have been achieving positive
operating results for years with growing business volumes. With a solvency ratio of around 214% in 2017, we also benefit from a
good equity base compared with our competitors and measured against regulatory requirements.
10.2.   Key Factors affecting our Results of Operations

The key factors discussed below have significantly affected our business and our results of operations during the periods for
which the financial information is included in this Prospectus, and we believe that these factors will continue to affect us in the fu-
ture:
10.2.1 Digitalization

Digitalization is a major factor that has significantly affected our business and our results of operations in the recent past and
that will continue to affect us in the future.

Progressive digitalization is leading to the creation of new technologies that hold the potential for significant economic
growth affecting the insurance industry as well as any other sector. Increasingly, customers are taking out insurance online and will
continue to do so in the future. The trend towards digitalization also affects the issuance of policy and the benefit processing. Our
business model, which aims to become Germany’s first fully digitalized insurance company, is not to wait and see, but to pick up and
drive this trend forward.

During the period for which the financial information is included, we took significant steps towards implementing digitaliza-
tion. With our new accident insurance, we developed an accident product which is unique on the German market and which can be
effected easily and flexibly via our accident insurance app. Once the insurance policy has been taken out, the existing protection can
be adjusted, depending on the situation, via this app for a defined period of time, if required (e.g. during a holiday). Other people,
such as family members and friends can be included in this additional coverage at any time via this app. From the conclusion of the
contract to the situational adjustment of the insurance cover to the digitalized claims settlement and the payment processing, we
strive to implement a fully digitalized process and document chain. All necessary data will flow within the framework of complete
dark processing into our new inventory management system, which will include all operational data from 2014 onwards.

Optionally, customers can inform themselves about an insurance contract via Amazon Alexa. For payment transactions, the
stored payment data can be synchronized with a single click via Amazon Pay when our accident insurance is concluded via the app.
We measure the degree of digitalization on the basis of the following developments:

In the fiscal year 2017, 80% of applications received were processed in the dark. During the same period, the proportion of
ePolicies rose from 26% to 50% of total new policies. From the beginning of 2018, the indication of an e-mail address is a prerequisite
for the policy. As a result, the quota of ePolicies has now risen to almost 100%. Furthermore, we plan to implement the fully auto-
mated dark processing with the majority of claims and first loss events in 2019.

The implementation of digitalization has entailed enormous costs. As of December 31, 2017, the total investments into the
Company’s digitalization amounted to €11.9 million. At the same time, digitalization has significantly reduced our cost of sales. Over
the past few years, digitalization has led to a steady reduction in the number of employees and wage costs. While we employed an
average of 174 people in 2015, the average number of employees fell to 119 in 2017.

Moreover, digitalization enabled us to expand our customer base. Our online sales channel is currently our strongest sales
channel which accounts for approximately 60% of the new business.

In order to drive forward this trend towards digitalization and to implement further technically optimized and market-driven
IT solutions for the insurance industry, we continue to need considerable know-how. As the market for IT specialists is largely ex-
hausted, one of the challenges will be to attract sufficiently trained personnel.
10.2.2 Claims Development

Claims development is in general subject to external circumstances. With regard to health insurance an increased demand
for insurance benefits may result inter alia from the behavior of insured persons or care providers. Claims development in property
and casualty insurance could be affected by man-made disasters as well as natural catastrophes such as earthquakes, storm or
floods. There is a risk of particularly large individual loss events or a particularly large number of individual loss events. The claims
development in the property-casualty segment has a significant influence on our results of operations.
10.2.3 Insurance Portfolio

The continuous expansion of the insurance portfolio and the run-off of loss-making business lines such as electronics will
have a positive effect on our future results of operations.
10.2.4 Sales Channels

The maintenance and strengthening of existing sales channels as well as the identification and build-up of new sales channels
is another factor which significantly affects the Group’s results of operation.
We have incurred and will continue to incur significant expenses in sales through a
a broad range of sales channels.
10.2.5 Reinsurance
R

With reinsurance we finance premium growth and protect ourselves against major losses. In the area of growth financing, we
use proportional reinsurance agreements with reputable reinsurers with excellent credit ratings. In addition, we hedge against major
losses or an accumulation of frequency losses by means of transfer agreements. It is essential for us to come to terms with financially
strong partners in the reinsurance sector to favorable conditions. As to prevent cluster risks in this respects we tend to cooperate
with a variety of partners in this sector whose solvency we prove regularly. Our business strategy continues to be to promote our
economic growth through the use of reinsurances. This helps us in particular in the handling of major losses. However, the Company
increased its retention by terminating two major proportional reinsurance agreements. Disruptions in the reinsurance markets could
prevent us from being able to transfer underwritten risks to the extent desired or on acceptable terms. For the risks associated with
reinsurance, please see “1. Risk Factors ― Risks Related to the Company’s Business, Operations and Financial Position ―
1.1.9 Reinsurance for our insurance business might prove insufficient, or might not be available in the required scope or only on less
favorable terms in the future.”
10.2.6 Competition and Price Pressure
Competition and price pressure is another factor which significantly affects the Group’s results of operation.

The markets for insurance products are highly competitive. Our competitiveness in these markets is influenced by numerous
factors such as the Group’s financial strength, rating, experience, the quality of its client relationships, the type, scope and conditions
of its offered products and services, the efficiency of its receivables management as well as its ability to respond appropriately to
changing customer requirements.

Due to the company’s trailblazer position created by its completely digitalized approach which allows for a very lean adminis-
trative structure there is some reason to assume that the group will nevertheless endure in this harsh economic environment. First
and foremost, this approach is a reaction to the incremental trend of customers choosing their insurance with the assistance of in-
ternet-based research tools endowing them with the ability to identify the least expensive insurer very quickly. This in turn has in-
creased competition in recent years and rendered customers, especially in the property/casualty insurance business, in mature mar-
kets such as Germany increasingly price-sensitive. This is primarily due to the large number of competing insurers. Many of them are
larger than DFV in terms of gross written premium or enjoy cost advantages over DFV.
10.2.7 Inflation
Inflation is also a factor which significantly affects the Group's results of operation.

An increase in the inflation rate can ensue to decreases in the fair value of the investment portfolio of DFV and a loss of net
income, because the fair value of fixed-income securities normally decreases as the higher inflation rate causes an increase in the
market interest rate. In addition, if inflation drives up the cost of settling claims in property/casualty insurance, the technical re-
serves may not suffice to meet claim payments, which would necessitate additional provisions and reduce operating results. On the
other hand, since certain assumptions about future inflation are already factored into the actuarial bases that determine the current
premium levels, a lower-than-expected inflation rate would increase profitability in the property/accident business.
10.2.8 Macroeconomic and Demographic Trends and Developments

key_factor_affecting_results: Macroeconomic and Demographic Trends and Developments

blobs.text:
As our business activities are subject to general economic conditions prevailing in Germany, uncertainties regarding the fu-
ture economic development continue to have a significant effect on the operations of the Group. In general, the macroeconomic
conditions under which the Group operates are affecting both the demand for the Group’s insurance products and the development
of the Group’s asset portfolio as well as the fair value of its liabilities.

The demand for private supplementary health and long-term care insurance as well as property and casualty insurance is sig-
nificantly influenced by the available income of private households and their willingness and ability to invest in long-term insurance
products or to engage in economic activities that favor or necessitate the purchase of insurance coverage. If private households scale
back on their spending, this would have a broad adverse effect on the demand for insurance products — and vice versa. Economic
downturns, a high unemployment rate and/or a general reduction of the available income of private households might therefore
lead to a drop in the demand for insurance coverage as consumers might postpone the conclusion of insurance contracts or termi-

nate existing contracts, which implies an increase in the lapse rate. Such increases in lapse rates can often be observed in adverse
macroeconomic climates when private households need to free up funds to meet liquidity requirements.

       Demographic trends are another factor with major effects on the Group’s results of operation. This concerns primarily the
general trend towards increases in life expectancy due to improvements in medical care and social conditions.

On the one hand, an older policyholder is statistically more susceptible to disease. In particular, there is an increasing preva-
lence of chronic disease among an ageing population. It has been calculated that, in 2001, chronic diseases contributed approximate-
ly 46% of the global burden of disease and is expected to increase to 57% by 2020 (Source: WHO, Report 2005). This trend increases
the likelihood that the Company is obliged to pay the treatment costs within the framework of the supplementary health insurance it
offers to its policyholders. The same development applies to private supplementary care insurance, as the need for care grows with
increasing age.

On the other hand, this trend puts significant strains on statutory health insurance funds (Gesetzliche Krankenkassen). In re-
action to this, public awareness of the shortcomings of the statutory health insurance has grown, leading to an increase in demand
for private supplementary insurance products. This has proven especially beneficial to insurers offering health insurance products.
10.2.9 Legal Framework and Regulation

The Group’s operating environment is shaped to a significant extent by detailed and extensive laws and regulations, in par-
ticular rules regarding insurance regulation, social security systems, financial services, security products and transactions, insurance
contract laws, consumer protection laws, anti-discrimination laws, labor laws, antitrust laws, and tax laws (for more information see
Section “1. Risk Factors - Risks Related to Regulatory, Legal and Tax Matters” and Section “13. Regulatory and Legal Environment”).
In particular, the Company is subject to the Directive 2009/138/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council of 25 November
2009 (“Solvency II”) which has been implemented in national law entering into force on January 1, 2016. We are subject to financial
and legal supervision by BaFin. The Company must meet minimum and solvency capital requirements and establish technical provi-
sions to cover expected future claims. For this reason, it is, inter alia, required to build up sufficient financial reserves as even to deal
with risks like natural disasters or extreme turmoil at the stock market.

As part of the ongoing insurance supervision process insurance companies are subject to numerous obligations to obtain BaF-
in approvals and make submissions. For example, amendments to the articles of association (except those which involve a capital
increase) and other material changes in the business plan may not be put into effect unless they have been approved by BaFin. Cor-
respondingly, the development of our business might be limited at least in a timely manner.

We are also subject to costs associated with the introduction and implementation of new regulations. For example the im-
plementation of Solvency II in German law established inter alia far reaching reporting obligations that needed to be fulfilled by in-
surance undertakings and are associated with additional effort for the Company. Another example is the introduction of the Long-
Term Care Strengthening Act II (Pflegestärkungsgesetz II) which provides for conversion from long-term care levels to long-term care
degrees and the extension of the concept of the need for long-term care led to the corresponding conversion of the 34,581 existing
contracts for supplementary long-term care insurances.

The effect of regulation is not only limited to compliance with the relevant regulations, but it requires considerable invest-
ments in order to establish and maintain the corresponding compliance structures. This results in higher fixed costs, which can signif-
icantly affect the Group’s results of operation. In addition, if legal or regulatory regulations are amended with detrimental effect for
insurance companies, this may adversely affect our business and therefore our results of operation.

With regard to health insurance it is discussed to implement a so called citizen´s insurance in Germany which shall unite stat-
utory and private health insurance. Insurance companies offering private health insurance would be limited to supplementary health
insurance products. This limitation would also apply to a health insurance company potentially to be founded by the Company. On
the other hand, depending on the factual set-up and scope of coverage under a citizen´s insurance, we do not expect our supple-
mentary health insurance products to become less attractive to customers.
10.3.   Results of Operations

The following table shows the consolidated statement of income of the Group as of and for the fiscal years ended Decem-
ber 31, 2017, 2016 and 2015 as well as the six months ended June 30, 2018 and 2017:
10.3.1 Gross written premium
Comparison of the Six-Month Period Ended June 30, 2018 and June 30, 2017

Our gross written premium decreased from €35.9 million in the six months ended June 30, 2017 by €5.7 million (or 15.9%) to
€30.2 million in the six months ended June 30, 2018. This decrease was mainly due to a decline in premiums in household insurance
following our decision to terminate a coinsurance contract with RheinLand Versicherungen. In addition, premium income from our
discontinued electronics insurance declined as expected. Nonetheless, our core business, i.e. our private supplementary health and
long-term care insurance segment remained unaffected by this development. In the six months ended June 30, 2018, we reported in
the private supplementary health and long-term care insurance segment a premium growth of approximately 14% compared to the
six months ended June 30, 2017. In particular, this applies to our dental supplementary insurance (Zahnzusatzversicherung). Adjust-
ed for the aforementioned declines in our household and electronics insurance, the gross written premium in our other business ar-
eas grew by around 5.5% compared to the previous-year period.
Comparison of the Fiscal Years Ended December 31, 2017 and December 31, 2016

Our gross written premium increased from €64.1 million in 2016 by €6.6 million (or 10.3%) to €70.7 million in 2017. This in-
crease is mainly due to the simplification of our insurance portfolio and the introduction of the 16 matrix in 2016, with which we laid
the foundation for the digitalization of our Group, and the consequential success of our supplementary health and long-term care
insurance products. In addition, we have been offering residential building insurance since 2015, which also contributed to the signif-
icant increase in gross written premium. In the years 2015 till 2017, our deductibles remained constant at approximately 55% of our
gross written premium.
Comparison of the Fiscal Years Ended December 31, 2016 and December 31, 2015

Our gross written premiums increased from €63.2 million in 2015 by €0.9 million (or 1.4%) to €64.1 million in 2016. This in-
crease is mainly attributable to the very good acceptance by our customers of the aforementioned simplification of our insurance
portfolio. However, the increase was offset by the effects of the termination of our electronics insurance business in spring 2015,
which we decided to take due to the very negative claims experience. Since then, we have only been working with the existing port-
folio in this area.
10.3.2 Total Income
Comparison of the Six-Month Period Ended June 30, 2018 and June 30, 2017

In the six months ended June 30, 2018, our total income increased from €16.2 million in the six months ended June 30, 2017
by €0,4 million (or 2.5 %) to €16.7 million. This increase resulted mainly from the overall increase of our gross written premium.
However, the increase in total income was affected by the simultaneous decline in income from investments and other income.
Comparison of the Fiscal Years Ended December 31, 2017 and December 31, 2016

Our total income increased from €28.1 million in 2016 by €5.0 million (or 18.0%) to €33.1 million in 2017, mainly due to our
higher premium income. Further, a positive investment income of €1.1 million contributed to this positive result in 2017.
Comparison of the Fiscal Years Ended December 31, 2016 and December 31, 2015

Our total income declined from €28.4 million in 2015 by €0.3 million (or 1.0%) to €28.1 million in 2016. The decrease in total
income resulted mainly from our negative investment income in 2016.
10.3.3 Benefits paid to customers
Comparison of the Six-Month Period Ended June 30, 2018 and June 30, 2017

In the six months ended June 30, 2018, our benefits paid to customers increased from €8.8 million in the six months ended
June 30, 2017 by €1.3 million (or 14.5%) to €10.1 million. Benefits paid to customers increased with regard to our core business i.e.
our private supplementary health and long-term care insurance segment. This is mainly due to our increased actuarial reserves re-
sulting from our growing business as well as provisions effects from the revised IBNR calculation, i.e. the revision of our loss reserve
for unknown incurred but not reported losses. The increase was offset by the decrease in the loss reserves related to our closed
household insurance business, which resulted in an overall decrease in gross benefits paid to customer in the six months ended June
30, 2018 compared to the six months ended June 30, 2017. This decrease was, however, overcompensated by our reinsurance re-
sults.
Comparison of the Fiscal Years Ended December 31, 2017 and December 31, 2016

Our benefits paid to customers increased from €16.8 million in 2016 by €1.2 million (or 7.0%) to €18.0 million in 2017. The
increase is in line with the portfolio growth of the supplementary health and long-term care insurance products and the correspond-
ing increase in actuarial reserves for these products.
Comparison of the Fiscal Years Ended December 31, 2016 and December 31, 2015

Our benefits paid to customers declined from €19.3 million in 2015 by €2.5 million (or 13.0%) to €16.8 million in 2016. The
decline partly reflects the end of new business in electronics insurance in line with the reorganization of our insurance portfolio that
began in 2015 and the positive impact of the new and redesigned reinsurance coverage.
10.3.4 Operating expenses
Comparison of the Six-Month Period Ended June 30, 2018 and June 30, 2017

In the six months ended June 30, 2018, our operating expenses remained almost stable, with a declining trend compared to
the six months ended June 30, 2017. This was mainly due to cost savings resulting from the digitalization of our insurance business.
Comparison of the Fiscal Years Ended December 31, 2017 and December 31, 2016

Our operating expenses increased from €7.9 million in 2016 by €3.5 million (or 45.1%) to €11.4 million in 2017. This increase
resulted from higher acquisition costs in connection with increased new business. Additional development and service costs for the
newly established telephone sales channel in the accident insurance business also led to higher operating expenses in 2017 com-
pared to 2016.
Comparison of the Fiscal Years Ended December 31, 2016 and December 31, 2015

Our operating expenses increased from €7.7 million in 2015 by €0.2 million (or 2.0%) to €7.9 million in 2016. The slight in-
crease was mainly due to higher marketing expenses for the introduction of the “16 matrix”. The higher marketing expenses exceed-
ed the decline in acquisition and administration expenses.
10.3.5 Total expenses
Comparison of the Six-Month Period Ended June 30, 2018 and June 30, 2017
In the six months ended June 30, 2018, our total expenses increased from €15.7 million in the six months ended June 30,
2017 by €0.8 million (or 5.0%) to €16.5 million. This was mainly due to the increased benefits paid to customers.
Comparison of the Fiscal Years Ended December 31, 2017 and December 31, 2016

Our total expenses increased from €26.0 million in 2016 by €5.0 million (or 19.0%) to €31.0 million in 2017. The main driver
for the increase in total expenses was the rise in operating expenses, which accounted for 72.0% of the total increase.
Comparison of the Fiscal Years Ended December 31, 2016 and December 31, 2015

Our total expenses declined from €27.7 million in 2015 by €1.7 million (or 5.9%) to €26.0 million in 2016. The decline in total
expenses is mainly attributable to the lower benefits paid to customers.
10.3.6 Net result
Comparison of the Six-Month Period Ended June 30, 2018 and June 30, 2017

In the six months ended June 30, 2018, our net result decreased from a profit of €0.3 million in the six months ended
June 30, 2017 by €0.3 million (96.1%) to a profit of €0.0 million. This decline was mainly due to the decrease of other income by €0.3
million.
Comparison of the Fiscal Years Ended December 31, 2017 and December 31, 2016

Our net result decreased from a profit of €1.7 million in 2016 by €0.2 million (or 12.8%) to a profit of €1.5 million in 2017.
Operating profit before taxes increased slightly by 5.0% in 2017 compared with 2016. This increase was, however, offset by higher
taxes on income.
Comparison of the Fiscal Years Ended December 31, 2016 and December 31, 2015

Our net result increased from a profit of €0.9 million in 2015 by €0.8 million (or 95.7%) to a profit of €1.7 million in 2016. This
increase resulted mainly from an improved underwriting result. Higher premium income in line with lower claims expenses contrib-
uted to this strong result.
10.4.   Assets, Equity and Liabilities
1 Assets
The following tables provide an overview of our assets as of the dates presented:
10.4.1.1 Investments
Comparison of June 30, 2018 and December 31, 2017

Our investments increased from €46.4 million as of December 31, 2017 by €8.7 million (or 18.8%) to €55.1 million as of
June 30, 2018. This increase is primarily attributable to the sustained strong cash flow from operating activities, which stemmed from
both existing insurance business and new underwriting business in the first half of 2018. Supplementary health insurance contribut-
ed significantly to the growth in written premium. In contrast to this strong growth, the market value of certain fixed income securi-
ties and equities declined due to widening spreads and weaker performance of the equity markets.
Comparison of December 31, 2017 and December 31, 2016

Our investments increased from €31.7 million as of December 31, 2016 by €14.7 million (or 46.4%) to €46.4 million as of De-
cember 31, 2017, due to continued strong growth of written premium, in particular in supplementary health and long-term care in-
surance, and the corresponding growth of our underwriting provisions. Capital markets continued to be influenced by the impacts of
central bank interventions and the monetary easing policy of the European Central Bank (“ECB”). While interest rates for German

government bonds recovered from their all-time low of the previous year, they remained at a very low level. Stock markets rose sig-
nificantly compared with 2016 and reached their highest level at the beginning of the fourth quarter of 2017.
Comparison of December 31, 2016 and December 31, 2015

Our investments increased from €15.6 million as of December 31, 2015 by €16.1 million (or 103.2%) to €31.7 million as of
December 31, 2016, due to the continued growth in premiums from supplementary health insurance and long-term care insurance
which increased by €4.2 million and €1.7 million, respectively, compared with the previous year. This growth was offset by a decline
in premiums from our electronics insurance after we decided to discontinue the sale of this product and our household insurance.
Capital markets continued to be quite volatile in 2016. While the stock markets weakened in the first half of the year and performed
better towards the end of the year, the monetary policy of the ECB and the so-called “Quantitative Easing Program” led to further
interest rate cuts and spreads on 10-year German government bonds, which became negative in June 2016.
10.4.1.2 Share of Reinsurers in Underwriting Provisions
Comparison of June 30, 2018 and December 31, 2017

Share of reinsurers in underwriting provisions increased from €29.4 million as of December 31, 2017 by €2.5 million (or 8.5%)
to €31.9 million as of June 30, 2018. The overall increase is attributable to the continued accumulation of provisions in the portfolio,
primarily in the long-term care insurance, which was offset by the termination of a retrocession agreement for our household insur-
ance following the termination of the cooperation agreement with RheinLand Versicherungen.
Comparison of December 31, 2017 and December 31, 2016

Share of reinsurers in underwriting provisions increased from €20.7 million as of December 31, 2016 by €8.7 million (or
42.0%) to €29.4 million as of December 31, 2017, due to the continued accumulation of actuarial reserves in the long-term care in-
surance.
Comparison of December 31, 2016 and December 31, 2015

Share of reinsurers in underwriting provisions increased from €13.6 million as of December 31, 2015 by €7.1 million (or
52.2%) to €20.7 million as of December 31, 2016. The increase results from the increase of underwriting provisions for long-term
care, which increased by €6.5 million compared with the previous year.
10.4.1.3 Total assets
Comparison of June 30, 2018 and December 31, 2017

Total assets increased from €94.3 million as of December 31, 2017 by €14.1 million (or 14.9%) to €108.4 million as of June 30,
2018. This increase was attributable to the continued strong growth of our business resulting in an increase of our total investments
from €46.4 million by €8.7 million (or 18.8%) to €55.1 million. In addition, our receivables increased from €1.9 million by €1.9 million
(or 98.5%) to €3.8 million due to the higher receivables from reinsurers.
Comparison of December 31, 2017 and December 31, 2016

Total assets increased from €72.6 million as of December 31, 2016 by €21.7 million (or 30.0%) to €94.3 million as of Decem-
ber 31, 2017, due to the continued strong growth of our business. Total investments increased from €31.7 million by €14.7 million
(or 46.2%) to €46.4 million due to the strong cash flow from operating activities and the further increase in underwriting provisions.
The increase in underwriting business also led to an increase in the share of reinsurers in underwriting provisions from €20.7 million
by €8.7 million (or 42.2%) to €29.4 million.
Comparison of December 31, 2016 and December 31, 2015

Total assets increased from €55.4 million as of December 31, 2015 by €17.2 million (or 31.0%) to €72.6 million as of Decem-
ber 31, 2016, due to the strong growth of our business. Investments more than doubled compared with the previous year and
amounted to €31.7 million at the end of 2016 after €15.6 million in 2015. The increase in underwriting business also led to an in-
crease in the share of reinsurers in underwriting provisions from €13.6 million by €7.1 million (or 52.2%) to €20.7 million. Receivables

Qualitative and Quantitative Disclosure on Financial Risks

Our risk management includes all relevant risk types. This approach is reflected in the present report on opportunities and
risks. In general, the requirements of IFRS 4 and IFRS 7 are limited to risks resulting from insurance contracts or risks from financial
instruments and place these at the center of reporting.

We focus on an overall approach when using risk management instruments and when assessing the risk situation pursuant to
the requirements of the German Insurance Supervision Act (Versicherungsaufsichtsgesetz, VAG).
10.7.1 Risk management system

The objective of our risk management is to ensure that the obligations arising from insurance policies, and here in particular
solvency and long-term risk-bearing capacity, the creation of sufficient underwriting provisions, investment in suitable assets, com-
pliance with commercial principles, including proper business organization and compliance with the remaining financial principles of
business operations, can be fulfilled on a permanent basis for all business activities.

Risk management comprises all systematic measures to identify, evaluate and control risks. Risks and other negative devel-
opments that could have a significant impact on the net assets, financial and earnings situation are analyzed, and countermeasures
are initiated.

The implemented risk management process establishes rules for the identification, analysis and evaluation, control and mon-
itoring, reporting and communication of risks and for a central early warning system. Investments are also included in risk manage-
ment. Moreover, the risk management system includes a business continuity management system.

It is the objective of the annual risk inventory to identify risks and assess their materiality. The subject of the risk inventory is
to review and document all individual and accumulation risks. The results of the risk inventory are recorded in the risk profile.

The identified risks are assigned to risk categories. Following this categorization, the main risks are shown in this opportunity
and risk report and measures to limit them are explained. Risk exposure is generally shown as net numbers, i.e. in consideration of
the initiated or planned risk mitigation measures.

The review and assessment of risk-bearing capacity at least once per quarter also includes a review of clearly defined key fig-
ures and threshold values. Measures are initiated if a defined index value is exceeded.

The risk-bearing capacity and all material risks are finally assessed by the risk commission on a quarterly basis. The central
risk reporting system ensures transparency in reporting. Notifications of the Management Board are provided for in the event of sig-
nificant changes in risks. The risk-relevant company information is made available to the responsible supervisory bodies on a regular
basis and, if necessary, also on an ad hoc basis.

The effects on the our risk profile are already analyzed and assessed as part of the new product procedure during product
development. The impact of new business segments or the introduction of new insurance products on the overall risk profile has to
be assessed.

sessed.

  10.7.2 Governance structure

Our risk management is embedded in the business strategy as an integral component of corporate management. It builds on
the risk strategy approved by the Management Board and is based on the three interlinked functions embedded in the control and
monitoring system: operational risk management, risk monitoring and internal auditing. The control environment is completed by
the Supervisory Board and external auditors.

The guideline Risk management and ORSA (Own Risk and Solvency Assessment) documents the management of risks with
comprehensive descriptions of methods, processes and responsibilities. A basic principle of risk organization and risk management
processes is the separation of risk management and risk monitoring.
10.7.3 Operational risk management

Risk management is the operational implementation of the risk strategy in the risk-bearing business segments. The operating
segments make decisions to consciously assume or avoid risks. In this context, they have to observe the specified framework condi-
tions and risk limits. The functions of the persons responsible for establishing risk positions are separated from the subordinate areas
of risk monitoring under personnel and organizational aspects.
10.7.4 Risk monitoring

Insurance companies must have an effective risk management system that is well integrated into the organizational structure
and decision-making processes of the company, whereby reasonably considering the information needs of persons who actually
manage the company or hold key functions through appropriate internal reporting. The risk management system has to include the
strategies, processes and internal reporting procedures which are required to identify, assess, monitor and control risks to which the
company is or may be exposed and to report these risks in a meaningful manner.

A risk strategy coordinated with the management of the company, which takes the type, scope and complexity of the busi-
ness conducted and the risks associated with it into consideration, is in particular part of the strategies that is to be developed.

Due to the uncertainty of future developments, the insurance business is associated with risks. It is important to take specific
risks in the context of the existing risk-bearing capacity, if the associated opportunities promise adequate added value.
Our overall risk can be divided into the following risk categories:

•   Undertaking risks,

•   Market risks, particularly in connection with investments,

•   Credit risks, in particular from the default of receivables from insurance business,

•   Liquidity risks,
•   Operational risks,

•   Reputation risk,

•   Strategic risks.

Our risk management aims to identify, control and ultimately systematically manage these risks early on. Our Management
Board members and executives perform active risk management. The department heads report routinely to the divisional or full
Management Board in regard to the current course of business, also from a potential risk perspective. In addition, our Supervisory
Board regularly addresses risk strategy issues at its meetings and is informed by the Management Board about business develop-
ment and planning.

Our risk strategy also includes risk transfer to solvent reinsurance companies with first-class ratings via proportional risk as-
sumptions and flexibly expandable coverage for major losses and natural catastrophes as well as annually adjusted insurance cover
for loss of earnings/operating interruptions, public liability, business premises, business inventory and cyber risks.
We also implemented an internal risk and solvency assessment process (ORSA – Own Risk and Solvency Assessment) accord-

ing to the requirements of Solvency II. While each insurance company applies identical criteria for assessing a risk with the applica-
tion of the standard formula, and thus determines a Europe-wide comparable solvency capital requirement, individual company as-
sessment criteria are also used in ORSA and the individual overall solvency requirement is determined based thereon. Furthermore,
the forecast for the next three to five years runs through certain stress scenarios to ensure a stable solvency of the Group even un-
der considerable pressure.

Insurance undertakings must have an effective actuarial function (AF). At the Company, the AF has been divided according to
the insurance products by the type of damage insurance on the one hand and by the type of life insurance on the other hand and
allocated externally in each case. The AF for the classes of insurance by type of loss, in particular supplementary health products by
type of loss and personal and property insurance, such as liability, accident, glass breakage, household contents, was outsourced to
Meyerthole Siems Kohlruss Gesellschaft für aktuarielle Beratung mbH, Cologne, Germany, through a function outsourcing agreement
of October 29, 2015, for which Dr. Dietmar Kohlruss, actuary (DAV) is responsible. The AF for the classes of insurance like life insur-
ance, in particular for the supplementary products for non-substitutive health and nursing care like life insurance, was outsourced to
the actuary (DAV) Dr. Berthold Ströter from the actuarial firm Bek Ströter & Partner PartG through a function outsourcing agreement
of November 24, 2015. The outsourcing officer for the AF is the head of our actuarial department. He has many years of professional
experience as a graduate mathematician (FH) in the insurance sector and is a DAV actuary.
Insurance companies are required to have an effective internal audit function that checks the adequacy and effectiveness of

the entire business organization and in particular the internal control system.

       10.7.5 Regulatory risk-bearing capacity and underwriting risks

It is the objective of our capital management to ensure risk-bearing capacity at all times to be able to meet all obligations
from insurance contracts and to finance future growth largely independently through an appropriate equity strategy. The degree of
capitalization represents the regulatory risk-bearing capacity of DFV as a ratio of eligible own funds to the risks resulting from busi-
ness activity. The risk-bearing capacity is analyzed at least quarterly on the basis of supervisory regulations and under consideration
of internal limits.

The capital of DFV as of December 31, 2017 amounts to TEUR 21,351 and is thus TEUR 1,767 above the equity under com-
mercial law (TEUR 19,584). The valuation differences are mainly due to the non-recognition of intangible assets and valuation differ-
ences in underwriting provisions (e.g. unearned premiums, claims equalization provisions).
Regulatory risk-bearing capacity

Regulatory risk-bearing capacity is determined using the standard formula pursuant to Solvency II. Risk capital requirements
(SCR: Solvency Capital Requirement) are calculated as value-at-risk with a confidence level of 99.5%.

The regulatory risk-bearing capacity of DFV is shown as a ratio of eligible own funds to the risks resulting from business activi-
ty. The development of the regulatory risk-bearing capacity is analyzed at least quarterly.

In the fiscal year 2017, DFV meets the statutory minimum solvency requirements pursuant to Solvency II. On December 31,
2017, the provisional regulatory risk-bearing capacity of DFV was 214% (previous year 190%). As of December 31, 2017, regulatory
capital in the amount of TEUR 9,991 (previous year 6,753) was available to cover the solvency requirement of TEUR 21,351 (previous
year 12,855).
Selected underwriting risks
Appropriate calculation and underwriting policy

In general, premiums are calculated using accepted actuarial methods and include sufficient safety margins. Based thereon,
acceptance guidelines are implemented for each insured risk and their compliance is systematically monitored so that the risk of un-
derwriting losses can be limited.

The powers of attorney to enter into legally binding underwriting risks for the Company are only granted to employees who
can prove that they have the necessary professional qualification. Before it is written, every underwriting risk is subjected to an ap-
propriate and comprehensive risk assessment.

All classes of insurance offered by Deutsche Familienversicherung include in their terms the right to adjust premiums in case
of a permanent change of the calculation basis. This also limits the risk of permanent underwriting losses.
Product development

When developing new products, the needs for insurance in the target markets of Deutsche Familienversicherung are ana-
lyzed systematically and in a targeted manner to ensure that the company offers coverage concepts tailored to the needs of the
market. It is in particular ensured that the protection offered is clearly structured and can be well understood by the policyholder.
This reduces the risk that the provided insurance cover does not meet the expectation and understanding of the policyholder and
the risk of legal disputes and damage to our image is consequently kept to a minimum.
Supplementary health insurances

We offer insurance cover against financial burdens in the event of illness and the need for care. In this context, the insurance
contracts cannot be terminated by the company on a regular basis. However, the premiums of a tariff are adjusted under certain
conditions. The company therefore bears the risk of an unfavorable development of insured losses, interest, mortality, cancellation
and other expenses only until the respective next premium adjustment.

Probability tables by the Federal Financial Supervisory Authority (BaFin), the Association of Private Health Insurers (PKV) and,
if the existence of a tariff provides a sufficient basis for this, the insurer's own tables are used for the calculation of insurance premi-
ums and actuarial provisions (ageing provisions). Furthermore, the calculation considers sufficient security surcharges for fluctua-
tions below the thresholds that allow premium adjustments.

tions below the thresholds that allow premium adjustments.

       If premiums are adjusted, the company reviews all calculation bases and adjusts the premiums appropriately to the existing
circumstances at that time. This also applies to the composition of the respective inventories by gender.

A sufficiently high actuarial reserve (ageing provision) was created for the tariffs calculated like life insurance (supplementary
care insurance, inpatient treatment, daily sickness allowance).
Damage and accident insurance

We offer insurance cover for property, liability, legal protection, animal and accident insurance. Therefore, our policyholders
are protected from economic loss or damage to insured property caused by the occurrence of defined risks. We offer coverage
against claims for damages of injured third parties in form of liability insurance. Accident insurance covers personal injury resulting
from accidents.

Each contract entered into by us can be terminated without cause at the end of a defined term. The respective policyholder
has a right of termination at any time. Under certain conditions, we have extraordinary termination rights.
Premium risk

Premiums are calculated after a thorough evaluation of the relevant statistical bases according to accepted methods of prop-
erty insurance mathematics. To this end, sufficient reserves are always part of the calculation; therefore, it is unlikely that the risk
contributions to cover the losses lack detail. This counteracts the risk of underpricing. In addition, adjustment rights exist for all tar-
iffs of property/casualty insurance if the claims experience exceeds the calculated safety surcharges.
Reservation risk

The reservation risk means that the individual or lump-sum provisions are too low for subsequent claims payments. There-
fore, we use statistics from our own claims experience in conjunction with actuarial estimation methods to estimate their amount. In
addition, we limit the risks in which the reversal of these provisions is constantly monitored. The knowledge acquired in this process
is re-incorporated into the current estimates.
10.8.   Critical Accounting Estimates and Judgements in Applying Accounting Policies

The preparation of our consolidated financial statements requires management to make judgements, estimates and assump-
tions that affect the reported amounts of revenue, expenses, assets and liabilities, and the accompanying disclosures, and the disclo-
sure of contingent liabilities. Uncertainty about these assumptions and estimates could result in outcomes that require a material
adjustment to the carrying amount of the corresponding assets or liabilities in future periods.

Estimates and judgments are continually evaluated and are based on our management’s historical experience and other fac-
tors, including expectations of future events that are believed to be reasonable under the circumstances.

Judgments that have the most significant effect on the amounts recognized in the financial statements, as well as estimates
that could potentially cause a significant adjustment to the carrying amount of assets and liabilities within the next financial year are
disclosed below.
10.8.1 Other intangible assets

Other intangible assets include purchased software. Purchased software is recognized at amortized cost or manufacturing
costs. For purchased software, the acquisition costs include the purchase price and directly attributable costs to prepare the soft-
ware for its intended use. Subsequently, software is carried at acquisition cost or manufacturing costs less any accumulated amorti-
zation and impairment losses. The amortization of software is generally depreciated pro rata temporis through additions and dispos-
als of the fiscal year to other intangible assets with limited useful lives.
10.8.2 Financial instruments

Financial instruments are currently held exclusively in the category "available for sale". They are reported pursuant to IAS 39.
                                                            - 100 -
Financial instruments are initially recognized on the fulfillment date.

Generally, fair values of financial instruments are determined based on parameters that can be observed on the market. IFRS
13 defines the fair value as "sales price" (price that would be received in an ordinary transaction between market participants on the
measurement date upon sale of an asset or upon transfer of a liability). The portfolio currently consists exclusively of stock exchange-
traded financial instruments, which are valued based on current market prices.

Pursuant to IFRS 13, the method to determine the fair values results in an allocation to a specific hierarchy level. Comprehen-
sive explanations of the hierarchy levels and their underlying individual valuation procedures as well as the used calculation parame-
ters, are presented below.

The category "financial instruments available for sale" is a residual. It contains all financial instruments which, due to their
nature, do not have to be allocated to another category and for which no other option has been exercised. This item mainly shows
shares, investment shares and other shareholdings. "Financial instruments available for sale" are measured at fair value. For listed
securities, this is generally the market value.

curities, this is generally the market value.

     Changes in value resulting from the difference between fair value and amortized acquisition cost are recognized directly in
equity.

An impairment loss is recognized through profit or loss if the fair value of equity instruments in an active market is below cost
for more than six months or more than 20% on the balance sheet date. Write-ups through profit or loss of equity instruments are not
permitted. Reversals of impairment losses are recognized directly in equity.

Profits or losses on the disposal of "financial instruments available for sale" are calculated from the difference between the
proceeds from the sale and the carrying amount on the date of sale. They are reported under investment income or expenses. Profits
or losses from an interim revaluation that were initially recognized directly in equity are realized upon sale.
10.8.3 Share of reinsurers in underwriting provisions

According to IFRS, reinsurers' shares in underwriting provisions are shown under assets in the balance sheet. The correspond-
ing gross amounts have to be shown on the liabilities side. The reinsurers' shares in underwriting provisions are determined by taking
the contractual terms of the underlying reinsurance contracts into consideration.
10.8.4 Receivables

Receivables mainly include interest receivable, receivables from direct insurance business (dIB) and accounts receivable from
reinsurance business. They are reported at nominal value less payments made. Based on past experience, a standardized specific al-
lowance is made for receivables from the dIB. Credit risks are adequately taken into consideration after an individual risk assess-
ment.

For reinsurance, allowances are made on a strict case-by-case basis. Write-offs through profit and loss are generally only
made in case of insolvency. Based on past experience no further allowances are made, even with regard to essential items.

In the Group, allowances through profit and loss are made and reduce the premium income and the book value of the re-
ceivables. If fair values of receivables are to be determined for the required disclosures in the notes, it is assumed pursuant to
IFRS 7.29 (a) that the carrying amount represents the best approximate value. According to the regulations of IFRS 13, this results in
an allocation of these fair values to hierarchy level 3.
10.8.5 Deferred tax assets

Deferred tax assets have to be recognized in accordance with IAS 12 if asset items in the consolidated balance sheet are to be
valued lower or liability items higher than in the tax balance sheet of the relevant Group company and these differences balance out
in the future with effect on taxes (temporary differences). If the temporary differences are recognized in profit or loss, the deferred
taxes are recognized in profit or loss; if they are recognized in equity, the related deferred taxes are also recognized directly in equi-
ty. In addition, deferred tax assets are formed for unused tax loss carryforwards and certain consolidation procedures. Deferred tax-
es are calculated using the individual corporate tax rates of the respective Group companies. For this purpose, changes in tax rates
already decided on the balance sheet date are taken into consideration. If a realization of the respective deferred tax refund claim is
not likely, the deferred tax assets is value adjusted.
10.8.6 Other assets

Other assets include operating and office equipment, prepaid expenses, inventories and sundry assets.

       Operating and office equipment is recognized at cost less accumulated depreciation and impairment losses. The straight-line
depreciation is based on expected useful lives of between three and five years.

A collective item is created for assets with acquisition values between EUR 150 and EUR 1,000 net. This collective item in-
cludes all assets acquired in a fiscal year within the stated value limits. It is depreciated over a period of five years, beginning in the
year of formation.
Prepaid expenses are stated at nominal values on a
a pro rata basis.

Inventories mainly include advertising material and office supplies. Inventories are measured at the lower value of acquisi-
tion or manufacturing costs and net realizable value. Any necessary allowances and reversals of impairment losses are recognized in
the income statement.Underwriting provisions (gross)
