11. MARKETS AND COMPETITION
11.1.   Overview of our Markets

As insurer we are exclusively active on the German market. Our range of services is mainly directed at individuals and families
as potential policyholders. The insurances we offer are devoid of any unnecessary add-ons whose prime purpose is merely to inflate
the insurance fee and are either tendered in combination (Kombiversicherung) or individually (Einzelversicherung). Though the Ger-
man insurance market has often been described as being saturated and not easy to penetrate for new market participants, we
earned in 2017, the tenth year of our group’s existence, already €71 million in gross contributions as defined in Section 36 Ordinance
regarding the Accounting System for Banks (Versicherungsunternehmens-Rechnungslegungsverordnung – “RechVersV”) (gebuchte
Bruttobeiträge) in 2017 and achieved thereby a 10.3% surplus in comparison to the previous business year . We believe that our suc-
cess can be attributed to the fact that we effectively combine the business model of a direct insurer (Direktversicherer) with the us-
age of digital technology and thus assume to be the first fully operational completely digitalized insurance company. In contrast to
mere online broker platforms, we sell our own insurance services, primarily consisting of supplementary health insurances and prop-
erty-casualty insurance.
11.2.   Macroeconomic Framework Conditions

The International Monetary Fund (“IMF”) expects global economy to grow by 3,9% in 2018 and 2019. The German gross do-
mestic product (“GDP”) shall grow by 2.2%. This forecast covers already the contingent negative effects of the tariff war commenced
by the current US administration as well as the Brexit negotiations (Source: CNBC, Press Report). The positive German economic con-
dition is likewise driven by its strong export industry as well as rising domestic consumption. In the long run, the German market will
be significantly shaped by its aging population. Its future economic growth will in the view of the IMF to a great deal hinge on the
question whether Germany will be able to adjust its infrastructure to this prognosis. This demographic situation will also affect the
insurance market as it already strains the statutory social security system and thereby generates an awareness to enter into supple-
mentary insurances. According to GDV surveys, the positive macroeconomic development also ensued to a stronger increase in pre-
mium income in the insurance industry in 2017 than in the previous year. Last year, German insurers recorded an increase in premi-
um income of 1.7% to €197.7 billion while in 2016 there was only an increase of 0,28% (Source: GDV, Statement).
11.3.   Insurance Market in Germany

The German insurance sector is traditionally shaped by a variety of insurers of different legal and organizational forms, busi-
ness strategies and target groups. The spectrum ranges from insurance groups with a global stance to regional insurers, from insur-
ances incorporated as stock corporation (Aktiengesellschaften) to insurance associations (Versicherungsvereine) to public insurers
(öffentlich-rechtlichen Versicherer), from providers of an entire product range to specialist insurers. These various insurers are in in-
tense competition. As a high economic and social significance is attributed to them insurance markets are traditionally amongst the
most heavily state-regulated markets. In Germany, there are currently 85 life insurers, 46 health insurers and 201 property-casualty
insurers operating under the supervision of the BaFin. In addition, eight public insurers (two life insurers and six property-casualty
insurers) are under supervision of federal states (Bundesländer). Approximately 3/4 of these individual insurers are part of a German
insurance group with several primary insurers. Thus, 264 individual companies together form 62 insurance groups. 76 individual
companies have no ties to a German insurance group and thus operate independently in the German market (Source: Company da-
tabase of BaFin, March 2018, p. 10). Compared to the other European states, the German market is rather diversified. Admittedly,
large insurance markets tend to have a lower market concentration than smaller markets such as the Scandinavian countries. How-
ever, the market concentration in Germany is also significantly lower than in France and Italy (Source: GDV, Analysis 2018, p. 10).

There is no trend towards market consolidation. Rather, the market has remained almost stable over the last few years
(Source: GDV, Analysis 2018, p. 10). In the main, consolidation in the insurance market is achieved by takeovers. In the 1990s and
around the turn of the millennium, a number of such transactions shaped the German insurance market. Currently, M&A activity on
the German insurance market is on a low level and limited to smaller companies (Source: GDV, Analysis 2018, p. 11).

Additionally, insolvencies play no role in market cleansing for the insurance industry. Usually, market withdrawals due to the
insolvency of unsuccessful companies are essential for market consolidation in other sectors. Yet, they are very rare in the insurance
industry. This can be attributed to the very high statutory safety requirements placed on insurers regarding their financial reserves
and their constant observation by the BaFin. Thus, in the last ten years there have only been two cases in which very small proper-
ty/casualty insurers went bankrupt. One of these cases was an independent new company founded by foreign investors in 2009,
which proved to be unable to establish itself permanently in the market (Source: GDV, Analysis 2018, p. 14).
11.3.1 Private Supplementary Health and Long-Term Care Insurance:

In Germany, certain insurances are mandatory, in particular health and long-term care insurance (Gesundheits- und
Pflegeversicherung). Principally, it is prescribed to take out a statutory insurance (Gesetzliche Krankenversicherung). An employed
customer is only free to decide for a private health insurance instead when its annual gross income amounts to €53,100 (“Income
Threshold”, Beitragsbemessungsgrenze). In an attempt to cope with salary increases and to enlarge the number of contributors the
income threshold is regularly raised. Additionally, self-employed persons and freelancers, civil servants, students and persons with-
out own income can decide for a private health insurance.

The statutory health insurance provides only for a limited treatment catalogue (Begrenzter Behandlungskatalog). The same
applies for the long-term care insurances where the customer is only entitled to limited subsidies measured by the amount of care
required, which is categorized into degrees of care (Pflegegrade). The only way to improve the quality of treatment or care the policy
holder receives is to enter a supplementary insurance. Statutorily insured persons are the primary target group of our dental, outpa-
tient and inpatient insurances. Thus, the aforementioned increases of the income threshold will not adversely affect our economic
standing in this business line but improve it. Moreover, the statutory health insurances are forbidden to offer own supplementary
health insurance policies. Rather, they are allowed to broker insurances of this kind offered by private health insurers. The coopera-
tion between us and various statutory health insurances, like Knappschaft and the insurance intermediary IG BCE Bonusagentur
GmbH (“IG BCE Bonusagentur”) with its subsidiary IG BCE Bonusassekuranz GmbH (“IG BCE Bonusassekuranz”) marks a significant
example for this. Since 2000, the number of people insured in the state healthcare-system entering supplementary health care in-
surances has almost doubled. In 2017, the number of customers with a supplementary health care insurance amounted to more than
25.5 million customers. Since end of 2016, approximately 400,000 more policyholders have found themselves willing to take out this
type of insurance. We could directly benefit from this increase as 39,522 new contracts for supplementary health care were conclud-
ed in 2017. This marks an increase of 14.4% and overall 314,095 insurance policies in this department (Source: GDV Textbook, p. 53).
11.3.2 Property and Casualty Insurance

Property and casualty insurances are principally not mandatory in Germany. The main exception in this regard is automotive
insurance which applies to all vehicle owners and which we have not covered in our range of services. Thus, all the insurances of-
fered by us in this area have a more supplementary nature and are not perceived as existential though they might absolutely pre-
serve the customer from existential risks. However, this is not detrimental to the online sales we prefer. Insurance policies have a
reputation for being complicated products. The more important the insurance is considered, the sooner the customer also wants a
more personal service which online distribution is not designed for (Source: GDV, Analysis 2018, p. 19).

Related to the entire German market, the premiums for property insurances rose weaker than in the previous year by 3%
(+4.1%) to €19.3 billion (previous year €18.7 billion). With a growth of 4.5%, the private property lines of business had the largest
share of the non-private property insurance with 1.3% (Source: Ergo Financial Statements, p.13).

The slump in contributions we have experienced since then can mainly be attributed to the discontinuation of the unprofita-
ble engineering insurance (Technikversicherung). Yet, the remaining services we offer in this segment develop differently.

While we were able to record an increase in gross contributions from approximately €823,000 to approximately €850,000 for
legal protection insurance, there was a significant drop for liability insurance in the same period from approximately €1,679,800 to
approximately €1,248400. By contrast, there was an increase in both areas throughout the German insurance market. In general,
liability insurance, premiums grew by approximately 1.5% to €7.8 billion (previous year: €7.6 billion). In legal protection insurance,
premium income rose by 4% to €4 billion (previous year €3.8 billion) (Source: Ergo Financial Statements, p. 14). This evidences that
the market is far from satiated, but experiences fierce competition and that we will be able to regain customers when we adjust our
insurance conditions accordingly.

For the areas in which we offer property and casualty insurance, 97.5 million insurance policies were held throughout Ger-
many in 2016 and gross contributions amounting to €17.107 billion were collected. In our opinion, however, the market potential for
these insurances is by no means exhausted. We still see opportunities here in the target group of 20- to 60-year-olds, since more
than 40.5 million potential customers of this target group have not yet taken out at least one of the property and accident insurance
policies we offer. In our estimate, there is only 30% market coverage for accident insurance.
InsurTech

In its analysis for the German insurance market the GDV deems it possible that new access routes to insurance (smart
phones, apps) could increase insurance demand. After all, they do not only facilitate access to traditional insurance products. They
also enable customers to take out additional risk protection – by taking out short-term insurance (e.g. during skiing holidays) or
booking additional protection modules for existing insurance contracts (e.g. third-party driver protection in motor insurance). The
possibility of taking out insurance cover as an "add-on" when purchasing other products and services (e.g. electronic devices, travel
bookings) is also playing an increasing role. An increasing proportion of customers' insurance contracts could be concluded via Inter-
net platforms in the future. Against the backdrop of their experience with digital services and their digital lifestyle, the younger gen-
eration of digital natives and online affine customers of all other age groups have new expectations of insurers, for example with re-
gard to communication channels, accessibility and reactivity. Digital access channels are becoming increasingly important. The major-
ity of the population now uses the Internet for information on insurance topics (Source: GDV, Analysis 2018, p. 18).

In addition, to the already established insurers new competitors want to embark on this trend by offering completely digital-
ized solutions and in so far emulating our business model. Most of these providers are only broker platforms like Clark Germany or
Getsafe Digital GmbH. Other competitors tender own insurances like Element Insurance AG and One Versicherer AG offering house-
hold insurance and liability insurance. Copy AG and Neodigital Versicherung AG tender accident and casualty insurances. Thus, there

is only a partial overlap between the offers of these companies and the range of services we can provide. In particular, there is no
intersection with our main pillar, the supplementary health care insurance. Only Ottonova presents an exception in this regard as
this Insurtech company offers such supplementary insurance as well as private health insurance. Yet, this competitor obtained its
license to enter the insurance market in 2017. Its customer’s base does not exceed 200 persons (Source: Ottonova, Press Report) and
it will require considerable time and investments till Ottonova will be established as reliable brand on the market with the ability to
attract customers in a greater number. Until then, it will have to keep up its business in view of the high fixed costs which are caused
by the strict regulation shaping the insurance market. Principally, this applies to most of the aforementioned Insurtech companies
who were granted a license to offer insurances in 2017 or 2018. They all start now where we began ten years ago.

Our head start position regarding Insurtech is reflected by the anticipatory technological decisions we have made. For in-
stance, when we introduced a new inventory control system (Bestandsführungssystem) we abandoned batch processing which is
common in the insurance industry. Instead, we decided for an event-based process. This means that all changes and adjustments to
insurance contracts can be processed in real time. Without this real-time processing, situational accident insurance, where the mar-
ket trend is heading to, would not be possible either. In this case, the policyholder must receive confirmation of his increased insur-
ance cover in real time.
11.5.   Competition
11.5.1 Main Competitors

The market for online insurance products is highly competitive, fragmented and rapidly changing. We face competition from
a diversified group of competitors operating under various brands. The competitors we face differ between our geographic markets
as well as different product categories and include:

We consider, however, ERGO Direkt Versicherung AG and ERGO Direkt Krankenversicherung AG (“Ergo”) as well as
HanseMerkur Allgemeine Versicherung AG and its subsidiary HanseMerkur as our main competitors.

These competitors and other established insurance companies use a variety of distribution channels to come to terms with
new customers. These encompass in particular branch offices, networks of brokers and salesmen, online platforms, direct insurances
and cooperation with statutory health care companies or other corporations. Though, we also utilize some of these channels with
the exception of branch offices approximately 60% of our customers are reached online. Thus, we regard this as the focal point of
our distribution. This arrangement is also adopted by other direct insurers (Direktversicherer). The current market leader in this area
is Huk 24 AG achieving gross contributions in the amount of €803,3 million. Yet, it is no direct competitor of the Company as the
gross of its earnings stems from automotive insurance (KFZ-Versicherung). This is a market we even do not intent to enter. Only ap-
proximately 12% of its gross contributions in 2017 derive from activities where a competitive overlap with DFV can be noticed,
namely property and casualty insurance while our business focusses primarily on supplementary health insurance. This marks also a
difference to competitors like Verti or Ergo Direct. Pursuant to their respective financial statements, both insurances providers are
focused on automotive and accident insurance. The business concept of Europa concentrates mainly on life insurances. Yet, WGV
Versicherungen a. G. is tendering supplementary health insurance to its customers, but has opened an array of service centers in
North Rhine-Westphalia as well as Southern and Eastern Germany and thereby abandoned the advantages of the business concept
as pure direct insurer which is our preferred way to attract new customers.

For further information on our competition, please also see “1. Risk Factors―1.1. Risks Related to the Company’s Business,
Operations and Financial Position ― We face intense competition from traditional insurer as well as other online insurer, which may
intensify even further.” above.
11.5.2 Prospect of competition

Overall, we believe that our competitive prospect can be described as auspicious. Our business activities are characterized by
our lean corporate structure which enables us to rapidly adapt to the changes of our market in which we operate. In contrast to
some of our competitor, we have always reacted swiftly when conspicuous or even detrimental developments have occurred. A
striking example in this regard might be the discontinuation of the unprofitable engineering insurance. This ability is enhanced by the
management focused governance of our company. As we are not part of a group we can use all the generated profits for invest-
ments in our own business model or the benefit of our shareholders and we are also not under the obligation to cross subsidize oth-
er departments or companies of the group.

In contrast, to the recently founded InsurTech companies, we can fairly assume to have achieved a significantly stronger
market position as our customer base is broader and our technological and economic comprehension of the insurance market is nat-
urally more evolved. We have an already proven ability to withstand the market forces and to grow nonetheless. Thus, we represent
a reliable and respectable partner for new customers with an already established brand.

Nonetheless, it is sometimes maintained that due to the special intangible nature of insurance products and the sometimes
high complexity of insurance decisions, customer confidence in an insurance’s reputation will remain central, especially in the insur-
ance of existential risks. Additionally, the future market development will also reflect that the new digital possibilities will find very
different acceptance in society. Over the next 10 to 15 years, the insurance business will continue to be strongly influenced by cus-
tomers who are not digital natives. Their willingness to take out an existentially important insurance policy online with a minimum of
advice is probably not very pronounced. The range of services we offer does not include such insurances. It focusses very deliberate-
ly on supplementary insurances where cost efficiency and rapidity is of greater significance. Thus, we are even able to cope with the
consumer habits of the older generations. This ability is enhanced by our cooperation with various statutory health insurances.

Another cause for optimism is delivered by GDV deeming it possible that new types of insurers, whose business models are
adapted to the new conditions of digitalization, will achieve a dominant market position. Conclusively, we are in a "pole position" to
shape the insurance market of the future (Source: GDV, Analysis 2018, p. 18).
12. BUSINESS
12.1.   Overview

We are an insurance company approved by BaFin. We offer insurance cover for the health, care and accident risks of natural
ersons and tangible assets owned by natural persons in Germany.

description_of_the_business: We are an insurance company approved by BaFin. We offer insurance cover for the health, care and accident risks of naturalpersons and tangible assets owned by natural persons in Germany.

blobs.text: pe

We see ourselves as the first insurer in Germany with a unique, fully digitalized platform. We started our activities in 2007.
Within eleven years, we have developed from an analogue insurance company into a profitable InsurTech company with around
420,000 existing contracts (as of June 30, 2018) as well as gross written premiums of around €71 million and an annual profit of
around €1.5 million in 2017.

We consider the development of innovative, digital solutions for supplementary dental, health and care insurance as one of
our core competencies. Since the introduction of our supplementary health insurance in 2008, we have received more than 130
awards for our products, in particular from Stiftung Warentest, whose rankings regularly place the Company at top positions. For ex-
ample, our dental supplementary insurance (Zahnzusatzversicherung), one of our main insurance products, has been honored as test
winner (Testsieger) in the ratings of Stiftung Warentest three times in a row with the top mark of 0.5 (very good) since 2014
(Source: Finanztest, issues 08/2014, 11/2016, 05/2018).

Our growing customer base and the recognition of our products by Stiftung Warentest demonstrate our competitiveness in
the already widespread insurance market. Despite our investments in our digitalization processes, we have been achieving positive
operating results for years with growing business volumes. With a solvency ratio of around 214% in 2017, we also benefit from a
good equity base compared with our competitors and measured against regulatory requirements.
We are active in the following segments and business areas:

•   Private supplementary health and long-term care insurance. With our private supplementary health and long-term
    care insurance, we offer our customers insurance protection against financial losses in the event of illness and the
    need for care. The private supplementary health and long-term care insurance covers benefits for the policyholder
    that are not covered by the statutory and private health and long-term care insurance. We differentiate between
    supplementary health insurance operated by type of life insurance (from supplementary long-term care insurance,
    funded long-term care insurance, supplementary insurance for inpatient medical treatment up to daily sickness al-
    lowance insurance) and supplementary health insurance operated by type of property insurance (from supplemen-
    tary dental insurance for dentures and dental preservation via supplementary insurance for outpatient medical
    treatment up to health insurance abroad):

    •      In the case of supplementary health insurance operated by type of life insurance, in particular supplementary
           long-term care insurance, the insurance premium calculated at the beginning shall apply for the entire term
           of the insurance contract until a premium adjustment has been made. In the younger years of the policyhold-
           er, the premium portions received from the insurance company are stored in the form of a mathematical
           provision or an ageing provision to cover the higher benefit risks at the age of the policyholder. These premi-
           um portions collected and saved are invested in the so-called security assets to cover the ageing provision,
           the use of which is monitored by an independent, external trustee and is therefore not subject to the insur-
           ance company’s free disposal authority.

    •      In the case of supplementary health insurance operated by type of property insurance, the insurance premi-
           ums are calculated for individual age groups. The insurance premium may therefore change during the term
           of the contract. No premium portions are provided for in this calculation type, as the insurance benefits are
fully covered by the premiums for the age groups.

In 2017, the segment “private supplementary health and long-term care insurance” accounted for €53.5 million (or around
76%) of our gross written premiums and an annual profit of about €1.1 million.

Property and accident insurance. This segment includes our supplementary insurance products such as accident in-
surance, liability insurance, legal expenses insurance, household insurance, animal insurance and electronics insur-
ance (in run-off). Our property insurance cover protects policyholders against financial losses caused by the occur-
rence of defined risks. Through liability insurance, the Company offers protection against claims for damages from in-
jured third parties. Accident insurance covers personal injury resulting from accident events. The electronics insur-
ance division, which mainly offers repair and theft protection for mobile phones, has been in run-off since 2015. The
travel insurance division, which includes in particular travel cancellation insurance and to a lesser extent international
health insurance, was discontinued with the termination of the brokerage and insurance brokerage contract with
Makler der Touristik (MDT) in 2016. In addition, the coinsurance agreement with RheinLand Versicherungen relating
to building insurance was cancelled as of December 31, 2017. The insurance liabilities from these discontinued opera-
tions are covered by us and our reinsurance partners until the end of the insurance contracts with our customers.

In 2017, the segment “property and accident insurance” accounted for €17.1 million (or around 24%) of our gross written
premiums and an annual profit of about €0.4 million.

In addition, the Company is licensed to operate as reinsurer in the same fields for which the Company holds a license as pri-
mary insurer. However, since 2017, the Company had not conducted reinsurance business.
12.2.   Our Digital Approach

The implementation of digitalization begins with the initiation of an insurance contract. We want to offer reasonable and ex-
cellent products that are easy to understand at the same time, and to combine this approach with a simple process of contracting.
From the overview of our products, the customer can immediately recognize the essential benefits and premiums of each insurance
product at a glance. As a mass market player, we offer insurance products and price levels that are suitable for the majority of poten-
tial customers.

We strive to offer our customers a simple and fast process for concluding an insurance contract. We offer a purely digital
process of contract conclusion via our own website or a project-related landing page. We also started using digital language assis-
tants like Amazon Alexa. In the meantime, it is possible to carry out the entire contract conclusion process orally. We see ourselves
as pioneers in the process of concluding oral contracts. Finally, there is the possibility of a paper-based contract conclusion. Paper
applications are essentially only used in the intermediary sales channel. Interactive PDF applications continue to circulate, as brokers
continue to prefer them because of their analog and paper-based orientation.

We offer our customers fast payment processing via Amazon Pay or PayPal. For payment transactions, the stored payment
data can be synchronized with a click. This completes the digital application process within two minutes.

If an insurance policy is taken out in one of the ways described above, this process is recorded fully automatically by us, re-
gardless of the medium. We speak of “dark processing”. This means that the application is automatically entered, checked and ap-
proved. In order to ensure digital processing, only applications will be accepted which have an e-mail address of the customer and
whose use the customer has agreed to.

Our goal is to offer our customers simple and paperless document management. Interested customers receive all relevant
documents by e-mail and the entire contract is processed electronically. After signing the insurance contract, our customers receive
an e-mail with two links and our Wallet Card. This is based on the idea of dispensing with any paper form when concluding new con-
tracts. The first link refers to access to our customer portal. The second link refers to the download of our insurance application.

In our digital customer portal, our customers find everything at a glance and without paper. They can view and download
their contract documents. If a customer has concluded more than one contract, all contracts are on our customer portal. The admin-
istration center of our customer portal opens up the possibility of adapting insurance contracts, e.g. in the event of a necessary
change of address or payment, but also if insurance cover is to be extended or reduced. In addition, our customers have access to
our service center. Finally, they can use our quick regulation.

We also offer all functions via our insurance app which is the mobile version of our customer portal. In addition, customers of
our accident insurance can adjust their insurance cover flexibly on a daily basis. With our accident insurance, customers can insure
their family, friends and acquaintances, depending on the situation.

We provide our customers with their digital insurance policy (e-Police) as a wallet card for their smartphone. Our Wallet Card
is the electronic form of the previously common customer card made of paper or plastic. Our Wallet Card contains the most im-
portant insurance data (e.g., customer number, insured person, product name), but also offers the option of submitting claims or
benefit cases via a direct link to our customer portal.

We strive for a quick and uncomplicated settlement of claims. When settling claims in supplementary health insurance, we
rely on the use of artificial intelligence (“AI”). AI helps us decide which insurance claims are justified and which are not. This leads to
cost savings and contributes to simplicity and speed of reimbursement. When the customer submits an invoice, AI determines what
type of document is involved and assigns the invoice to a service. In the next step, the system checks whether the damage or medical
service is covered by the contract. This works fully automatically through AI and digital added value. In the case of medical invoices
or reports, AI also reads out so-called ICD codes (International Statistical Classification of Diseases and Related Health Problems).
Each disease or injury is therefore assigned to an ICD code and AI directly checks whether the code is covered by the existing insur-
ance or not. Our customers benefit from a particularly fast reimbursement of costs. We guarantee our clients claims settlement with-
in 48 hours of receipt of all relevant documents. Since there is a high probability of fraud in property insurance segment, the claim
history in this segment is checked manually by a claim handler. In future, most of our insurance products could be processed auto-
matically.
12.3.   Our 16 matrix for our supplementary insurance products

With the development of our 16 matrix for our supplementary insurance products, we have laid the foundation for the digi-
talization of our insurance products. Our goal is to enable our customers to take out insurance quickly and easily online. This is why
we have simplified our insurance products and grouped them into four product families.

The 16 matrix was introduced in 2016 in the supplementary health and long-term care insurance segment. For the product
innovation of the 16 matrix, the Company was awarded the Gold Innovation Prize of the German insurance industry (Innovationspre-
is der deutschen Assekuranz in Gold) in 2017 by the renowned, independent analysis house of the insurance industry, Morgen &
Morgen, and the insurance magazine, one of the leading trade journals for insurance intermediaries.
The following table shows the 16 matrix for our health and long-term care insurance products at a glance:

The core idea of the 16 matrix is to offer our supplementary insurance products sorted by insurance families (e.g., supple-
mentary dental insurance), whereby the customer can choose one of four alternatives with different insurance cover. The customer
can choose between the categories ”basic”, “comfort”, “premium” and “exclusive” for each insurance family to determine the scope
of his insurance cover. Because we want to serve the mass market, we offer insurance products and price levels to suit all customer
groups. In our supplementary dental insurance “DFV-Zahnschutz”, the customer can choose between a reimbursement scope of
50%, 70%, 90% and 100% on all dental treatment. This means that in the “exclusive” category, all measures taken by the dentist
would be reimbursed.

The use of the 16 matrix benefits us in two ways: From the customer’s point of view, the use of the 16 matrix increases the
overall understanding of the insurance products offered. From the Company’s point of view, the 16 matrix system also significantly
simplifies the process, as only one condition record and one product information sheet are required for each product family and only
one customer information sheet for all product families. Moreover, there is only one application process. The matrix system also has
the advantage that it is scalable: The reimbursement scope can be adjusted and/or product families can be extended without chang-
ing the matrix system. The expansion of the product families will therefore only lead to a slight increase in process complexity, as we
have already demonstrated with the successful introduction of the 16 matrix for our property insurance products.

In conclusion, the introduction of the 16 matrix was more than just a reorganization of our health insurance products. The
matrix has enabled us to reduce the number of our insurance products from 120 to only 16. This significantly reduces the complexity
and costs of installing and operating insurance products and offers our customers a product that is easy and convenient to use.
12.4.   Sales Structure and Selected Sales Activities

12.4.   Sales Structure and Selected Sales Activities
We have the following sales channels:
•       direct
•       online
•       DRTV
•       cooperations
•       intermediaries
In addition, the cooperation between DFV and the German soccer club Eintracht Frankfurt is a key element of our sales and
marketing presence.
1 Direct

Direct sales essentially comprises marketing for existing customers, i.e. the processing and administration of our own portfo-
lio. The so-called “cross-selling” and “up-selling” takes place both in writing and by telephone exclusively in the portfolio.

First, customers are called for whom insurance cover does not appear to be sufficient to advise on comprehensive insurance
cover. Conversely, customers are also addressed if, for example, too comprehensive insurance cover has been taken out in a family.
All in all, these activities serve customer loyalty. In addition, we systematically process our holdings, particularly with regard to the
conversion of old holdings to new products that are subject to unrestricted digitalization.

In addition, the direct sales channel is also used for general call acceptance, whether through marketing measures or general
service calls, especially from existing customers.
Direct sales account for around 5% of new business.
12.4.2 Online

The online sales channel is currently our strongest sales channel. It accounts for approximately 60% of new business. The ac-
tivities mainly include search engine marketing (SEM) with Google Ads and Bing Ads, search engine optimization (SEO) for Google
and Bing Search as well as affiliate marketing with over 3,400 affiliate partners. Online brokers such as Check24 are also supported in
online sales. In addition, display networks such as Google Ads, Yahoo Gemini (Oath) and Taboola are used to manage performance-
oriented display campaigns. In addition to campaign management, the special focus of online sales is on the continuous develop-
ment of our Internet presence.
12.4.3 DRTV

DRTV stands for Direct Response TV and currently takes place mainly through a cooperation with Germany’s largest private
broadcasting group ProSiebenSat.1 Media SE (“ProSiebenSat.1”). We try to concentrate on so-called transaction-based advertising,
i.e. advertising that should lead directly to the conclusion of a specific insurance product. As a rule, our brand is not advertised. New
contracts are remunerated on a commission basis. Depending on the broadcasting volume used, these contracts account for around
30% of new business.

The DRTV sales channel was significantly expanded. The problem is not so much a negative relationship between expenses
and revenues, which is excluded by commission agreements, but the limitation of the transmission times to be used.

Should DFV also expand its focus to non-transaction-related advertising, a notice-optimization effect (NOE) is expected, as
the existing distribution channels, in particular online and DRTV, are additionally supported by classic advertising.
12.4.4 Cooperations

The cooperation sales channel is volatile. Acquisition periods of 12 to 24 months from the first meeting to the first sale are
common in the cooperation business. The sales focus is on partners with high potential, so that the conclusion of a cooperation
agreement can generate high volumes over a period of two to three years. Thereafter, the potential in the partner’s portfolio natu-
rally flattens out and is limited to winning new partner customers.

Our cooperation partners include in particular Knappschaft and IG BCE Bonusassekuranz GmbH, a subsidiary of IG BCE Bo-
nusagentur GmbH which is a subsidiary of the Mining, Chemical and Energy Industries Union (Industriegewerkschaft Bergbau,
Chemie, Energie). In addition, there are cooperations with Siemens Financial Services and BMW.

For occupational health insurance, the “DFV-DeutschlandPflege” was tailored together with the IG BCE Bonusagentur for op-
erational matters via a group insurance and is currently unique in Germany. Effective January 1, 2019, Henkel AG & Co. KGaA with its
8,300 employees in Germany is the first company to use this group insurance solution. The implementation at Henkel serves as a
blueprint for the introduction at other companies in the chemical and pharmaceutical industry that have already expressed interest
in this solution.
The cooperation sales channel contributes between 5% and 20% to new business, depending on the acquisition status.
12.4.5 Intermediaries

The intermediaries sales channel is basically a very heterogeneous sales channel and can be divided in brokerage and agency
sales. Besides the aforementioned cooperations, the sale of insurance products through insurance agents is mainly organized via
DFVV Deutsche Familienversicherung Vertriebsgesellschaft mbH (“DFVV”), a wholly owned subsidiary of the Company.

The majority of new business in the brokerage sales channel is generated through direct cooperation with insurance brokers
and brokerage pools. Besides, part of the business is generated through a cooperation with VPV Lebensversicherungs-AG (“VPV”).
The focus of the cooperation with VPV is the development of new business in the field of long-term care and supplementary long-
term care insurance. The Company provides several insurance products designed for VPV which are distributed by the sales organiza-
tion of VPV including on the one hand VPV´s company own organization and on the other hand various broker pools related to VPV.
While the other sales channels mentioned above mainly sell supplementary health insurance, the sales channel via broker pools ad-
vertises the supplementary long-term care insurance comparatively strongly.

In June 2018, DFV acquired a 10% stake in the share capital of BCA AG, Oberursel, Germany (“BCA”), minus one share. BCA is
one of the broker pools mentioned above. This participation serves to expand the opportunities within the framework of intermedi-
aries sales by creating new sales potential.
12.4.6 Eintracht Frankfurt

We have significantly expanded our cooperation with the German soccer club Eintracht Frankfurt. From the 2018/19 season,
we will be a premium partner of Eintracht Frankfurt.

Unlike classic advertising, such as TV-relevant perimeter advertising, the cooperation will give us the opportunity to partici-
pate in a unique digital ecosystem to be built up by Eintracht Frankfurt serving the various interests of its fans and members. This
includes, inter alia, activities to support our IPO, to broaden brand awareness, to establish B2B customer contacts (e.g., events with
stakeholders and other target groups) and to address customers with joint digital products in the stadium of Eintracht Frankfurt and
beyond. Furthermore, the access to our products will be integrated into the club’s new digital platform “EintrachtTech” which is sup-
posed to be implemented in the 2019/2020 season.

Eintracht Frankfurt has developed into one of the anchor institutions in the Rhine-Main region. The cooperation with Ein-
tracht Frankfurt will give us access to its strong regional network, especially in Frankfurt. In addition, the cooperation with Eintracht
Frankfurt forms the basis for additional insurance business in the sports sector. This cooperation is complemented by a smaller part-
nership with the German basketball club Frankfurt Skyliners.
12.5.   Our Market Opportunity

The conclusion of new insurance policies is still characterized by personal contact. In 2016, around 90% of the new insurance
contracts were sold through this distribution channel. For example, online penetration in the insurance industry is still relatively low,
with only 16.9% of accident insurance policies sold through direct sales (Direktvertrieb) in 2016, of which only a portion was agreed
online. Nevertheless, this is a growing trend as customers increasingly use messenger apps and social networks in insurance matters
(Source: GDV, Analysis 2018, p. 17 et seqq.).

We believe that this represents a material catch-up potential driven by the general trend towards the use of online media for
the acquisition of new products. Favorable demographic developments will further accelerate the migration from offline to online in
the insurance industry. Between 2007 and 2017, the proportion of Europeans aged 25-64 who bought products online rose from 35%
to 63% (Source: Eurostat, demographic database), driven by the so-called millennials with high affinity to internet in general and e-
commerce in particular, which are beginning to spend their rising revenues on online purchases. We believe that the insurance in-
dustry is particularly attractive for an online offer. Because insurance policies can be easily simplified and standardized for the major-
ity of potential customers, they are best suited for this sales channel.

We believe that due to the strict regulation of the insurance industry there is no reason for the customer to distrust the con-
clusion of insurance policies via digitalized channels. The personal relationship between an agent or broker thus loses importance for
the client. The same applies to the brand of the respective insurer. Rather, customers rely on comfort, pricing and immediate claims
settlement. In addition, the online insurance industry benefits from other positive features such as the efficient management of in-
surance policies through apps and AI as well as cost advantages, especially in personnel and sales costs. We believe that, compared
to our competitors, we offer a wide range of insurance at very competitive premiums that are easy for our customers to understand
and specifically tailored to the new digitalized distribution channels.

Achieving a strong market position by providing a digitalized platform for the tendering of insurance policies is particularly at-
tractive due to the challenges that the industry and technology present to other market participants. These challenges include com-
pliance with the extensive regulation of the insurance sector and the bundled expertise in the insurance industry as well as digitaliza-
tion. We believe that we have successfully mastered these challenges and that our market position will be protected by the signifi-
cant barriers mentioned above.
12.6.   Our Key Strengths
12.6.1 We are the first insurer in Germany to use a fully digitalized platform.

competitive_strength: We are the first insurer in Germany to use a fully digitalized platform.

blobs.text:
We consider ourselves to be the first digitalized insurance company in Germany. Our rapid growth since launching our online
offering has enabled us to achieve a unique market position. We consider ourselves the first digitalized insurer and go-to destination
for online insurance in Germany with around 420,000 existing contracts representing a total gross written premium volume of about
€30.2 million (as of June 30, 2018).

We expect our sales, which amounted to €71 million in 2017, to exceed those of all other InsurTech companies in Germany
during this period. Furthermore, we believe that there is currently no other Insurtech in Germany of a comparable size in terms of
the above figures and we expect our current market position to give us a significant competitive advantage in the highly fragmented
online insurance industry.

The processes and services mentioned above are not yet available for all products and services. However, we have developed
a platform that allows us to further expand the above processes and complement the insurance tariffs.
12.6.2 Our digital insurance products are awarded regularly by Stiftung Warentest.

competitive_strength: Our digital insurance products are awarded regularly by Stiftung Warentest.

blobs.text:
We are convinced that we offer some of the best insurance products on the markets in which we operate. Since the introduc-
tion of our supplementary health insurance in 2008, we have received more than 130 awards for our products, in particular from
Stiftung Warentest, whose rankings regularly place the Company at top positions. For example, our dental supplementary insurance
(Zahnzusatzversicherung), one of our main insurance products, has been honored as test winner (Testsieger) in the ratings of Stiftung
Warentest three times in a row with the top mark of 0.5 (very good) since 2014 (Source: Finanztest, issues 08/2014, 11/2016,
05/2018). Further independent industry, trade and consumer magazines from whom we have been awarded include, among others,
Franke & Bornberg (Source: F&B, Rating Zahnersatz), Focus Money (Source: Focus Money, Zahnzusatz 9/2017), Morgen & Morgen
(Source: M&M, Rating ZahnZusatz), and Ökotest (Source: Ökotest, issue 05/2017).
12.6.3 We follow an uncompromisingly digital approach.

competitive_strength: We follow an uncompromisingly digital approach.

blobs.text:
In Germany, we have been a frontrunner in the digitalization of business processes, including the practical use of AI. In our
opinion, the development of innovative, digital solutions for dental, health and supplementary care insurance has become our core
competence and guarantee of success in recent years. We have standardized the customer information, the health question, the way
of online conversation for all product families. Each product family has a uniform conditional work, product information and insur-
ance policy.

Essential cornerstones of our unique business model are our own position management system, our product model editor
and our digitalized customer journey:

ur digitalized customer journey:
  •      Own position management system

Following our separation from Helvetia, we have developed our own portfolio management system. This position manage-
ment system differs fundamentally from comparable systems used by our competitors. On the one hand, the programming is com-
pletely done in Java. On the other hand, it is an event-driven process machine. Due to this approach, we avoid the batch processing
which is commonly used within the insurance industry. As a result, all changes and adjustments made to our insurance contracts can
be processed in real time. Without this real-time processing, for example, situational accident insurance would not be possible, as
this only makes sense if the customer receives confirmation of his increased insurance cover in real time.
•   Product model editor

The focus of our newly created IT is the so-called “Product Model Editor” (“PME”). The PME is an effective, java-based ma-
chine with which approximately 1,500 characteristics per product can be entered. With the help of such a comprehensive input op-
tion for product properties in this PME, it is possible that changes to insurance products can be implemented immediately and insur-
ance products as such can be technically introduced within a few days. For the latter, there is an additional time requirement only
through product presentations in the subsystems such as the language assistant and the necessary so-called tests, since the PME
controls all interfaces and electronic documents as well as contract preparation and claims processing. For more complex products a
test of two to four weeks is required. By comparison, we estimate that established competitors take between 12 and 15 months to
launch a new online product.
Digitalized customer journey

With respect to digitalization, we distinguish between the internal and external effects of digitalization. The internal effect of
digitalization is process optimization. The external effect, on the other hand, is what the customer actually experiences. This experi-
ence includes shorter application procedures, simpler application procedures and a simple possibility to adapt existing insurance
products independent of time and space, in particular with respect to the closing, policy and claims and service processes:
Closing Process

The implementation of the digitalization begins with the conclusion, because the customer understands the insurance prod-
uct in a few seconds and can convince himself of the quality of the product by a certificate of a third party, e.g., the Stiftung
Warentest. If this idea is combined with a simple contract, simple but product-related advertising can be used to draw attention to
the product almost like a buzzword. Nevertheless, the customer is sufficiently informed to be able to assess the insurance product.

That is why we work with transaction-related advertising, i.e. not with general brand advertising, but with product-related
advertising. Through targeted embedding in the 16 matrix structure, we explain the product in its entirety in a few seconds and the
customer can also complete this product in just as few seconds.

We offer various digital payment methods and customer advice. Digital payment options are Amazon Pay and PayPal. With
this procedure, both payment and address data are synchronized via the data stored in the amazon account, eliminating the need to
complete an online form. Digital customer advice is provided via “Amazon Alexa and our own chatbot “Viktoria”. ”, Digital customer
advice shall also be provided in the near future via “Google Home”. We assume that digital language assistants will take over most of
the insurance consultancy in the future. Alexa skills and Google actions were programed for the consulting dialogue for digital insur-
ance consulting. In addition, customers can access a range of product information and request and change insurance data via our

chatbot “Viktoria”. No employee is required for these purposes. Digitalization has significantly reduced incoming calls from custom-
ers. The technology thus helps the Company to keep costs under control and reduce the number of employees to a minimum even
with increasing customer numbers.
Policy process

An expression of interest from the customer is recorded fully automatically by our IT system, regardless of the medium. This
means that the application is automatically entered, checked and approved. In order to ensure digital processing, only applications
will be accepted which have an e-mail address of the customer and whose use the customer has agreed to. After approval of the ap-
plication, the customer receives an e-mail with two links and our Wallet Card. This is based on the idea of dispensing with any paper
form when concluding new contracts. The first link refers to access to our customer portal. The second link refers to the download of
our insurance application. Our customer portal is the electronic form of what customers used to receive in paper form. The policy is
stored in our customer portal because it must be compiled on the basis of legal requirements. If the customer has concluded several
contracts, all his contracts are on our customer portal. Independently of the conclusion process, our customer portal offers the pos-
sibility of adapting insurance contracts, for example in the event of a necessary change of address or payment, but also if insurance
cover is to be extended or reduced. Our insurance app is the mobile version of our customer portal. In this way, however, the above-
mentioned situational accident insurance can also be controlled, since the customer can access all his insurance data at any time via
our insurance application. Our Wallet Card is the electronic form of the previously common customer card made of paper or plastic.
The Wallet Card contains the most important insurance documents, but also offers the option of submitting claims or benefits via a
direct link to our customer portal. If the customer has opened his DFV customer portal and the insurance premium due has been col-
lected, he will receive an e-mail informing him of the insurance cover.
Claims and service process

The further digitalization is also reflected in the claims area. Here, too, it is up to the customer how he reports the claim to
us. The customer can still do this on paper by post or via our customer portal, our insurance app or via the link on our Wallet Card.
Especially in the service area, it is sufficient to simply photograph the invoice if one of the three electronic input tools is used. Re-
gardless of the actual type of receipt of the claim, the claim is created automatically for the first time. Thanks to these optimized
processes, our customers are able to submit a claim within just six minutes.

The further course of digitalization now depends on the product. Whereas in the area of property damage only an automatic
creation of the claim file was possible up to now, in the area of supplementary health insurance, a completely digitalized and thus
automated benefit processing is currently taking place in the main benefit types, at the end of which the amount to be replaced is
paid out. The differences between property and health insurance can be explained by the different burden of irregularities on the
policyholder side. For example, the probability of fraud in household and liability insurance is relatively high, which is why an admin-
istrator-supported examination of the claims history continues to prove its worth. In contrast, the possibilities for manipulation in
the area of supplementary health insurance are significantly limited. There is a special feature in supplementary health and accident
insurance because they have succeeded in aligning insurance cover with so-called ICD codes. ICD codes are the internationally bind-
ing coding of all diseases that can affect a person. With the accident insurance quoted several times, no digital processing based on
the classic accident concept ”an involuntary event that suddenly takes effect from the outside“ can be realized. This is not the case
when ICD codes are used. For example, the classic term ”accident” has been replaced by an ICD code list defining so-called external
measures. This ICD code list is the subject of the insurance conditions and, after reading the ICD code from the medical opinion with
the help of AI, enables an appropriate comparison and thus an automated decision proposal for the claim handler. Typically, our AI-
based claims system only takes a few minutes to verify the validity of a claim. However, we aim that all customers receive a refund
within 48 hours.
12.6.4 We have a lean, profitable and scalable business model.

competitive_strength: We have a lean, profitable and scalable business model.

blobs.text:
Even though we generally follow a multi-channel sales approach, we are constantly increasing the use of direct sales, to tap
new customer potential at low, scalable costs. As the market penetration of digitalized business in the German insurance market is
still very low, we believe that the German insurance market represents a large and growing market opportunity for our digital busi-
ness model. At the same time, the market penetration in certain lines of business, e.g. long-term care, is very low. As a result, we
believe that the German market offers a large and growing market opportunity for our digitized business model.

For this purpose, we have – relative to our size – invested heavily in our automated, state-of-the-art IT platform in order to
optimize our end-to-end fulfillment processes. We follow a lean and cost-efficient fulfillment approach geared towards customer
satisfaction through high reliability and low return times. As today, our digitalized platform could accommodate about ten times the
current customer base at low additional cost.

We believe that our fully digitalized platform, combined with our focus on customer services and a targeted strategy to fully
digitalize our processes along the entire customer-claims journey, drives our customer loyalty, provides us with a key advantage
compared to other players in the insurance industry. This will help us to further grow our business and to continue to expand our
market position.
12.7.   Our Strategy

We strive to grow our business sustainably and to achieve above-market revenue growth, as well as strong profitability and
cash flow. The following is a summary of the key elements of our current strategy:
12.7.1 We strive to fully digitalize our business.

key_element_strategy: We strive to fully digitalize our business.

blobs.text:
We strive to become Germany’s first fully digitalized insurance company. The continuation and further development of our
digitalization is at the center of our corporate strategy. Progressive digitalization is leading to the creation of new technologies with
the potential for significant economic growth in the insurance industry and in all other sectors. More and more customers are in-
creasingly ready to leave manual claims processes behind and move to a purely digital self-service model. Due to fully automating
back-office processes and decisions traditionally made by claims handlers, claims can be settled more quickly and effectively. The
trend towards digitalization is also having an impact on policy issuance and benefits processing (Source: McKinsey, Insurtech trends
2018).

Our digital approach is holistic: from a customer’s point of view, we develop a strategic perspective before taking into ac-
count tactical and operational aspects. It is not just a question of continuing digitalization in the form it has taken today. Digitaliza-
tion itself is subject to constant further development and technical improvements are to be expected. The lack of suitable IT solu-
tions has so far prevented extensive digitalization, for example, in the area of property insurance.

In 2019, we will continue with the expansion of dark processing of claims and benefits and extend it to the entire portfolio. In
addition, we will extend the policy change processes to life insurance products and thus lay the foundation for the development of
the planned life insurer.

To promote direct sales, we are also planning substantial investments in sales and marketing, e.g. in Google Search, TV mar-
keting (ProSiebenSat.1), cooperations with major companies (Henkel, etc.), and in the expansion of our broker channel.
12.7.2 We want to expand our product portfolio.

key_element_strategy: We want to expand our product portfolio.

blobs.text:
We are striving to become an insurance provider that covers almost all private risks. Therefore, our product portfolio must be
expanded in particular by offering digitalized insurance products.

For example, we applied the concept of 16 matrix supplementary insurance also to our property and casualty insurance seg-
ment. As with supplementary health insurance, the product categories accident, liability, household and legal protection are divided
into the variants “Basic”, “Comfort”, “Premium” and “Exclusive”.

12.7.3 We aim to establish holistic insurance solutions.

key_element_strategy: We aim to establish holistic insurance solutions.

blobs.text:
Until now, established insurers have almost always offered individual insurance. We expect that customers will increasingly
ask for comprehensive insurance solutions in the future, instead of opting for individual products that only cover certain needs.
Therefore, we plan to become a provider of insurance solutions by offering bundles of related insurance products to cover all insur-
ance needs of a customer or his family at once for an insurance lump sum. Changes in connection with the policyholder, whether
positive or negative, are no longer taken into account. Once the customer has opted for such a product bundle, he no longer has to
worry about certain insurance issues. In order to be able to offer an overall solution, approval by the BaFin is required in order to be
able to offer the corresponding insurance lines.

12.7.4 We want to grow our business internationally.

key_element_strategy: We want to grow our business internationally.

blobs.text:
With a successful IPO, we create suitable structures for planned foreign activities. With the new DFV accident insurance, we
have created an insurance product that is suitable for internationalization, especially with the possibility of situational adjustment.
Our aim is therefore to be the first insurance company to offer a so-called European policy, i.e. an insurance product that offers a
uniform risk description at a uniform price throughout the euro zone.

In order to expand our business geographically, a test field is to be launched in the Netherlands in 2019. From there, our in-
surance products are to be marketed in Benelux, France and/or Spain. A notification procedure with BaFin will be required for each
EEA Member State in which we intend to conduct insurance business in the future.

However, our supplementary health insurance products in their current form are not suitable for internationalization, as they
are tailored to the situation of statutory health insurance funds (Gesetzliche Krankenkassen) in Germany.
