13. REGULATORY AND LEGAL ENVIRONMENT
13.1.   Overview

The Company is a German primary insurance company licensed in Germany and subject to comprehensive governmental
regulation. Although the Company holds the respective license it does not conduct any reinsurance business at the time being. The
competent regulatory authority for the Company is the German Federal Financial Supervisory Authority (Bundesanstalt für Fi-
nanzdienstleistungsaufsicht, “BaFin”). Rights and duties of BaFin for the purposes of insurance regulation are set out in the German
Insurance Supervision Act (Versicherungsaufsichtsgesetz, “VAG”) together with the regulations promulgated thereunder. The current
version of the VAG is derived mainly from EU directives, in particular the directive 2009/138/EC on the taking-up and pursuit of the
business of insurance and reinsurance (“Solvency II”). Solvency II is supplemented by other EU legislation directly applicable in every
EEA Member State, e.g., the European Commission´s delegated regulation (EU) 2015/35 of October 10, 2014. As the scope of EU leg-
islation also includes the EEA, references in this section to EU legislation are intended to mean that such legislation is also applicable
to the EEA. The following section describes material aspects of EU and German insurance regulation.

EEA. The following section describes mat

 13.2.   Insurance Regulation in the EU

Since 1973, the EU has adopted a number of interim directives that affect the underwriting and distribution of life insurance
and other types of insurance. These directives have been implemented through national law in Germany and the other EEA Member
States. Ensuring certain minimum standards for insurance regulation in Europe, it was the primary objective of these directives to
grant insurance companies the freedom to establish branches and to provide services outside their home jurisdictions.

In January 2010 Solvency II came into force and replaced 13 existing insurance directives. With the adoption of Solvency II, a
new basis for the insurance supervisory law in Europe was established. In order to establish a single European insurance market, Sol-
vency II was designed to create a uniform regulatory environment in the entire EU/EEA. Solvency II consists of three pillars.

Pillar 1 sets out quantitative requirements regarding appropriate levels of capital to be held by an insurance company. Insur-
ers have to establish technical provisions to cover expected future claims from policyholders. Such technical provisions must be
equivalent to the amount the insurance company would have to pay if it transfers its obligations towards its policyholders to another
insurance company. In addition, insurance companies must meet Minimum Capital Requirements (“MCR”) and Solvency Capital Re-
quirements (“SCR”). The MCR is determined in the directive on the capitalization of insurance undertakings. The Company must have
a minimum capital of €3.7 million. The SCR is based on a value-at-risk measure calibrated to a 99.5% confidence level over a period
of one year. The amount of the SCR shall at least cover life and non-life insurance risks, health insurance risks, market risks, credit
risks and operational risks, not including reputational risks or risks resulting from strategic decisions. The SCR may be calculated ei-
ther using a standard form or an internal model approved by the competent homestate regulator.

Pillar 2 of Solvency II stipulates qualitative requirements regarding the organization and management of insurance compa-
nies. Inter alia, pillar 2 focuses on the insurer´s governance and risk management. Pillar 2 defines key functions, i.e. independent risk
control, compliance, internal audit and actuarial function. Insurance companies are obliged to install these key functions which are
essential to the governance system and are intended in particular to ensure adequate and independent control within the company.
Furthermore, pillar 2 sets out personal and professional qualification requirements for persons who effectively run the company in-
cluding members of the management and supervisory board as well as other persons who perform key functions.

The focus of pillar 3 is on supervisory reporting and transparency requirements and sets out the insurance company´s obliga-
tions of disclosure to regulatory authorities and the public.

Solvency II has been implemented in German law via the Act to Modernize Financial Supervision of Insurance Undertakings
(Gesetz zur Modernisierung der Finanzaufsicht über Versicherungen), which came into force in full on January 1, 2016. In addition,
the European Commission enacted the delegated regulation (EU) 2015/35 of October 10, 2014 which came into force on January 18,
2015. The delegated regulation is directly applicable in all EEA Member States and does not require any additional implementation in
national law. The objective of Solvency II and the new architecture of insurance supervisory law in Europe is a general (full) harmoni-
zation of insurance supervision in the EU including the EEA.

The 2008 financial crisis disclosed deficiencies of the EU financial supervision. The European Insurance and Occupational Pen-
sions Authority (“EIOPA”) was established in 2010 by the EU regulation (EU) 1094/2010 of November 24, 2010 to prevent the risks of
destabilizing the insurance sector. EIOPA was set up to support coordination between national authorities and to ensure consistent
application of EU laws for the insurance and occupational pensions sector in the EU. Therefore, EIOPA draws up regulatory and tech-
nical standards that accompany laws adopted by the Council and the European Parliament for insurance companies. Technical regu-
latory and enforcement standards developed by EIOPA are issued by the European Commission as delegated legal acts within the
meaning of Article 290 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (“TFEU”) or as enforcement acts within the meaning
of Article 291 TFEU and are legally binding for insurance companies.
Furthermore, EIOPA already issued numerous guidelines and recommendations on the application of European law. Such

guidelines and recommendations are not directly binding for insurance companies. However, the national supervisory authorities
must either comply or must explain any deviations from the guidelines and recommendations issued by EIOPA. To date, BaFin has
complied with all EIOPA guidelines with only a few minor exceptions. Finally, in exceptional circumstances, i.e. a breach of law by a
national authority, EIOPA may issue instructions to national authorities as BaFin. In this case, EIOPA can issue a recommendation to
the national authority. If the national authority´s noncompliance persists, EIOPA may take direct action itself and under certain strict
conditions issue binding decisions on insurance companies.
13.3.   Insurance Regulation in Germany

The company in its capacity as insurance company is subject to supervision by BaFin under the VAG and EU legislation as laid
out above. The primary objectives of supervision by BaFin are the protection of policyholders´ interests and preservation of the in-
surer’s ability to fulfil its obligations under the insurance policies it has written.

s ability to fulfil its obligations u

  13.3.1 Licensing Regulation

Insurance regulation comprises both licensing regulation and ongoing supervision. Primary insurance and reinsurance com-
panies require a license to carry out their business in Germany unless they already hold a license from another EEA Member State.
Insurance companies holding a license of a EEA Member State are entitled to conduct insurance business in other EEA Member
States under the European principle of freedom of services or freedom of establishment without being subject to licensing laws of
that other EEA Member State (single license principle). However, the supervisory authority of the EEA Member State where the in-
surance company intends to conduct business directly or via a branch needs to be notified of such intention. An additional license is
not required. The insurance company will be subject to financial and legal supervision by its homestate regulator, where the insur-
ance company has its registered seat. Besides, legal supervision is also conducted by the regulatory authorities of each EEA Member
State, in which the insurance company conducts business. However, the national supervision law of the respective country of opera-
tion is only partially applicable in this regard.

Authorization to conduct insurance business can only be granted to stock companies including the European stock company
(Societas Europaea), mutual insurance companies or corporations or institutions under public law. Applicants for an insurance license
must inter alia provide evidence that the company has a proper and effective business organization which ensures sound and pru-
dent management. It must also be able to prove that it has sufficient own funds to comply with the capital requirements. When con-
sidering applicants for an insurance license, BaFin will examine whether the organizational, financial and other legal requirements
applicable to insurance companies have been satisfied. Inter alia, managing directors, other persons that effectively run the under-
taking, board members, the actuary in charge as well as other persons responsible for key functions must be reliable and technically
suitable. Examination by BaFin also includes a background check on shareholders with a qualifying holding (bedeutende Beteiligung).
Furthermore, applicants must submit a business plan setting out information regarding the type and scope of the proposed business.
In addition, applicants must demonstrate that they have adequate capitalization to support the insurance lines they propose to
write. The license is issued uniformly for the entire EU as well as all other EEA Member States.

In order to prevent that risks inherent to certain lines of insurance affect other lines of insurance, insurance companies au-
thorized to conduct life insurance will not be authorized to conduct other types of insurance. Such principle of separation of certain
insurance lines also applies to substitutive health insurance. Therefore, an insurance company is prohibited to write substitutive
health insurance and other insurance lines at the same time. Reinsurance companies are not affected by the aforesaid principle and
therefore may offer both, life and non-life reinsurance including substitutive healthcare. Besides, primary insurance companies are
not allowed to conduct business that is not directly connected with insurance business (Verbot versicherungsfremden Geschäfts).
13.3.2 Ongoing Supervision

BaFin’s onging supervision comprises legal and financial supervision. The primary goal of BaFin’s legal supervision of insurers
is the proper operation of insurance business, including compliance with all supervisory provisions and regulations governing insur-
ance contracts as well as any other provisions concerning policyholders and the insurer’s business plan. The primary goal of BaFin’s
financial supervision is to ensure that insurance companies are able to meet their obligations under insurance contracts written by
them at any given time. In particular, BaFin ensures that insurance undertakings are solvent and maintain their long-term risk-
bearing capacity, have recognized adequate technical provisions, invest in appropriate assets, comply with general commercial prin-
ciples, including those in respect of a proper system of governance, and that they also comply with other financial principles estab-
lished for their business operations.

BaFin has the general authority to take all measures which are appropriate and necessary to prevent or remedy grievance.
Grievance means in particular any conduct of an insurance company that is contrary to regulatory objectives. If the insurance under-
taking violates the applicable law or orders of the supervisory authority, BaFin may warn and recall persons who effectively run the
undertaking or are responsible for other key functions. This also includes the members of the supervisory board. Furthermore, BaFin
must revoke authorization to conduct insurance business, e.g. if the insurance undertaking does not comply with the MCR and BaFin
is of the opinion, that the financing plan submitted is obviously inadequate. In addition, BaFin is entitled to revoke authorization if

the company no longer fulfils the conditions for granting of the license or seriously violates its obligations. In the interest of effective
supervision, BaFin has far reaching rights to information and (on-site) auditing. Insurance companies have comprehensive obligations
to report to BaFin. The reporting obligations include regular financial reports. BaFin may also examine the books and records of in-
surance companies subject to its supervision at any time.

As part of the ongoing supervision process insurance companies are subject to numerous obligations to obtain approvals and
make submissions. For example, amendments to the articles of association (except those which involve a capital increase) and other
material changes in the business plan may not be put into effect unless they have been approved by BaFin.
13.3.3 Supervision of holders of a qualifying holding (bedeutende Beteiligung)

The acquisition or maintenance of qualifying holdings (bedeutende Beteiligung) in an insurance company is subject to special
supervision by BaFin. In particular, BaFin has the authority to prohibit acquisition or increase of a qualifying holding in accordance
with section 18 VAG.

A qualifying holding is defined in section 7 no. 3 VAG and is deemed to exist if at least 10% of the capital or the voting rights
in an insurance undertaking are held directly or indirectly or if a significant influence can be exerted otherwise on the management
of an insurance undertaking. BaFin must be notified in writing and without undue delay of a person´s intention to acquire, alone or in
concert with other persons or undertakings, a qualifying holding in an insurance company subject to supervision by BaFin. If the
holder of a qualifying holding intends to increase the amount of the qualifying holding alone or in concert with other persons or un-
dertakings, such that the thresholds of 20%, 30% or 50% of the voting rights or the registered capital are reached or exceeded, or
that the insurance undertaking becomes a controlled enterprise, the respective holder has to notify BaFin in writing without undue
delay too. Finally, BaFin must also be notified in writing and without undue delay of the intention to give up or to reduce a qualifying
holding to an amount below the thresholds of 20%, 30% or 50% of the voting rights or the registered capital or the intention to
change the holding so that the insurance undertaking is not a controlled enterprise any longer.

The insurance undertaking itself is subject to similar notification duties in connection with qualifying holdings. According to
section 47 no. 5 VAG insurance undertakings must notify BaFin of the acquisition or disposal of a qualifying holding in its own under-
taking, the reaching as well as exceeding or falling short of the holding thresholds of 20%, 30% and 50% of the voting rights or of the
capital as well as the fact that the undertaking becomes a subsidiary of another undertaking, as soon as the insurance undertaking
gains knowledge of the forthcoming change of the holding structure.

In the interest of sound and prudent management of an insurance company, holders of a qualifying holding must in particular
be reliable. BaFin will conduct an ownership control procedure before acquisition or increase of a qualifying holding can be complet-
ed. For this purpose BaFin must be provided with certain documents and information regarding the acquiring person as further spec-
ified by the ownership control regulation (Inhaberkontrollverordnung – “InhKontrollV”). According to section 18 para. 1 VAG BaFin
may prohibit the acquisition or the increase of a qualifying holding, if there are facts justifying the assumption that the notifying per-
son or, if the notifying person is a legal entity, a legal representative or a representative according to the articles of association, or, if
the notifying person is a commercial partnership, one of the partners, is not reliable or does not satisfy the requirements to be set in
the interests of a sound and prudent management of the insurance undertaking for any other reasons. BaFin may further prohibit
the acquisition or increase of the qualifying holding if the insurance undertaking will be or remain unable to satisfy the supervisory
requirements, or if the acquisition or increase of the holding would result in the integration of the insurance undertaking, together
with the holder of the qualifying holding, into a group structure which, due to the ownership structure or poor economic transparen-
cy, may hinder effective supervision of the insurance undertaking or the effective exchange of information between the competent
authorities or the allocation of competencies between them. If the insurance undertaking, as a result of the acquisition or increase of
the qualifying holding, would become a subsidiary of an insurance undertaking of a non-EEA Member State which is not subject to
effective supervision in the state of its registered or head office or the competent supervisory authority of which is not willing to co-
operate in a satisfactory manner, BaFin may also prohibit the acquisition. Furthermore, the future manager must be reliable and pro-
fessionally suitable. In addition, BaFin may prohibit the acquisition if money laundering or terrorism financing takes or has taken
place in connection with the proposed acquisition or increase of the holding, or there has been an attempt to commit these criminal
offences, or the proposed acquisition or increase could increase the risk of such conductor. Further, the notifying person must have
the necessary financial stability, in particular in respect of the type of the actual and planned business of the insurance undertaking.
The required financial stability is in particular missing if the notifying person, due to its capitalization or financial situation, is unable
to satisfy the special requirements of the insurance undertaking resulting from its capitalization or liquid funds in order to ensure
that the obligations under the insurance contracts can be fulfilled at any time or in order to avoid liquidity shortages. At least, BaFin
may prohibit the acquisition or increase of a qualifying holding if the information provided together with the notification or request-
ed by BaFin are incomplete or incorrect (section 18 para. 2 VAG). The assessment period of BaFin is in general 60 working days as
from the date of the letter by which BaFin confirmed in writing the receipt of the full notification. The assessment period might be
extended by BaFin by up to 20 working days to a maximum total of 80 working days within the first 50 working days of the initial as-
sessment period. Extension by up to 30 working days to a maximum total of 90 working days is possible to the extent that the appli-
cant is situated or regulated outside the EEA or the applicant is a natural or legal person not subject to supervision under Directive
2009/138/EC, Directive 2009/65/EC, Directive 2004/39/EC, or Directive 2006/48/EC. Acquisition or increase of the qualifying holding
can be completed if BaFin does not deny it during the assessment period.

Furthermore, BaFin has the authority to issue orders to shareholders retrospectively if they jeopardise a prudent manage-
ment of the insurance company. In particular, BaFin may prohibit the exercise of voting rights and may order that disposal of shares
is subject to BaFin approval (i) if the conditions for prohibition of the holding according to section 18 para. 1 or 2 VAG as laid out
above are met; (ii) the holder of a qualifying holding has not notified BaFin of the acquisition or increase of the qualifying holding in
advance and has not made up for its notification duties within the time limit set by BaFin; or (iii) if the holding has not been acquired
or increased within a time limit set by BaFin or has been acquired or increased irrespective of an enforceable prohibition of the ac-
quisition by BaFin.
13.3.4 Life Insurance

Some types of insurance have distinct characteristics. This is in particular the case in life insurance, in which insurance premi-
ums are subject to a specific statutory regulation. Life insurance premiums have to be calculated on the basis of reasonable actuarial
assumptions and must be high enough to allow the insurance company to fulfil all of its obligations, especially to build up sufficient
reserves for individual contracts. Life insurers are required to calculate their premiums in a particularly conservative manner in order
to protect policyholders. An insurer’s calculation of premiums and certain other requirements must be monitored and signed off by
responsible actuary to be appointed for this purpose and who is bound by special public law duties. Furthermore, policyholders have
a right to participate in surpluses and valuation reserves.
13.3.5 Healthcare Insurance

Healthcare insurance is subject to specific statutory regulation. This is in particular the case, if it is offered by type of life in-
surance or replaces health or long-term care insurance cover provided for under the statutory social insurance system (substitutive
health insurance). Specific regulatory requirements apply inter alia in connection with the calculation of premiums. Premiums are to
be calculated on an actuarial basis on the basis of probability tables and other relevant statistical data, in particular taking into ac-
count the relevant assumptions concerning the risk of disability and illness, mortality, the age and sex dependence of the risk and the
likelihood of reversal and taking into account a security surcharge and other surcharges as well as an actuarial interest rate. Moreo-
ver, specific requirements apply regarding termination or amendments to the insurance contract. Comparably to life insurance, a
responsible actuary must be appointed in connection with the provision of substitutive health insurance or if health insurance is of-
fered by type of life insurance. The actuary monitors calculation of premiums and underwriting reserves, in particular the ageing re-
serve.
13.4.   Regulation of Insurance Distribution Group Companies

The Group includes a mediation company, DFVV Deutsche Familienversicherung-Vertriebsgesellschaft mbH, acting as insur-
ance agent. In general, insurance agents need to be authorized by the German Chamber of Industry and Commerce and must be reg-
istered with the intermediary register according to the German trade regulations (Gewerbeordnung – “GewO”). According to sec-
tion 48 VAG the Company must ensure, that it cooperates only with insurance intermediaries being authorized by the Chamber of
Industry and Commerce pursuant to the German trade regulations or insurance intermediaries that are not subject to authorization
or have been exempted from the authorization requirement. Authorization is, inter alia, not required, if the insurance agent carries
on its intermediary activity solely on behalf of one or, if the insurance products are not in competition, several insurance undertak-
ings authorized to conduct insurance business in Germany and if the insurance undertaking or undertakings have assumed full liabil-
ity from the agent resulting from its intermediary activities (so called “tied-agent”). Authorization as insurance agent is not granted
or revoked if facts justify the assumption that the agent is not reliable, the agent lives in disorderly financial circumstances, does not
provide professional indemnity insurance or an equivalent guarantee or does not provide the required evidence of competence.
13.5.   Measures for the Stabilization of the Financial Market

In response to the worldwide financial crisis 2008 and in the interest of a stable financial market, systemically important
companies in the financial and insurance industry must fulfil tighter regulatory and solvency requirements. Companies whose col-
lapse may have unforeseen consequences for the entire financial and insurance industry and which are deemed in this manner rele-
vant for the financial system are concerned. Currently 9 insurance undertakings have been identified by the Financial Stability Board
(“FSB”) and are listed as global systemically important. The Company is not one of these.

As of the date of this Prospectus, SK Beteiligungen GmbH, the Community of Heirs (Erbengemeinschaft) Vogel and Luca Pesa-
rini (directly and indirectly through ETHENEA Independent Investors S.A.) (the “Major Shareholders”) each hold more than 30% of
the voting rights in the Company and are, therefore, considered to hold a controlling interest in the Company pursuant to the WpÜG.

Following the completion of the Offering, the SK Beteiligungen GmbH, the Community of Heirs (Erbengemeinschaft) Vogel
and Luca Pesarini (directly and indirectly through ETHENEA Independent Investors S.A.) will hold at least 22.63%, 22.39% and 25.58%,

none of the Major Shareholders will continue to hold more than 30% of the voting rights in the Company and, thus, will continue to
hold a controlling interest in the Company pursuant to the WpÜG.

The voting rights of the Major Shareholders do not differ from the rights attached to any other shares, including the Offer
Shares. There are no special provisions in the Articles of Association to ensure that the ability of a controlling shareholder to exercise
control is not abused.
15. GENERAL INFORMATION ON THE COMPANY AND THE GROUP
15.1.   Formation

The Company was incorporated as a stock corporation (Aktiengesellschaft) under German law under the legal name “DFV
Deutsche Familienversicherung – Vermittlungs-AG” by memorandum of association dated July 25, 2006. The Company was regis-
tered with the commercial register (Handelsregister) of the local court (Amtsgericht) of Frankfurt am Main, Germany, on Septem-
ber 18, 2006.

On November 30, 2006, the Company’s shareholders’ meeting resolved on the change of the Company’s legal name to “DFV
Deutsche Familienversicherung AG” which was registered with the commercial register (Handelsregister) of the local court
(Amtsgericht) of Frankfurt am Main, Germany, on February 9, 2007.

(Amtsgericht) of Frankfurt am Main, Germany, on February 9, 2007.

       The Company is registered with the commercial register (Handelsregister) of the local court (Amtsgericht) of Frankfurt am

Main, Germany, under the number HRB 78012.

      15.2.   Commercial Name and Registered Office

The Company is the Group’s parent company. The Group primarily operates under the commercial name “Deutsche Fami-
lienversicherung”.

The Company’s registered office is in Frankfurt am Main, Germany, and its business address is at Reuterweg 47, 60323 Frank-
furt am Main, Germany (telephone: +49 (0) 69 95 86 969).
15.3.   Fiscal Year and Duration

The Company’s fiscal year is the calendar year. The Company has been established for an unlimited duration.

15.4.   Object of the Company

Pursuant to Section 2 para. 1 of the Articles of Association, the object of the Company is the direct operation of property, ac-
cident and legal expense insurance, as well as non-substitutive health insurance and private supplementary long-term care insur-
ance, active reinsurance and the distribution of other insurance products in its own name and under other names. Under Section 2
para. 2 of the Articles of Association, the Company is entitled to engage in all businesses connected to the object of the Company or
favoring same or directly or indirectly promoting same. The Company can also participate or invest in other businesses or companies
with the same or similar object. It can also restrict its object to some of the activities stated in Section 2 para. 1 of the Articles of As-
sociation. Furthermore, the Company can establish branches at home or abroad.
15.5.   Our History

The Company was founded in 2006 by Dr. Stefan M. Knoll and Philipp J. N. Vogel under the company name “DFV Deutsche
Familienversicherung – Vermittlungs-AG”. Object of the Company was the brokerage of insurance products for families as well as the
acquisition of suitable sales partners, who in turn can make customer portfolios available for insurance brokerage. The Company
prepared the formation of an insurance company.

By the end of 2006, DFV Deutsche Familienversicherung – Vermittlungs-AG was granted permission by BaFin to commence
business operations as from January 1, 2007 in the business lines accident insurance, fire and natural hazards, hail, frost and other
property damage, various financial losses as well as legal expenses insurance. With permission to commence business operations,
the Company was renamed “DFV Deutsche Familienversicherung AG” and the share capital was increased from €50,000 to
€5,400,000. The object of the Company was changed into the direct operation of property and accident insurance as well as legal
expenses insurance and the brokerage of other insurance products in own name and under a different name. In the aftermath, the
Company’s share capital was increased several times.

At the beginning, the Company’s almost exclusive sales channel was DRTV. The Company initially offered property insurance,
preferably in the form of a combined insurance product. At a standard price of €19.99, accident, home contents, glass, third party
liability and legal expenses insurance were each part of the combined insurance product “KombiVersicherung 5 plus”. An IT support
contract was concluded with Helvetia Schweizerische Versicherung AG (“Helvetia”), under which the Company was able to use Hel-
vetia’s IT as an inventory management system.

IT as an inventory management system.

Initially, all shares in the Company were held by their founders, Dr. Knoll and Mr. Vogel. In 2008, Helvetia became a share-
holder of the Company.

With the BaFin permission, the Company’s insurance portfolio was extended in 2008 to include supplementary health insur-
ances with the types of risk per diem allowance, cost insurance and combined services. The object of the Company was changed ac-
cordingly. As a result, numerous company health insurance funds were acquired as sales partners.

In 2011, the Company was licensed by BaFin to operate as reinsurer in the fields of supplementary health insurances and
changed its object accordingly.

In 2012, the Mellinckrodt fund joined the Company as new shareholder and Helvetia sold all of its shares in the Company to
the founders. In the same year, the Company was granted permission by BaFin to operate supplementary long-term care insurance
and to operate as reinsurer in the fields for which the Company holds a license as primary insurer. The object of the Company was
changed accordingly. The Company’s insurance portfolio was extended to include supplementary long-term care insurance.

The IT support contract with Helvetia was terminated on December 31, 2013. Subsequently, we developed our own invento-
ry management system. In 2014, we succeeded in gradually introducing our own inventory management system which in our opinion
is one of the most modern portfolio management systems on the insurance market.

s one of the most modern portfolio management systems on the insurance market.

      Luca Pesarini became a shareholder of the Company in 2014 and the shares of the Mellinckrodt Fund were transferred to the
Ethenea Fund.

In 2015, Mr. Vogel, founding member and member of the Management Board, died. The Company was then completely re-
structured and realigned. The business line of electronics insurance was suspended, the number of employees was reduced and the
sales division was reorganized. The goal was to return to the profit zone. In 2016, we introduced the so-called 16er matrix supple-
mentary health insurance, which contains four product lines in four variants. In addition the broker portal was developed and intro-
duced. This restructuring process was completed in 2017.
15.6.   Group Structure

The Company is the parent company of the Group. The Group’s business is conducted by the Company and its various subsid-
iaries. The Group compromises all companies whose financial and business policy can be controlled by the Company, either directly
or indirectly, and the equity interests of the Group whose financial and business policy can be influenced by the Company to a signif-
icant extent. As of the date of this Prospectus, the Group compromises three companies (excluding the Company), which are all
based in Frankfurt am Main, Germany.

16. SHARE CAPITAL OF THE COMPANY AND APPLICABLE REGULATIONS

16.2.   Development of the Share Capital

16.3.   Authorized Capital 2018

On September 5, 2018, the Company’s extraordinary shareholders’ meeting resolved to create an authorized capital (“Au-
thorized Capital 2018”). The resolution was entered into the commercial register on September 13, 2018.

of shares and the implementation of the capital increases. The shareholders are generally to be granted a subscription right. The new
shares may also be taken up by one or more credit institutions with the obligation to offer them to the shareholders for subscription

(indirect subscription right). However, the Management Board is authorized, with the approval of the Supervisory Board, to exclude
shareholders’ subscription rights in the following cases:

       •       for fractional amounts resulting from capital increases against cash and/or contributions in kind as a result of the
               subscription ratio;

       •       to the extent necessary to grant shares to holders of bonds with warrants or convertible bonds of the Company or a
               Group company in the event of an offer addressed to all shareholders or a capital increase with subscription rights to
               the extent to which these holders would have a subscription right to shares of the Company after exercising the op-
               tion or conversion right or fulfilling the corresponding obligation;

       •       in the case of capital increases against cash contributions up to an amount which does not exceed 10% of the regis-
               tered share capital at the time this authorization becomes effective or, if the share capital is then lower, at the time
               this authorization is exercised, if the issue price of the new shares does not significantly exceed the stock exchange
               price of the already listed shares with the same features within the meaning of Section 203 para. 1 sentence 1 and
               para. 2 AktG in conjunction with Section 186 para. 3 sentence 4 AktG. Shares acquired on the basis of an authoriza-
               tion by the Company’s general meeting (“General Meeting”) and sold during the term of this authorization in accord-
               ance with Section 71 para. 1 no. 8 sentence 5 AktG in conjunction with Section 186 para. 3 sentence 4 AktG are cred-
               ited against the aforementioned 10% limit. Furthermore, shares issued to service subscription rights arising from
               bonds with warrants and/or convertible bonds shall be included in this limitation, provided that the bonds with war-
               rants and/or convertible bonds are issued during the term of this authorization in analogous application of Sec-
               tion 186 para. 3 sentence 4 AktG, excluding subscription rights;

       •       in the case of capital increases against contributions in kind for the purpose of granting new shares for the direct or
               indirect acquisition of companies, parts of companies or interests in companies and other assets, including loans and
               other liabilities, including receivables from the company itself;

       •       to offer the new shares by way of a public offering in the Federal Republic of Germany and/or the Grand Duchy of
               Luxembourg and, if applicable, by way of a private placement in other jurisdictions outside the Federal Republic of
               Germany and the Grand Duchy of Luxembourg at a sales price still to be determined by the Management Board and
               subject to the approval of the Supervisory Board, in each case together with an introduction of the shares of the
               Company for trading on a German stock exchange (“IPO”);

       •       to offer the new shares for subscription to persons who are employed by the Company or any company affiliated
               with it within the meaning of § 15 AktG or members of corporate bodies of any company affiliated with it within the
               meaning of § 15 AktG, whereby the subscription may also take place at preferential terms. The new shares may also
               be taken up by one or more banks or companies within the meaning of § 186 para. 5 sentence 1 AktG as defined by
               the Management Board with the obligation to pass them on exclusively to the beneficiaries.

         The Supervisory Board is authorized after complete or partial execution of the capital increase from Authorized Capital 2018
or after expiry of the authorization period to amend the wording of the Articles of Association in accordance with the extent of the
capital increase from Authorized Capital 2018.
16.4.   General Provisions Governing a Liquidation of the Company

Apart from liquidation as a result of insolvency proceedings, the Company may only be liquidated with a vote of 75% or more
of the share capital represented at the vote. Furthermore, the commencement of insolvency proceedings regarding the assets of the
Company, the rejection of insolvency proceedings for insufficient assets to cover the costs of the proceedings, a cancellation of the
Company for lack of funds or the imposition of a final decision of the registry court about a material defect in the Articles of Associa-
tion could lead to a cancellation of the Company. In the event of the Company’s liquidation, the AktG provides that any assets re-
maining once all of the Company’s liabilities have been settled shall be distributed amongst the Company’s shareholders in propor-
tion to their shareholdings. The AktG provides certain protections for creditors in the event of a liquidation of the Company.
16.5.   General Provisions Governing a Change in the Share Capital

The AktG provides that the share capital of a stock corporation (Aktiengesellschaft) may be increased by a resolution of the
shareholders’ meeting passed by a majority of at least 75% of the share capital represented at the vote and may change the articles
of association accordingly. However, the articles of association may provide that, instead of the 75% majority, a simple majority of
the share capital represented at the vote suffices to increase the Company’s share capital, provided that at least 50% of the Compa-
ny’s share capital is represented at the vote. Section 21 para. 2 of the Articles of Association has made use of this option, and conse-
quently capital increases may be resolved by the Company’s shareholders’ meeting with a simple majority of the share capital repre-
sented at the vote, if at least 50% of the Company’s share capital is represented at the vote.

The shareholders’ meeting may also create authorized capital (Genehmigtes Kapital). This requires a resolution passed by a
majority of at least 75% of the share capital represented at the vote, authorizing the Management Board to issue a specific number
of shares within a period of no more than five years. The aggregate nominal amount of the new shares may not exceed 50% of the
share capital existing at the time the authorization is granted (i.e., at the time the authorized capital is registered in the commercial
register).

In addition, the shareholders’ meeting can create conditional capital (Bedingtes Kapital) through a resolution passed with a
majority of at least 75% of the share capital represented at the vote, for the purposes of (i) granting exchange or subscription rights
to holders of convertible bonds or other securities granting a right to subscribe for shares; (ii) preparing for a merger with other
companies; or (iii) granting subscription rights to managers and employees of the Company or an affiliated company by way of an
approval resolution or authorization resolution. The nominal amount of conditional capital may not exceed 10% of the share capital
at the time the resolution is passed in cases where it is created to grant subscription rights to managers and employees, and may not
exceed 50% in all other cases.
Resolutions to reduce the Company’s share capital require a majority of at least 75% of the share capital represented at the
vote.
16.6.   General Provisions Governing Subscription Rights

Section 186 AktG generally grants all shareholders the right to subscribe for new shares of the Company issued in case of a
capital increase. The same applies to convertible bonds, bonds with warrants, profit participation rights and participating bonds.
Subscription rights are freely transferable and may be traded on German stock exchanges for a prescribed period before the deadline
for subscription expires. However, shareholders do not have the right to demand admission to trading for subscription rights. The
Company’s shareholders’ meeting may resolve to exclude shareholders’ subscription rights with a vote of 75% or more of the share
capital represented at the vote. Exclusion of shareholders’ subscription rights, wholly or in part, also requires a report from the Man-
agement Board to the shareholders’ meeting that justifies the exclusion and demonstrates that the Company's interest in excluding
subscription rights outweighs the interests of the shareholders to be granted subscription rights. An exclusion of shareholders' sub-
scription rights is, in particular, permissible if:

•       the Company increases its share capital against cash contributions;

•       the amount of the capital increase of the issued shares with no subscription rights does not exceed 10% of the share
        capital at issue, both at the time when the authorization takes effect and at the time when it is authorized; and

•       the price at which the new shares are being issued is not materially lower than the stock exchange price of the Com-
        pany’s shares.

16.7.   Exclusion of Minority Shareholders
16.7.1 Squeeze-Out under Stock Corporation Law

Sections 327a et seq. AktG, which govern the so-called “squeeze-out under stock corporation law”, upon request of a share-
holder holding 95% or more of the Company’s share capital, the Company’s shareholders’ meeting may resolve to transfer the shares
of minority shareholders to such majority shareholder against payment of an adequate compensation in cash. The amount of the
cash payment offered to minority shareholders must to reflect “the circumstances of the Company” at the time the shareholders’
meeting passes the resolution. The amount of the cash payment is based on the full value of the Company, which is generally deter-
mined using the capitalized earnings method. Minority shareholders are entitled to file for a valuation proceeding (Spruchverfahren),
wherein the court will review the fairness (Angemessenheit) of the cash payment.
16.7.2 Squeeze-Out and Tender Rights under Takeover Law

Under Sections 39a and 39b WpÜG, in case of a so-called “squeeze-out under takeover law”, an offeror holding at least 95%
of the voting share capital of a target company (as defined in the WpÜG) following a takeover offer or mandatory offer, may, within
three months of the expiration of the deadline for acceptance of the offer, petition the regional court (Landgericht) of Frankfurt am
Main, Germany, to order the transfer of the remaining voting shares to such offeror against payment of an adequate compensation.
Such transfer does not require a resolution of the shareholders’ meeting. The consideration paid in connection with the takeover
offer or mandatory offer is considered adequate if the offeror has obtained at least 90% of the share capital that was subject to the
offer. The nature of the compensation must be the same as the consideration paid under the takeover offer or mandatory offer,
while at all times a compensation in cash must also be offered.

In addition, following a takeover offer or mandatory offer, the shareholders in a target company who have not accepted the
offer may do so up to three months after the acceptance period has expired (Section 39c WpÜG), provided the offeror is entitled to
petition for the transfer of the outstanding voting shares in accordance with Section 39a WpÜG.

The provisions for a squeeze-out under stock corporation law cease to apply once an offeror has petitioned for a squeeze-out
under takeover law, and only apply again when these proceedings have been definitively completed.
16.7.3 Squeeze-Out under Reorganization Law

Pursuant to Section 62 para. 5 sentence 1 UmwG, a majority shareholder holding at least 90% of the Company’s share capital
may require the Company’s shareholders’ meeting to resolve to transfer the shares of the minority shareholders to such majority
shareholder against payment of an adequate compensation in cash, provided that (i) the majority shareholder is a stock corporation
(Aktiengesellschaft (AG)), a partnership limited by shares (Kommanditgesellschaft auf Aktien (KGaA)), or a European Company (So-
cietas Europaea (SE)) having its seat in Germany; and (ii) the squeeze-out is performed to facilitate a merger under the UmwG be-
tween the majority shareholder and the Company. The shareholders’ meeting held to approve the squeeze-out must take place with-
in three months of the conclusion of the merger agreement.

The procedure for a squeeze-out under the UmwG is essentially identical to the "squeeze-out under stock corporation law"
described above, including the minority shareholders' right to judicial review of the appropriateness of the cash compensation.
scribed above, including t
16.7.4 Integration

Section 319 et seq. AktG, the Company’s shareholders’ meeting may vote for an integration (Eingliederung) into another
stock corporation that has its registered office in Germany, provided the prospective parent company holds at least 95% of the
shares of the Company. The former shareholders of the Company are entitled to adequate compensation, which generally must be
provided in the form of shares in the parent company. In such case, Section 305 para. 3 sentence 1 AktG stipulates that shares must
be issued based on the appropriate valuation in case a merger had taken place between the two companies, i.e. the amount of the
cash compensation must be determined using the “merger value ratio” (Verschmelzungswertrelation) between the companies. Frac-
tional amounts may be paid out in cash.
16.8.   Shareholder Notification Requirements; Mandatory Takeover Bids; Directors' Dealings

Once the Company’s shares are admitted to trading on the regulated market (regulierter Markt) of the Frankfurt Stock Ex-
change (Frankfurter Wertpapierbörse) with simultaneous admission to the sub-segment of the regulated market with additional post
admission obligations (Prime Standard) of the Frankfurt Stock Exchange (Frankfurter Wertpapierbörse), the Company will be subject
to WpHG provisions governing, inter alia, disclosure requirements for significant shareholdings, the WpÜG provisions governing
takeover bids and mandatory offers, as well as the MAR provisions governing, inter alia, directors’ obligations to disclose transactions
in the Company's shares, debt instruments, related derivatives or other related financial instruments. In addition, the Company is
subject to VAG provisions which stipulate special notification requirements regarding holders of a qualifying holding in the Company.
16.8.1 Notification Requirements of Shareholders

16.8.1.1 Special notification requirements and non-denial of acquisition pursuant to the German Insurance Supervision Act
         (VAG)

Section 17 para. 1 VAG stipulates notification requirements regarding holders of a qualifying holding (bedeutende Betiligung).
BaFin may prohibit acquisition or increase of a qualifying holding in accordance with section 18 VAG. A qualifying holding is deemed
to exist if at least 10% of the capital or the voting rights in an insurance undertaking are held directly or indirectly or if a significant
influence can be exerted otherwise on the management of an insurance undertaking.

BaFin must be notified in writing and without undue delay of a person´s intention to acquire, alone or in concert with other
persons or undertakings, a qualifying holding in an insurance company subject to supervision by BaFin. If the holder of a qualifying
holding intends to increase the amount of the qualifying holding alone or in concert with other persons or undertakings, such that
the thresholds of 20%, 30% or 50% of the voting rights or the registered capital are reached or exceeded, or that the insurance un-
dertaking becomes a controlled enterprise, the respective holder has to notify BaFin in writing without undue delay too. In both cas-
es BaFin will conduct an ownership control procedure before the acquisition or increase of the qualifying holding can be completed.
For this purpose BaFin must be provided with certain documents and information regarding the acquiring person as further specified
by the ownership control regulation (Inhaberkontrollverordnung). The assessment period of BaFin is in general 60 working days as
from the date of the letter by which BaFin confirmed in writing the receipt of the full notification including all required documents
and information. BaFin may extend the assessment period by up to 20 or under certain conditions up to 30 working days. During
such period, BaFin may prohibit acquisition or increase of the qualifying holding.

In addition, BaFin must also be notified in writing and without undue delay of the intention to give up or to reduce a qualify-
ing holding to an amount below the thresholds of 20%, 30% or 50% of the voting rights or the registered capital or the intention to
change the holding so that the insurance undertaking is not a controlled enterprise any longer.
According to section 47 no. 5 VAG the insurance undertaking itself must also notify BaFin of the acquisition or disposal of a

qualifying holding in its own undertaking, the reaching as well as exceeding or falling short of the holding thresholds of 20%, 30% and
50% of the voting rights or of the capital as well as the fact that the undertaking becomes a subsidiary of another undertaking, as
soon as the insurance undertaking gains knowledge of the forthcoming change of the holding structure.

BaFin may not only prohibit acquisition or increase of a qualifying holding but also has the authority to issue orders to share-
holders retrospectively if they jeopardise a prudent management of the insurance company. In particular, BaFin may prohibit the
exercise of voting rights and may order that disposal of shares is subject to BaFin approval. For further information regarding owner-
ship control and regulatory supervision of holders of a qualifying holding, see “13.3.3 Supervision of holders of a qualifying holding
(bedeutende Beteiligung)”.
16.8.1.2 Notification Thresholds and Attribution Rules

Pursuant to Section 33 para. 1 WpHG, anyone who acquires or whose shareholding in any other way reaches or exceeds 3%,
5%, 10%, 15%, 20%, 25%, 30%, 50% or 75% of the total number of voting rights in the Company, is required to concurrently notify
both the Company and BaFin of such occurrence. Subsequent notifications are required if such person (i) acquires additional shares
or in any other way reaches or exceeds a higher threshold or (ii) sells or in any other way falls below the aforementioned thresholds.

All such notifications must be submitted without undue delay, and no later than within four trading days. The four-day notifi-
cation period starts at the time the person or entity subject to the notification requirement has knowledge of or, in consideration of
the circumstances should have had knowledge of, his proportion of voting rights reaching, exceeding or falling below the aforemen-
tioned thresholds. The WpHG contains a conclusive presumption that the person or entity subject to the notification requirement
has knowledge at the latest two trading days after such an event occurs. Moreover, a person or entity is deemed to already hold
shares as of the point in time such person or entity has an unconditional and due claim of transfer related to such shares. If a thresh-
old has been reached or crossed due to a change in the total number of voting rights, the notification period starts at the time the
person or entity subject to the notification requirement has knowledge about such change, or upon the publication of the revised
total number of voting rights by the Company, at the latest.

In connection with these requirements, Section 34 WpHG contains various attribution rules. For example, voting rights at-
tached to shares held by a subsidiary are attributed to its parent company. Similarly, voting rights attached to shares held by a third
party for the account of a person or entity are attributed to such person or entity. Voting rights which a person or entity is able to
exercise as a proxy according to such person's or entity's discretion are also attributed to such person or entity. Furthermore, any
coordination by a person or entity with a third party on the basis of an agreement or in any other way generally results in an attribu-
tion of the full amount of voting rights held by, or attributed to, the third party as well as to such person or entity. Such acting-in-
concert generally requires a consultation on the exercise of voting rights or other efforts designed to effect a permanent and materi-
al change in the business strategy of the Company (e.g., fundamental changes to the Group’s business model or a sale of a substan-
tial part of the Group’s assets). Accordingly, the exercise of voting rights does not necessarily have to be the subject of acting-in-
concert. Coordination in individual cases, however, is not considered as acting in concert.

Except for the 3%-threshold, similar notification requirements towards the Company and BaFin exist, if the aforementioned
thresholds are reached, exceeded or undercut, because the shareholder holds financial instruments that (i) confer to him (a) the un-
conditional right to acquire already issued shares of the Company to which voting rights are attached when due or (b) discretion to
exercise his right to acquire such shares, or (ii) relate to such shares and have a similar economic effect as the aforementioned in-
struments, whether or not conferring a right to a physical settlement. Thus, the latter mentioned notification requirements also ap-
ply, for example, to share swaps against cash consideration and contracts for difference. In addition, a person or entity is subject to a
notification requirement towards the Company and BaFin if the sum of the voting rights from shares and (financial) instruments held
or attributed to such person or entity reaches, exceeds or falls below the aforementioned thresholds, again except for the 3%
threshold.
16.8.1.3 Exceptions to Notification Requirements

There are certain exceptions to the notification requirements. For example, a company is exempt from notification obliga-
tions if its parent company has filed a group notification pursuant to Section 37 para. 1 WpHG. If the Company’s parent company is
itself a subsidiary, then the relevant company is exempt from notification obligations if its parent's parent company has filed such
group notification. Moreover, shares or instruments held by a credit institution or a credit securities services company with a regis-
tered seat in the EU or in another Member State are not taken into account for determining the notification obligation or proportion
of voting rights held, provided (i) the shares or instruments are held in such credit institution's or credit securities services company's
trading book, (ii) they amount to no more than 5% of the Company’s voting rights, do not grant the right to acquire more than 5% of
the voting rights, or do not have a similar economic effect and (iii) it is ensured that the voting rights pertaining to such shares or in-
struments are not exercised or otherwise utilized.
16.8.1.4 Fulfillment of Notification Requirements
If any notification obligation is triggered, the notifying person or entity is required to fully complete the notification form set

forth as an annex to the German Securities Trading Regulation (Wertpapierhandelsanzeigeverordnung). The notice may be submitted
either in German or English, in writing or via fax. Irrespective of the event triggering the notification, the notice must include (i) the
number and proportion of voting rights, (ii) the number and proportion of instruments and (iii) the aggregate number and proportion
of voting rights and instruments held by, or attributed to, the notifying person or entity. In addition, the notice must include certain
attribution details (e.g., the first name, surname and date of birth of the notifying individual or the legal name, seat and state of a
notifying entity, the event triggering the notification, the date on which the threshold was reached or crossed and whether voting
rights or instruments are attributed).

As a domestic issuer in Germany, the Company is required to publish such notices without undue delay, but no later than
three trading days after receipt, via media outlets or outlets where it can be assumed that the notice will be disseminated in the en-
tire EU and in all other Member States. Such publications shall only be made in the English-language. The Company is also required
to transmit these publications to BaFin, specifying the time of publication and the media used and to the German Company Register
(Unternehmensregister) for storage.
16.8.1.5 Consequences of Violations of Notification Requirements

Rights of shares held by shareholders, or from which voting rights are attributed to shareholders, do not exist for as long as
the notification requirements are not fulfilled or not fulfilled appropriately. This temporary nullification of rights applies, in particu-
lar, to dividend, voting and subscription rights. However, it does not apply to entitlements to dividend and liquidation gains if the
notifications were not omitted wilfully and have since been submitted. If the shareholder wilfully or grossly negligently fails to dis-
close the correct proportion of voting rights held, the rights attached to shares held by or attributed to such shareholder cease to
exist for a period of six months after such shareholder has correctly filed the necessary notification, except if the variation was less
than 10% of the actual voting right proportion and no notification with respect to reaching, exceeding or falling below the aforemen-
tioned thresholds, including the 3% threshold, was omitted. In addition, a fine may be imposed for failure to comply with notification
obligations.
16.8.1.6 Special Notification Requirements for more than 10% of the Voting Rights

Pursuant to Section 43 WpHG, a shareholder who reaches or exceeds the threshold of 10% of the voting rights of the Com-
pany, or a higher threshold, is required to notify the Company within 20 trading days regarding the objective being pursued through
the acquisition of such voting rights, as well as regarding the source of funds used for the purchase. Changes in those objectives must
also be reported within 20 trading days. The Articles of Association have not made use of the option to release shareholders from
this disclosure obligation. In calculating whether the 10%-threshold has been reached, the aforementioned attribution rules apply.
The Company is required to publish any notification pursuant to Section 43 WpHG it receives without undue delay and no later than
within three trading days.
16.8.2 Mandatory Offers

Pursuant to the WpÜG, every person whose share of voting rights reaches or exceeds 30% of the voting rights of the Compa-
ny is required to publish this fact, including the percentage of its voting rights, within seven calendar days of crossing this threshold.
Such publication must be furnished on the Internet and by means of an electronic system for disseminating financial information.
The WpÜG contains a series of provisions intended to ensure the attribution of shareholdings to the person who actually controls the
voting rights attached to such shares.

Once the share of voting rights exceeds 30% of the voting rights of the Company, such shareholder is required to make a
mandatory tender offer to all shareholders of the Company. Under certain conditions, BaFin may grant an exemption from this rule.
If the relevant shareholder fails to give notice of reaching or exceeding the 30%-threshold or fails to submit the mandatory tender
offer, such shareholder is barred from exercising the rights associated with these shares (including voting rights and, in case of willful
failure to send the notice and failure to subsequently send the notice in a timely manner, the right to dividends) for the duration of
the delinquency. A fine may also be imposed in such cases.
16.8.3 Managers’ Transactions

A person discharging managerial responsibilities within the meaning of Article 3 para. 1 no. 25 MAR (i.e., the members of the
Management Board and the Supervisory Board), must notify the Company and BaFin of transactions undertaken for their own ac-
count relating to the Company’s shares or to financial instruments based on the Company's shares (subject to a €5,000.00 de-minimis
exception per calendar year for all such transactions). This also applies to persons closely associated with a person discharging man-
agerial responsibilities within the meaning of Article 3 para. 1 no. 26 MAR. Such notifications shall be made promptly and no later
than three business days after the date of the relevant transaction. The Company shall ensure that such notifications are made public
promptly and no later than three business days after the relevant transaction.

During a closed period of 30 calendar days before the announcement of an interim financial report or a year-end report
which the Company is required to make public according to (i) the rules of the trading venue where the Company's shares are admit-

ted to trading or (ii) national law, persons discharging managerial responsibilities are prohibited from conducting for their own ac-
count or for the account of a third party any transactions directly or indirectly relating to shares or debt instruments of the Company,
or to derivatives or other financial instruments linked to such securities.
16.8.4 Short Selling Regulation (Ban on Naked Short-Selling)

Pursuant to Regulation (EU) no. 236/2012 of the European Parliament and of the Council of March 14, 2012 on short selling
and certain aspects of credit default swaps (the “Short Selling Regulation”), the European Commission’s delegated regulation for the
purposes of detailing the Short Selling Regulation, and the German EU Short Selling Implementation Act (EU-Leerverkaufs-
Ausführungsgesetz) of November 15, 2012, the short-selling of the Company’s shares is only permitted under certain conditions. In
addition, under the provisions of the Short Selling Regulation, significant net-short selling positions in the Company’s shares must be
reported to BaFin and published if they exceed a specific percentage. The reporting and publication process is detailed in the German
Regulation on Net-Short Positions (Netto-Leerverkaufspositionsverordnung) of December 17, 2012. The net short-selling positions
are calculated by offsetting the short positions of a natural person or legal entity in the Company’s shares with its long positions in
such shares. The details are regulated in the Short Selling Regulation and the other regulations the European Commission enacted on
short-selling. In certain situations described in the Short Selling Regulation, BaFin may restrict short-selling and comparable transac-
tions.
17. GOVERNING BODIES OF THE COMPANY
17.1.   Overview

The governing bodies of the Company are the Management Board (Vorstand), the Supervisory Board (Aufsichtsrat) and the
shareholders’ meeting (Hauptversammlung). The Company has a two-tier management and control system, consisting of the Man-
agement Board and the Supervisory Board. The responsibilities and powers of the Company’s governing bodies are determined by
the German Stock Corporation Act (Aktiengesetz – “AktG”), the Articles of Association and the rules of procedure of both the Super-
visory Board (Geschäftsordnung des Aufsichtsrats) and the Management Board (Geschäftsordnung des Vorstands).

The shareholders’ meeting elects the members of the Supervisory Board, which in turn appoints the members of the Man-
agement Board. The Supervisory Board is entitled to remove any member of the Management Board under certain circumstances.
Simultaneous membership in the Supervisory Board and the Management Board is not permitted under German law, as the Supervi-
sory Board is responsible for supervising the management of the Company by the Management Board. However, in exceptional cases
and for an interim period, a member of the Supervisory Board may take a vacant seat on the Management Board. During this period,
such individual may not perform any duties for the Supervisory Board. The duration of such stand-in arrangement may not exceed a
maximum period of one year.

The Management Board is responsible for managing the Company in accordance with applicable law, the Articles of Associa-
tion and its rules of procedure, including the distribution-of-business plan (Geschäftsverteilungsplan). The Management Board repre-
sents the Company in dealings with third parties. As set out in the AktG, the Supervisory Board advises and oversees the Manage-
ment Board’s administration of the Company, but is itself generally not authorized to manage or represent the Company. The Super-
visory Board may amend the Articles of Association if such amendments are purely semantic.

The Articles of Association or the Supervisory Board must, however, designate types of transactions that may only be con-
ducted with the approval of the Supervisory Board. Matters subject to the approval of the Supervisory Board or of a committee of
the Supervisory Board pursuant to the Articles of Association or the rules of procedure of the Management Board currently include
the:

In addition to the aforementioned transactions and measures, the Supervisory Board may make other types of transactions
and measures subject to its approval by amending the rules of procedure of the Management Board or the Supervisory Board or by a
resolution of the Supervisory Board. The Supervisory Board may also grant revocable consent in advance to a certain group of trans-
actions in general or to individual transactions that meet certain requirements.

Each member of the Management Board and Supervisory Board owes a duty of loyalty, duty of legality and duty of care to
the Company. In discharging these duties, each member of these bodies must consider a broad spectrum of interests, particularly
those of the Company and its shareholders, employees and creditors. In addition, the Management Board must also take into con-
sideration the shareholders’ rights to equal treatment and equal access to information. If members of the Management Board or Su-
pervisory Board breach their duties, they may be jointly and severally liable with the other members of the Management Board or
the Supervisory Board to the Company for any damages the Company has incurred.

Under German law, shareholders generally have no right to directly assert claims against members of the Management Board
or Supervisory Board if they believe that such members have violated their duties to the Company (i.e., only the Company has the
right to enforce such claims against the members of the Management Board or Supervisory Board). With respect to claims against
members of the Management Board, the Company is represented by the Supervisory Board, and with respect to claims against
members of the Supervisory Board, the Company is represented by the Management Board. The German Federal Supreme Court
(Bundesgerichtshof) has ruled that the Supervisory Board is generally required to assert claims against members of the Management
Board if they are likely to succeed unless significant interests of the Company conflict with the pursuit of such claims and outweigh
the interests of the Company asserting such claims against members of the Management Board.

If either the Supervisory Board or the Management Board decides not to pursue claims of the Company against members of
the respective other governing body for violations of their duties, such claims must nevertheless be asserted if the shareholders’
meeting adopts a resolution to this effect with a simple majority of the votes validly cast. The shareholders’ meeting may also ap-

point a special representative (besonderer Vertreter) to assert such claims. Shareholders whose aggregate shareholdings amount to
10% of the Company’s share capital or a pro rata share of €1 million in the Company’s share capital may also motion for the compe-
tent court to appoint such a special representative. If there are facts that justify the suspicion that the Company was harmed by dis-
honesty or a gross violation of laws or the Articles of Association, shareholders whose aggregate shareholdings amount to 1% of the
Company’s share capital or a pro rata share of €100,000.00 in the Company’s share capital may under certain conditions assert
claims of the Company against members of the Management Board or Supervisory Board in their own names. However, such claims
become inadmissible once the Company itself files a suit to assert such claims.

In addition, the Company’s shareholders’ meeting may appoint special auditors (Sonderprüfer) to audit transactions, particu-
larly management transactions, with a simple majority of the votes validly cast. If the shareholders’ meeting rejects a motion to ap-
point special auditors, the competent court shall appoint such special auditors upon a motion by shareholders whose aggregate
shareholdings amount to 1% of the Company’s share capital or a pro rata share of €100,000.00 in the Company’s share capital, if
there are facts that justify the suspicion that the relevant occurrence involved acts of dishonesty or gross violations of the law or the
Articles of Association. If the shareholders’ meeting has resolved to appoint special auditors, the competent court shall appoint dif-
ferent special auditors upon a motion by shareholders whose aggregate shareholdings amount to 1% of the Company’s share capital
or a pro rata share of €100,000.00 in the Company’s share capital, if such appointment appears necessary due to reasons concerning
the original special auditors.

Shareholders and shareholder associations may solicit via the shareholders’ forum of the German Federal Gazette (Bun-
desanzeiger), which is also accessible via the website of the German Company Register (Unternehmensregister), other shareholders
to file a motion, jointly or by proxy, for the appointment of special auditors, for the appointment of a special representative, the
convention of a shareholders’ meeting, or the exercise of voting rights in a shareholders’ meeting.

The Company may only waive or settle claims for damages against members of the Management Board or Supervisory Board
if at least three years have elapsed since such claims arose and if the shareholders’ meeting has consented to such waiver or settle-
ment by a simple majority vote, provided that a minority of the shareholders whose aggregate shareholdings amount to at least 10%
of the Company’s share capital does not object to such resolution in the minutes of the shareholders’ meeting.

Under German law, neither individual shareholders nor other persons may use their influence on the Company to cause a
member of the Management Board or the Supervisory Board to act in a manner that would be detrimental to the Company. Any per-
son who uses his or her influence on the Company to cause a member of the Management Board or the Supervisory Board, an au-
thorized representative (Prokurist) or an authorized agent (Handlungsbevollmächtigter) to act to the detriment of the Company or its
shareholders may be liable to compensate the Company and the affected shareholders for the resulting losses. Alongside a person
who uses his influence to the detriment of the Company, the members of the Management Board and Supervisory Board can be
jointly and severally liable, if they acted in violation of their duties.
17.2.   Management Board
Overview

Under the Articles of Association, the Management Board consists of at least two persons. The Supervisory Board determines
the exact number of the members of the Management Board. The Supervisory Board may appoint members of the Management
Board for a maximum term of up to five years. Reappointments or extensions, each for a maximum term of up to five years, are
permissible.

The Supervisory Board may revoke the appointment of a member of the Management Board prior to the expiration of the
relevant member’s term for good cause (wichtiger Grund), such as a gross breach of fiduciary duty, inability to properly manage the
Company, or if the Company’s shareholders’ meeting has passed a vote of no-confidence with respect to such member, unless the
no-confidence vote was clearly passed for arbitrary reasons.

The Supervisory Board is also responsible for entering into, amending and terminating service agreements with members of
the Management Board and, in general, for representing the Company in and out of court vis-à-vis the members of the Management
Board.

Pursuant to Section 84 para. 2 AktG and Section 7 para. 2 of the Articles of Association, the Supervisory Board may appoint
any member of the Management Board as chairperson of the Management Board and any other member as deputy chairperson.

If the Management Board consists of only two members, it has a quorum if both members participate in the vote. If the
Management Board consists of three or more members, it has a quorum if at least half of its members take part in the voting. Mem-
bers of the Management Board who abstain from voting are also counted for purposes of calculating the quorum. Resolutions of the
Management Board may also be adopted outside of meetings by casting the vote in writing, in oral form, by telephone, by telefax, by
e-mail or any other customary means of communication or in a combination of the aforementioned forms or in a combination of a
meeting and adopting the resolution outside of a meeting. Where possible, resolutions by the Management Board should be passed
unanimously. If the Management Board has only two members, any resolutions must be adopted unanimously. If unanimity cannot

be achieved, the relevant resolution shall be passed with simple majority of the votes cast, unless other majorities are required by
law, the Articles of Association or the rules of procedure of the Management Board. In the event of a tie, the chairperson of the
Management Board shall have the casting vote; this does not apply if the Management Board only consists of two members.

The Company is legally represented by two members of the Management Board or by one member of the Management
Board jointly with an authorized representative (Prokurist).

The rules of procedure of the Management Board stipulate that the delegation of responsibilities to individual members of
the Management Board is established on the basis of the distribution-of-business plan (Geschäftsverteilungsplan). The distribution-
of-business plan is an annex to the rules of procedure of the Management Board and may only be amended or repealed by resolu-
tion of the Supervisory Board.

Additional provisions regarding, inter alia, the duties of the members of the Management Board, the overall responsibility of
the Management Board, the allocation of responsibilities for particular functions and the Management Board’s internal organization
are set forth in the rules of procedure of the Management Board, which were adopted by the Supervisory Board on October 24,
2018.

pany is obliged to reimburse each member of the Management Board for the employer’s share of the statutory health insurance (ge-

salary for the month in which the triggering event occurs, and for the three subsequent months. In the event of his death, his wife
and, if she is no longer alive, his biological children are entitled to this entitlement. Continued wage payments are not offset against
other income.

The members of the Management Board are covered by directors and officers (“D&O”) insurance policies with coverage in
line with best market practice and a deductible in line with the respective provisions of the AktG. The D&O insurance policies also
cover defense costs in case of criminal prosecution.
